PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent General Business Order of the Day No. 17 being called on forthwith.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Beazley

TALK.START.PARA: —We will take that now.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative, with an absolute majority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the co-operation of the Government in this matter. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House commends the men and women of the Australian Defence Force for their outstanding contribution to Sydney's Australia Day Bicentennial celebrations and notes that the success of the day was in large part due to their willing participation on what was a holiday for other Australians.

There is no one in the House or in Australia who saw that memorable day in Sydney who was not very impressed and moved. I think that part of the success of the day was the participation by the defence forces of Australia, including a magnificent fly-past by aircraft from all three Services. Not only that, members of the defence forces participated in guards of honour and provided a lot of communications. While we were enjoying ourselves on that day many members of the defence forces were working very hard.

This motion seeks to recognise their efforts and commend them. I might just say in passing that it is a pity in this bicentennial year that the defence forces are not more overtly recognised for their contributions. The Tattoo is going around Australia later this year but it is timely to remember the effort and the contribution that the defence forces have made to the security of this country. Those of us who can remember-and I can just dimly-the dark days of 1942 should remind ourselves just what the defence forces have meant to Australia. We would not be leading this sort of life unless that contribution had been made. The same goes for the contribution in World War I, World War II, Korea, Malaya, Borneo and Vietnam. The same effort is being put in now by the men and women of the defence forces. It is also timely to remember, as I go tomorrow to Bundaberg to take part in a celebration and dedication of a Beaufort bomber that crashed during World War II, just what that enormous contribution has been over all these years to Australian security. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to second the motion. A motion equivalent to this has been moved and carried by the Senate, so it is entirely appropriate that the House should join it and ensure that a united view go forth from the whole Parliament to the defence forces, thanking them for their participation on that day. As somebody who had a box seat for the performances of the Defence Force during Australia Day, I can only agree with the sentiments that have been expressed. They did very, very well. Of course, it is sometimes forgotten that this meant they had no holiday. Nevertheless, I am absolutely convinced that every one of the members of the defence forces-and a substantial number participated in it-enjoyed the affair immensely.

SPEECH.PARA: A very impressive fly-past display was put on by the Air Force. I was the recipient of a great deal of comment on the size of that fly-past and how good it looked from the various dignitaries who were at the Sydney Opera House to watch it. In addition to that, enormous work was done on the day by the Navy and the Army, in assisting with the communications involved, the various parades and also, of course, the review of tall ships.

There will be a number of other occasions on which this sort of motion can be moved during the year. By the time this year is out there will be a thoroughgoing awareness in the public mind of both the effectiveness and the performance of our defence forces. The public will have many opportunities to see them. There will be air pageants, there will be a major naval review, there will be military tattoos. There is scarcely a celebration anywhere in the country that will not involve the participation of our armed forces. Some of those events will be spectacular, as I have said. Some will be pretty mundane but nevertheless important to the particular communities that experience them. This bicentennial celebration will be very much a people celebration. Honourable members will find that the armed forces of this country, as is appropriate, are well spread throughout the community and are well able to support that type of activity.

It is well to remember in the bicentennial year the contribution of our armed forces to our survival as a nation and to the fact that we are able to celebrate our 200th birthday at all. I was quite interested yesterday to have a chance to talk with the French Defence Minister on his visit to the War Memorial. He pointed out there was no equivalent in France. He also said he might do something about that. That demonstrates that Australia is not a nation that forgets the contribution of its defence forces. This is a nation which remembers their contribution with honour and in detail. That is appropriate, and the performance that is expected of them and has already been obtained from them in the course of these bicentennial events is further evidence of that high public regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support briefly the comments of the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) on this bipartisan motion, similar to one already passed by the Senate, and add just one dimension. Not only did the Army, Navy and Air Force perform so admirably on 26 January and in the build-up to and during the first two months of our bicentennial year; it was very much a case of business as usual at first light the next morning. This was demonstrated to me most adequately when, thanks to the approval given by the Minister, I, as shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, went out on HMAS Onslow, sailing through the Heads from Sydney early the next morning. That is a submarine, I might add, also with a deficient air-conditioning system. We dived and travelled underwater most of the way to Jervis Bay. The sailors told me that day that they were very proud-although the submarine squadron had not been directly involved the day before-that there was such a tremendous reception for the armed forces component of the Australia Day observance in Sydney on 26 January.

SPEECH.PARA: This is one of those rare occasions when a motion goes through with unanimous support in both Houses of Parliament. Last year the same thing happened with the Vietnam veterans welcome home parade, which was recognised by motions in both Houses of Parliament. It should happen more often. I commend the motion to the House and support the recognition, long overdue, of the Australian Army, Navy and Air Force for all their efforts. I wish them well as they carry out their duties in this bicentennial year and I wish them well as they maintain a defence capability for Australia during this difficult period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the remarks of the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). I join with them in placing on record that on 26 January 1988 a contingent of the Australian Army was present at the raising of the Australian flag in Flinders Mall, Townsville, to celebrate the Bicentenary of our nation. That flag was raised in the same place as the Australian flag in its present design was first raised in this continent on 16 September 1901 by Lord Hopetoun, the first Governor-General of Australia. The Minister was correct when he said that in virtually every commemorative celebration for our Bicentenary in Australia this year there will be-or should be-the presence of members of the Australian armed forces.

SPEECH.PARA: In this country, more than in any other democracy that I can think of, the armed forces are so much part and parcel of our community. As the representative of an electorate which hosts more than 10 per cent of the Australian Army and nearly 6 per cent of the Australian Defence Force, I point out that the armed forces are not only the defenders and protectors of the freedoms of our country, but also, more than anything, part of the civilian community of Townsville. They occupy a very special place of honour in the hearts and minds of everyone in Townsville. I am certain that the motion that has been moved in this House this morning will receive the wholehearted support of every honourable member. I commend the honourable member for McPherson for moving it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take a brief moment to echo the words of the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) because what he has said certainly applies to my own constituents in Holsworthy. I join with the honourable member in commending the motion to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 February, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Carlton had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its disgraceful mismanagement of the Austudy scheme, causing distress and financial embarrassment to thousands of students and their families who have had to wait for lengthy periods before receiving their entitlements.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the bene-fit of those listening to the broadcast today, I point out that this is a continuation of a debate which began yesterday on the Student Assistance Legislation Amendment Bill which is essentially about the tracking down by the Government of fraud and overpayments in the area of Austudy. I regret that the Government, in bringing legislation before the Parliament to amend Austudy arrangements, has yet again failed to address some of the glaring anomalies of the Austudy program. Whilst the Opposition does not intend to oppose this legislation, as we support the crackdown on fraud and overpayments, we are constrained to condemn the Government for failing to address the educational needs in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party of Australia went to the last election with a good record of a creative and progressive education policy which it then presented. Without that policy I do not believe some of the changes which we see being mooted in the Government would have been made. We went to the last election saying that Austudy and unemployment benefits should be the same and, of course, that happened this year. Our Party also has creative ideas, which is more than can be said for the Government in the educational field. I refer in particular to one of the aspects of Austudy which many people opposed very strongly, and that was the payment of Austudy directly to students aged between 16 and 18 years. I think that the previous Opposition spokesman for education encouraged the Minister to change that so that payments could be made to parents. That is the case now, even though parents have to apply for it.

It was inevitable that this Government would become bankrupt of ideas for the simple reason that it has lost touch with the people. The coalition has remained in touch with the people and can understand their needs. It is only if people in this Parliament stay in touch with the electorate that we can understand its needs, share its hopes and provide it with a vision. This Government is out of touch and its Party has said so. The people of the Adelaide electorate have said so by electing their first Liberal member for nearly 20 years. The Premier of New South Wales has said so and the Government's lack of ideas says so also. The need is clear but the Government will not face it in this area. The Government fails to recognise that many young people are faced with a hopeless situation which is due largely to this Government's economic policies-policies which have maintained an unemployment rate that is 40 per cent higher than under the previous coalition Government, policies which mean that there are 700,000 more Australians living in poverty now than there were in 1983 and policies which have extended the period of unemployment, on average, from 32 to 58 weeks.

Yesterday I was interested to hear the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) congratulate the Government on rising retention rates in our schools, saying that that was due to the Government's policies. One of the real reasons why retention rates have increased in Australia is that parents know there is very little option but to encourage their young people to stay at school. It is absolutely mind-boggling that a government can claim that it is the real reason why students are going on to higher education. The major factor involved is that parents know that their young people have very little option, so there is now very strong encouragement from parents to have their children continue in education. It is not due to Government activity. Education is vital to the revitalisation of employment prospects and the Australian economy as a whole. The Government has rightly said that one of our key goals in education must be to increase our participation in education-commonly called retention rates.

In introducing Austudy the Government argued that it was trying to rationalise student assistance programs. Yet the Austudy program maintains significant inequities. Today I wish to address a couple of particular problems which I see in Austudy. Firstly, Austudy penalises students who have supported themselves for a period but who, due to a change in circumstances, apply for Austudy. At present, students who have provided their own support for one or more years are penalised. For example, a student who pays his or her own way, and completes one year of a three-year course and then changes to another course, can obtain Austudy only for the first two years of the new course. Although such a person may have successfully completed the year in the first course, the fact that both courses are theoretically free of fees and the fact that the person was not a burden on the Commonwealth are apparently of no consideration. Such an anomaly acts as a disincentive for students ever to support themselves or to complete their course.

I believe that within the present system students should be entitled to three years of Commonwealth support for tertiary education, conditional only on meeting eligibility requirements and satisfactory progress. The reason for students dropping out of schools or for continuing in their studies are many and varied, but I believe that a most significant factor is the support given to those families supporting young people going on to further study. For example, let me look at how Austudy allows for the families of isolated children. People on the mainland of Australia might be surprised to learn that in Tasmania there are many children who are regarded as isolated. There are nearly 700 such children located throughout the State, in the west coast regions, the Tasman Peninsula, Flinders Island and the central highlands. In my own electorate of Braddon there are isolated children in the far north west and on King Island.
Let me read out an extract from a letter from a constituent of mine-the father of an isolated child. It reads:

My purpose in writing to you is to bring to your attention and seek your support in rectifying a gross anomaly that appears in the Austudy eligibility criteria, particularly in relation to HSC students who are forced, because of isolation, to live away from home compared to TAFE students of the same age who are similarly forced to live away from home.

No doubt that comes about in Tasmania because that State has year 11 and year 12 colleges which are not available to all high school students in their region. Children often have to move away from home. The Australian Capital Territory has a similar set-up, but at this stage none of the other States has. My constituent continued:

As the guidelines stand at the moment if my 17-year old daughter attended a Tech College for full-time study, she would be entitled to claim, depending on my income, a portion of $3,974 but because she attends an HSC College she can only claim a portion of $2,614, a difference of $1,380.

I also have a son studying at University.... If I claimed (isolated children's allowance) for my daughter I would receive the non-income tested payment of $989 but I would not qualify for any assistance under Austudy for my son because I would be unable to claim sibling concession for my daughter under Austudy. But a person with the same income as mine and with children of the same age with one at University and one at Tech College would qualify for sibling concession and would receive an additional $1,380 assistance over what my children will receive this year.

I agree with my constituent. This is hardly an equitable situation. This Government fails to recognise that parents are the main contributing factor in determining whether their children will continue to pursue their studies.

We are talking here about a test on parental income. No educational factors come into play. Effectively, we are paying a subsidy to parents to take a particular direction for their children's education. In this case there is an incentive for parents to say to their young people that they ought to go on to technical college and not do the higher school certificate, because then they can receive more benefits. Parents, together with their children, should be able to make educational choices free from these sorts of pressures. I call on the Minister to indicate how a Government which preaches equity can justify the maintenance of this inequity, which discriminates against those already disadvantaged in education through isolation. I call on the Minister to look at the interaction of these two schemes.

In Tasmania the school retention rates are fairly low. In 1985 the male retention rate for years 7 to 12 for Australia as a whole was 42 per cent; for the north-west coast it was 16 per cent. In some respects I can understand why that occurs. There, people are satisfied, largely speaking, with the way in which they live. There are lots of things that young people can do and enjoy without their having to go on to further education. However, in redressing this disparity the people on the north-west coast have displayed their commitment to education. I believe that the north-west coast is one of Australia's leading communities in addressing the problems of educational access. One creative initiative by which it is leading the nation is the North-West Council for Community Education. Whilst the Commonwealth has assumed responsibility for tertiary education, it is interesting to note that this centre is funded by the State Government. A similar centre in Darwin is funded by the Commonwealth. For students the centre acts as an education broker and as their advocate with tertiary institutions. For the institutions it tries to keep them in touch with the local service demands and acts as a base in the region.

The centre has been a key element in the real progress made in tertiary education access over recent years. North-west enrolments in mainland institution courses have increased 50 per cent in the last nine years. The Tasmanian Institute of Technology has established study centres in Devonport and Burnie, and the University of Tasmania now offers courses on the coast; teleconferencing facilities are being used to bring together scattered classes.

In education it is crucial that all Australians have equal access at the gate. Initiatives such as the North-West Council strive to achieve this goal by effectively moving the gate much closer to the people in the region. All of these efforts to help the remote regions will be useless if the students, or their families, cannot afford to do the courses of their choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's policy on education is hopelessly flawed and was quite properly rejected by the Australian people at the last election. Perhaps members of the Opposition should ask themselves why teachers and all educators support the Government. They should take a look at our nation. They hold two States. But, despite the fact that they hold two States, in every State of the Commonwealth the Australian Teachers Federation and other associations to which educators belong resoundingly give their support to this Government because the Opposition's policy is not worth a tinker's damn.

SPEECH.PARA: I can tell those opposite one other thing that people recognise. They recognise that the Opposition has two policies on every subject. I invite honourable members opposite to read this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. It is interesting because a former Ombudsman in New South Wales, Mr George Masterman, has revealed a few truths. A Mr Pickering, who is the Opposition spokesman on police matters in New South Wales--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Madam Speaker. The honourable member is referring to matters wholly outside the area of education, let alone this Bill.
—The honourable member may continue.
—He told Mr Masterman, `This is our policy until the election. I am trying to win the vote of policemen, so we have a very attractive policy until the election'.

—Order! I point out to the honourable member for Hunter that I was not in the chair for the preceding speech. I am not quite sure how far and wide previous speakers ranged. I am aware that the Bill states `and for related purposes' but I ask the honourable member to relate his remarks to the contents of the Bill.
—Thank you, Madam Speaker, although I think I have now proved my point. The point I am making is that the Opposition has two policies-one for public display and also a secret agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has its priorities right. One of its chief priorities is equal opportunity for all. Of course, there cannot be equal opportunity for all unless every person is given a chance to develop his or her natural abilities and talents, to acquire skills and knowledge and to progress to the highest academic level of which the individual is capable. This Government is committed to equality of education for all, to providing assistance to bring education within the reach of all and to creating a better educated Australia.

In the Government's pursuit of these commitments its achievements have been remarkable. So remarkable have those policies been that in the eyes of everyone who knows anything about education they have left the Opposition's policies for dead. When did we last hear from the Opposition spokesman on education in this House? Perhaps I should say, `When did we last hear a meaningful contribution from the Opposition spokesman on education in this House?'. Can anyone on either side of the House claim seriously that the Opposition has made a meaningful contribution to the education agenda?

Because of this nation's disastrous trading problems, the Government has inherited the unenviable task of restructuring and modernising the economy. We have not shirked the hard decisions. I congratulate the Australian people who have recognised the need for hard decisions to be made in order to restore the health of the economy and those people who have supported the rational economic management provided by this Government and rejected the worthless economic nonsense offered by those opposite.

Essential to the Hawke Government's strategy of dragging the economy out of the shadows into the sunlight is the lifting of the educational standards of the work force. Unless the educational standards, training and work skills of Australians are lifted dramatically, this nation will not be able to compete successfully with countries such as Japan, the United States of America and other trading rivals. So this Government is striving mightily, and succeeding magnificently, in producing a better educated and more skilled work force. Everyone will be aware that education costs money, but in difficult economic times this Government found the money for a giant leap forward in education.

The Federal Government has the major funding responsibility for higher education, for universities, colleges of advanced education and institutes of tertiary education. It also provides a share of the funding for the States technical and further education system. Every year since 1983-84 the Government has provided increases in real terms to its areas of responsibility in education. But our greatest achievement is yet to come. I will return to that point later.

We have succeeded in encouraging students to stay on at school. The number of full time students staying on to complete their education has risen from 48 per cent in 1983 to 56 per cent in 1987. It is an amazing increase. In my Hunter electorate the year 11 retention rate in Maitland high schools has increased by 11 per cent, from 50 per cent to 61 per cent. The same success story rings loud and clear in other areas of the Hunter electorate such as in Cessnock, Singleton, Beresfield and Merriwa. The retention rate has increased not only in high schools but also in universities, institutes of higher learning and technical and further education colleges.

As I said earlier, the best is yet to come. The Green Paper on higher education will revolutionise education in Australia and propel us triumphantly into the twenty-first century. What has been the key to the Government's unprecedented success in education? Undoubtedly, the key to the Government's success has been Austudy. In 1987 the Government replaced the former tertiary education assistance scheme (TEAS), adult secondary education assistance and the secondary allowance scheme with Austudy. TEAS and the other schemes were good but Austudy, despite early teething problems, is brilliant. There were early teething problems; I am well aware of that. When one puts into place such a massive scheme as Austudy is, of course there will be growth problems. But now those growth problems have been largely overcome and the Austudy system is working very successfully.

People will not pursue education if they cannot afford the costs. Austudy has brought education within the reach of all. During 1988, 241,000 students will receive Austudy assistance. This includes 128,000 tertiary students, 109,000 secondary students and 4,000 adult secondary students. Other students will receive postgraduate awards and other programs will assist Aborigines, migrants and the children of certain veterans. Because of Austudy, no person is denied the right to educational opportunities.

Some people-not that many-criticise Austudy because means testing rules them ineligible. But hundreds of thousands of Australians are gaining opportunities which would be denied them were it not for Austudy. In future years, millions of Australians will bless Austudy. But even the most beneficial and brilliant of schemes is open to exploitation. No-one will deny that Austudy has been subjected to rip-offs. The Bill presently before the House, the Student Assistance Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973 so as to implement measures to reduce Austudy fraud and to assist in the recovery of overpayments. Time prevents me from dealing with every section of this Bill, but I know that every honest Australian will agree that it is a fundamental responsibility of the Government to ensure that Austudy payments, which are provided at considerable cost to the taxpayer, go to the students for whom the scheme is intended. This Bill will ensure that those entitled to Austudy will get it and that those not entitled to Austudy will not get it. People who get Austudy through fraud will get something less pleasant when they are caught-they will get it in the neck.

This Bill quite rightly provides penalties for false claims or other deceptions. I believe that fines, and even imprisonment, are totally justified. Hopefully, this Bill will stop the cheats. The extra money saved or recovered might enable the Government to lift the income threshold which currently governs eligibility. Perhaps the extra money will enable a wide-ranging investigation to be carried out into matters which have disturbed every member of this House. I get so frustrated so frequently when an honest worker's child just fails to satisfy the Austudy income requirements when I know only to well that the child of a really affluent family, which may be living in the same street as the poor child from the battling family, receives total Austudy assistance. Tax concessions which produce such distortions leave me staggered.

It came to my notice recently that a person received overpayments of unemployment benefit and assistance under the former tertiary education assistance scheme in excess of $25,000 over three years. The circumstances were serious in that they involved aliases, forgery and false statements. In this instance, the person was charged under the Crimes Act 1914. Indeed, had the person been charged under section 91 of the Student Assistance Act, the maximum penalty at that time would have been a paltry $100 fine. The maximum penalty under the Social Security Act was 12 months imprisonment or a $2,000 fine. In this particular case, the punishment plainly did not fit the crime.

It is not hard to understand why the person involved wanted to be charged under the Student Assistance Act and not the Crimes Act. Had the person been charged under the Student Assistance Act, which lays down a maximum fine of $100, the court would have been entitled to criticise the prosecution on the basis that the charges did not adequately reflect the criminality of the conduct and did not provide the court with an appropriate basis for sentence. As it turned out, the person involved received a substantial prison sentence.

That is just one instance of which I am aware, and in that instance the overpayment was considerable. There is no question but that overpayments occur-hopefully, not regularly on the scale that I have described. The Bill before us provides the legislative basis for recovery of overpayments and allows for the imposition of more substantial fines for those who abuse the Austudy system. It is essential that Austudy assistance be directed to students who need that vital assistance to enable them to pursue their education. Abuse of any financial support system, be it Austudy or social security, cannot be tolerated. I congratulate the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), and I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in the comments of the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon). You may not have had the privilege, Mr Deputy Speaker, of hearing him, and if you consider that I am discussing the matter in a wide-ranging way, let me say that I shall be doing so only by way of rebuttal at this stage. The honourable member for Hunter had the audacity to suggest that Opposition members were not significant contributors in matters of student assistance and areas of education policy generally. He asked when the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) last made a significant contribution in debates of this sort. Of course, it was pointed out-in a disorderly fashion perhaps, by way of interjection-that the honourable member for Mackellar did so yesterday in a very significant speech on this very subject.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say to the honourable member for Hunter that in the area of legislation impacting upon students and in the area of policy development in relation to education, not only has the honourable member for Mackellar been a Significant contributor to the debate but also so was his predecessor as shadow Minister, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), in the previous Parliament. In regard to the Student Assistance Legislation Amendment Bill and the student assistance legislation that is being amended, the specific proposals for the aligning of Austudy in the form that it is in now to previous arrangements under the tertiary education assistance scheme (TEAS) and unemployment benefits were matters that were on the agenda largely because of pressure from Opposition members.

It is a significant fact, and it was one of which I became aware in my electorate over time, that students were concerned that other young people leaving school and not going on to pursue other studies appeared to be advantaged in being eligible for unemployment benefits under more generous terms when students were very often not eligible for the old TEAS arrangements and were having to incur a significant and immediate cost penalty in undertaking tertiary studies. It was an important development that we saw when the legislation to bring in the new form of Austudy arrangements was introduced.

The honourable member for Hunter ought to be aware that the teething problems on which he spoke, which arose following the introduction of this legislation, were problems that were very obvious to the Opposition, and particularly the Opposition spokesman, when the package was revealed. It was very much as a result of the efforts of the honourable member for Tangney, as recounted yesterday by the honourable member for Mackellar, that changes were made in the Austudy package.

I particularly became aware in my own electorate of one of the concerns of parents of students who were in the 16- to 18-year-old group staying on at school when, under the package as proposed, the funds were to be put into the hands of the students still at school. I found it an extraordinary proposition, particularly in households where there might be a supporting mother who had a very limited pension income. She might well find that she was providing a roof and sustenance to a child who was prepared to take the student assistance allowance in his pocket and not have the immediate welfare of the total family in mind and not be prepared to make a contribution to the family situation.

Very often, relationships between young adolescents and their parents are such that, as the young person strikes out and wants to assume a separate identity, the student does not have a sense of responsibility in financial matters. In such circumstances, we were likely to see very considerable hardship in many homes as a result of the arrangement where the payment was taken away from parents and given to the student. That proposal was put forward seriously by the Government. It was not until the eleventh hour, as described by the honourable member for Mackellar, that the then Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, had a change of heart and accepted the argument put by the Opposition. I am sure I was not the only person to draw that matter to the attention of the shadow Minister and the Minister at that time.

The legislation we are discussing really is in a much more limited area than I have addressed to this point. As I mentioned, the Student Assistance Legislation Act provides the statutory basis for the Austudy payment and the postgraduate award scheme. The Bill before us will include a package of measures to prevent the facilitation of fraud-because I think that is what has happened in the past-and to enable the recovery of overpayments under the two schemes which the student assistance legislation implements. The Bill before us specifically covers these matters. It requires individuals and organisations to provide the information needed to verify entitlements and requires debtors to disclose their financial situation.

The second point is that the Bill makes it an offence to give false information in relation to an application for assistance. At present the offence is not established by statute but under the student assistance regulations. Thirdly, it provides substantial penalties for offences, under the Act and regulations, so it is upgrading the penalties to make them more significant in terms of the changed relativities in this area. Fourthly, it will enable the Department of Education to recover overpayments from money held for a debtor. Fifthly, it will enable an overpayment to be written off or waived, or for agreement to be given to the overpayment being repaid by instalments. At present overpayments are written off or waived under the Audit Act. That is making it administratively a little easier although arrangements were always possible even under the old scheme.

The explanatory memorandum makes it clear that the penalties have changed significantly. The Act currently enables regulations to provide a maximum penalty of $100 for offences. Now the Act will provide, for offences under the Act, a fine of $2,000 or 12 months imprisonment or, for corporations, $10,000, and for offences under the regulations, a fine of $1,000 or six months imprisonment. So there are significant changes. The Minister makes it clear that the Government has been reviewing penalties generally and I think it is appropriate that that should occur from time to time.

The Opposition in its contribution made it clear that it is not opposing the Bill. We suggested a second reading amendment, but the general thrust of the legislation with regard to the penalties and the way in which they are to be imposed is supported subject, I think, to a number of comments on which we would like some clarification. I know my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar, when he spoke yesterday, sought clarification of one area in which I am particularly interested. These provisions are intended to enable better detection, better prevention and recovery of moneys wrongly paid under programs administered by the Department of Education and its successors. I must say, whilst I do not greet those sorts of changes with the same enthusiasm as the honourable member for Hunter, I do believe that penalties ought to be such that people who are knowingly going to try to defraud any welfare or assistance program are properly dealt with. So, I think cheats, as they were referred to, ought to be caught.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you don't want to hit them in the neck.

—That is the point I was about to make. The honourable member for Hunter said that they should get it in the neck. I am not sure what that means. I can only surmise that if one is to get it in the neck it imputes hanging. I know some people have recently advocated the return of hanging. I am a member of the Parliamentary Amnesty Group. I am glad that my Leader, last weekend, asserted once more the freedom we have on this side of the House to exercise our own consciences on this matter. I am not inclined to encourage hanging as the appropriate penalty, even for those cheating the student assistance legislation, though the honourable member for Hunter may be implying that he would. He may care to make a personal explanation on this matter later in the day.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I do invite some comment from the Minister in relation to the provisions which deal with corporations. If the same enthusiasm of the honourable member for Hunter has been displayed by those who draft the legislation-that they proverbially want to put it to corporations in the neck-then perhaps proposed section 31j requires some explanation. Proposed section 31j (1) says:

Where, in proceedings for an offence against this Act or the regulations in respect of any conduct engaged in by a corporation, it is necessary to establish the state of mind of the corporation, it is sufficient to show that a director, servant or agent of the corporation, being a director, servant or agent who engaged in the conduct within the scope of his or her actual or apparent authority, had the state of mind.

I imagine they are generally, because of the problem of proving appropriate mens rea, the sorts of provisions that operate in relation to corporations. It is difficult to establish the state of mind unless something is recorded in minutes or unless it is under seal of the company. I imagine matters of this sort will not be dealt with in that way. Subsection (2) of proposed section 31j goes on:
Any conduct engaged in on behalf of a corporation:
(a) by a director, servant or agent of the corporation within the scope of his or her actual or apparent authority; or

(b) by any other person at the direction or with the consent or agreement (whether express or implied) of a director, servant or agent of the corporation, where the giving of such direction, consent or agreement is within the scope of the actual or apparent authority of the director, servant or agent; shall be deemed, for the purposes of this Act and the regulations, to have been engaged in by the corporation.

So, there is a deeming provision. We are not only going to find it much easier to establish the corporation's state of mind by looking at the employee-servant, agent or director-but we also have the provision which enables us to deem that conduct of the corporation and then we impose later significant penalties up to $10,000. For the sake of completeness I might just mention subclause (3) of proposed section 31j which says:

A reference in subsection (1) to the state of mind of a person includes a reference to the knowledge, intention, opinion, belief or purpose of the person and the person's reasons for the intention, opinion, belief or purpose.

What interests me particularly in relation to these provisions which invoke very significant penalties against corporations and facilitate corporations being prosecuted is the point made in debate yesterday by the honourable member for Mackellar. He raised the point that whilst we impose on presumably private schools, private corporations that are involved in education, a very onerous penalty and we impose on those who are directors, servants or agents of such corporations significant penalties as well as responsibility, one has to ask what happens in relation to public corporations. What happens in relation to those institutions of State governments, those institutions funded by the Commonwealth that enjoy an immunity in relation to these matters? I am concerned that we impose penalties upon the directors, servants and agents of corporations to ensure that the information provided is correct and we impute to them certain states of mind, yet when it comes to dealing with those people in the same position, carrying the same responsibilities for corporations that enjoy government funding, there appears to be an immunity from prosecution, from penalty, an immunity presumably assumed because these organisations publicly funded would be more accountable to direction from government. I would like some clarification of that matter because I would very much regret if, in dealing with this legislation, we created a double standard in which those who were involved in education privately were subjected to significant, harsh penalties and those engaged in public education were able to be accountably free from any responsibility if they engaged in the same form of conduct.

I would like, just in the context of some of the discussion that preceded regarding the level of penalties and these provisions, at least to hold out a plea for balance in the way in which these matters are dealt with. Over time it has been my experience in my electorate that many students have come to me unable to understand with clarity the student assistance regulations. All too often they seek to obtain benefits because they believe they have an entitlement and find out later, sometimes 6 months later, sometimes 8, 9 or 12 months later, that the entitlement that they thought they had had been ruled out when it was considered within the Department. Then, of course, the recovery processes start.

Whilst these penalties are for the purpose of catching cheats such as the one mentioned by the honourable member for Hunter, and penalties ought properly to apply in such circumstances, I think the balance needs to be kept in mind by those officers who have been given those additional powers by the Department. In launching prosecutions and seeking the imposition of penalties, some regard must be had of the way in which the administration itself is functioning. Significant delays may occur in the processing of applications if there is ambiguity in the way in which the student assistance regulations are drafted. I must say, even with some training in the area of interpreting laws, very often I find it difficult to find my way through student assistance regulations and the Act to establish eligibility. Is it any wonder then that many students find themselves in exactly the same position? So, there is a need for this legislation to be looked at by the officers concerned having regard to the difficulties that those who receive benefits under the legislation have, and for some discretion to be exercised.

One of the difficulties I have found in relation to the payment of benefits under these programs is that as we have introduced further legislation and regulations, as we have established with greater certainty the outcome of whether a person is entitled to benefits by using precise legal terms, we have often, failed to put any discretion in the hands of the Minister or the Department to pay benefits where in conscience-in terms of justice between individuals-the circumstances may well warrant the payment of a benefit even though the precise law may deny it. There is a need for the Government to keep students' problems in mind when dealing with these matters, as well as ensuring that the law is properly administered and public moneys properly accounted for.

TALK.START.PARA: -I call the honourable member for Hunter.

—Having been invited by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) to make a personal explanation, I shall do so. I feel that only a wide-ranging imagination and powerful fanciful interpretations would enable the honourable member to imagine that when I said that a person who was guilty of Austudy fraud should `cop it in the neck' I was advocating hanging. I could just as easily have said `cop it in the pants' or the shins or something like that. I am not an advocate of hanging for minor offences of that nature!
—Minor offences?
—Well, for offences of that nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The objective of the Student Assistance Legislation Amendment Bill is to put in place measures designed to facilitate the prevention of fraud and recovery of overpayments under the student assistance scheme. I do not think anyone here would oppose that proposition. For a long time this Government has pursued a strategy of ensuring that available benefits such as social security, unemployment and educational assistance, and so on go to those who legally and financially deserve and need that assistance. This has been part of this Government's commitment to the streamlining of the provision and delivery of government services.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I have been in this House-from 1984-I have noticed a special emphasis on efficiency, on the quality of service provided by government institutions at a Commonwealth level and on the closing of the loopholes. There has also been a special effort to recover moneys that have been illegally obtained. Therefore, the provisions that are before us are not surprising and they must be welcomed by all honourable members. There has also been a commitment from the Hawke Government to upgrade the skills and the capacity of the Australian work force. I recall speeches made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other senior Ministers as to the problems that we have in competing in the world open market.

There is a challenge before us. It is not just a matter of broadening our industrial base, which was regrettably destroyed during the Fraser era, particularly between 1981 and 1983, but it is more a case of ensuring that we have work skills and people who are able to provide the human resources in industry. A catch 22 situation has prevailed in that employers will not move into these industry areas when there are not the qualified, highly skilled and highly trained employees available. Institutions will not have a training program or a course structure for such people unless the jobs are available. I recall a situation in one of the Queensland colleges of advanced education, where there was a stress on high technology. It was suggested that this particular institution should promote courses in that area. But the question was asked: once the courses are there and the students have graduated, where would they get jobs? Those in the industry areas say, `What is the use of moving or investing in these fields unless we have the human resources?'. I believe that this Government is trying to address that problem and it is doing so very effectively.

Regrettably, under the previous Liberal- National Government there was very little incentive to go on to further education. If one compared the dole payment-the unemployment benefit-with what young people received if they stayed at school or went on to college, clearly there was a subtle encouragement to go on the dole. If one went on the dole one's parents' income was not tested; there was no test at all for getting the dole, and the payment was higher. It was no wonder that low and middle income families did not encourage young students to pursue education. Instead, they were happy to see them register for unemployment. This has been changed. I recall that a commitment was given by the previous Minister for Education, Susan Ryan, when she said that over a three-year period the Government would rectify the anomaly; that it would ensure that there was some sort of parallel or squaring up between student allowances and the benefits paid to those people unfortunately unemployed. We have done that. We have paralleled the payments that are now available to young people in order to keep them at school. It has taken three years but they have been three very successful years for the squaring up has been put in place.

We now see that student allowances and unemployment benefits for people between the ages of 16 and 20 are the same. There is no longer an incentive to leave school and go on the dole. Instead there is an incentive to continue education, to go on to a technical and further education college or stay at school for years 11 and 12 in Queensland-there may be different grades in other States-or to pursue a course at a college. It is all part of the strategy of this Government to encourage young people to pursue education and to upgrade the skills of our work force. This strategy has worked, not only in terms of paralleling and bringing together or squaring up the allowances available to students and unemployment benefits, but we also have the statistical information. In 1983 some 32 per cent-32 young people out of every 100-who reached grade 10 did not bother to continue. They either went on the dole or tried to find a job. That percentage has not doubled but it has jumped to more than 50 per cent. In Queensland it has gone up to 55 per cent. I give credit to that State, irrespective of its political colour, for the encouragement it now gives in high schools and other areas to keep young people in education.

This Government has also placed a new emphasis on girls in the education system. I am most impressed with what the Catholic education system is doing to provide special courses to encourage girls to pursue studies in mathematics and science. This is now occurring right across the state system. A major change is taking place in the education environment, but it has been achieved at a price; it has been extremely costly. In 1986 there were about 186,000 recipients of the tertiary education assistance scheme and secondary allowances. That cost the taxpayers in this country $438m. It is a lot of money. This academic year that number will increase to 244,000. The cost will blow out from $438m to $616m. It is very important that that money is well spent. The Government is very conscious of the need to give assistance and to match up the incentives that are available to young people to stay at school.

This year, a 16- or 17-year-old student can receive $50 if staying at home and $76 if living away from home. Those aged 18 and above will get $60 if they stay at home and $91.20 if they live away from home. An important factor has been that the income test has been reviewed. The maximum yearly parental income for a young person to be able to get the full $50 is $26,259; for those living away that figure increases to $31,699. In the 18-year-old group, parents can earn as much as $34,879. That is not the bottom line because consideration is given to other dependants. For instance, for one extra child, the Government recently raised the special deduction from $450 to $1,200. If parents have two extra children, they can now claim an extra $2,500. The amount of money parents are allowed to have and still get assistance to enable their children to stay at school is quite considerable. The Government has also realised that the costs that families face, when there are older children attending university and secondary school, are quite high. The sibling concession has been changed so that the loss a person sustains in his allowance-instead of being $1 for every $4 earned-is now only $1 after he earns an extra $8.

I suggest that the Government deserves credit for the way it has tackled this nation's education needs. It has ensured not only that there is actual cash on hand for students but also that they are given exemptions. Those who get any type of Austudy are exempt from the higher education administrative charge of $263 that students who do not get Austudy have to pay. In fact, $1 of Austudy exempts them from the $263. The Government realises that it should not leave something if it is working; it has to continue to review it. That is certainly taking place.

I note that an Opposition member who spoke previously mentioned the problems of people in isolated areas. I agree. I appreciate that this Government has made special allowances available for those who are boarding, doing correspondence courses or living in a second home somewhere. However, we need to have another look at the way in which we assess income. I suggest-I am sure that thousands of people in country and rural Australia would agree with me-that a family receiving $25,000 and living in a country town or a coalmining area, say, my electorate of central Queensland, does not have the same purchasing power as a family receiving $25,000 and living in Sydney. I think that is true of most capital cities.

We did a test recently in my region and found that some people-for instance, those in my mining towns-were paying $3.69 a kilo for potatoes. A person in Brisbane could buy potatoes for about $1.90 a kilo. The cost is more than double. That is also true with the cost of fuel. I have an argument going at the moment because in central Queensland the cost of fuel is as high as 66c a litre. In the northern part of my electorate it is 69c a litre. I was in Queanbeyan the other day and it was 45c a litre. Sometimes I wonder whether there is a full appreciation of the very special problems facing people in country and rural Australia when it comes to purchasing power and what they must pay for the transportation, food, electricity, telephone calls and so on.

Whilst this Government deserves full credit for the way in which it has revamped the system and the way in which it has considered very carefully the special deduction that should be given to families who have more than one child, we need to start looking at not so much the earned income of a family but the purchasing power of a family. One way of tackling that-I ask the Minister to give it some consideration-is to adopt a zonal approach so that people living in a particular zone get a further deduction or some type of exemption from certain costs. The higher cost of living element must be considered.

I have gathered statistics from all over the nation on the additional burdens that country and rural people have. We must do something about them. One does not have to be thousands of miles away from a coastal city to suffer. In fact, one can be in a town such as Mount Morgan, which is only some 35 kilometres from Rockhampton. One may also carry a cost burden because of lack of transportation, lack of choice and lack of facilities. I ask the Minister to consider that point. As the reviews continue and as we look at the measures used for determining eligibility, we must realise that the cost of living-people's capacity to buy; their purchasing power-is a very important issue.

Another anomaly exists. A moment ago I referred to the income test. I now wish to relate that to assets. The criticism that I hear about Austudy comes from people who say they know of someone who owns a property, has a shop or runs a business somewhere and yet, because that person has a smart accountant who can bodgie the books and come up with a figure that is below the income measure, his children can still get Austudy. I believe that the assets test that has been applied to pensions has been a fantastic success. It has achieved a new quality of life for pensioners because it has meant that more money has been available for pensions and has been passed on to pensioners. Maybe the time has come to look at applying an assets test to Austudy, just as it is applied in other areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the country kids?

—A millionaire such as the honourable member does not understand the problems of ordinary people. But we appreciate his position, so we will cast that aside. We know that some people with assets worth hundreds of thousands of dollars can still, because of the rules, get Austudy for their children.
—Because they are broke.

—That could be taken into consideration, but I am told that the anomalies exist. I raise another anomaly. It is one that is regrettable and one that I raised in the media recently. Problems have arisen because of the application of the income test to those who come to Australia from overseas. I refer to expatriates and New Zealanders. We have a special relationship with New Zealand. I have no argument with assisting our friends across the Tasman, but I think that charity begins at home-not across the Tasman. Whilst I understand the contribution that New Zealanders have made to Australia in wartime and peacetime in education, I cannot accept that, even though there may be only 300 of them-the number is irrelevant; the principle is what I am about-New Zealanders can still come to this country and, regardless of what their parents earn in New Zealand, get Austudy in Australia. I did a test in my State of Queensland and was told that whilst no names or any information was given that could trace the people--
—Did they give you any computer print-outs?

—There were no computer print-outs, which no doubt the honourable member for Moreton would require. I did not ask for them, I just asked for an estimate. I was told that about 60 expatriates and New Zealanders in Queensland-mainly New Zealanders-were getting Austudy. I asked about the number in New South Wales and I was told that the figure was 100-plus. The number would be similar in Victoria. We are talking about from 250 to 300 New Zealanders and expatriates-mainly New Zealanders-getting Austudy. However, my miners, the people in my country areas, who earn over the figures I cited earlier cannot get it. Because of some indiscretion by the Department of Social Security in discussions with the Commonwealth Department of Education-although Commonwealth Education opposed it-the whole system is based on a person's taxable income. If parents' income is earned in New Zealand it is not taken into consideration. Three hundred does not sound like many, but the Austudy payment for a person at university is $4,173, and the exemption from the higher education fee is worth $263, so we are talking of around $4,500. When one multiplies that by around 300 one starts to realise that we are giving away about $1.3m.

SPEECH.PARA: An Australian who lives in New Zealand and works for the Australian High Commission and whose children are in Australia does not have that privilege or right because his income is taxed by this Government. An Australian soldier who is serving in Malaysia and whose children are in Townsville, Cairns, Brisbane or Sydney does not have that privilege. But an expatriate, an Australian, who works for the New Zealand Government or the Papua New Guinea Government and whose kids are in Australia does not have his income counted. That is not good enough. I am told also that that flows into the job search allowance. I understand that that it only for 16- and 17-year-olds, so there would not be many. I am also told that it could affect our first home owners grants system.

I have no argument with helping people in need, but we must help the needy, not the greedy. I put it to this House that it is simply not acceptable that a New Zealander whose family in New Zealand could be earning $100,000 is able to come to this country and take $4,500 a year from the Australian taxpayer for taking up a university place, thereby stopping a person from Queensland or New South Wales continuing his studies. The same rules do not apply to a person from Queensland, New South Wales or wherever. That is not acceptable. I am pleased that the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) has taken this issue on board. I ask him to pursue the proposition that there ought to be some requirement that says that no New Zealander or expatriate can receive such assistance unless he or she has lived here for a certain period.

We have done that with the unemployment benefit. We have built in a rule of six months. People used to come off the boats and planes, say that they would stay permanently, and then go and enrol for the unemployment benefit. We put an end to that after a long campaign. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) addressed that situation. The same needs to be done with student assistance. There needs to be some sort of permanency and residential clauses that say a person cannot get Austudy if he is a New Zealander or an expatriate and his children are living here, unless he has some permanency or residential qualifications. If those qualifications were required, I believe that would solve the problem.

There are some anomalies and there is a need for review. Having pursued the matter of New Zealanders obtaining Austudy, the main aspect I raise concerns people who live in isolated areas and do not have the same capacity to purchase as their counterparts in capital cities. It is time we gave cognisance to that problem. I appreciate what the Government has done. I applaud the measures it has introduced, and I applaud its efforts in putting legislation in place to enable the recovery of moneys illegally obtained. I back the Government totally in the gradual changes it has brought about to ensure that more and more Australians are given assistance and the incentive to pursue their education. However, as the reviews continue I ask that the points I have raised be taken into consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of points made by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) require a response. The first is that early in his speech he suggested that middle and low income people are quite happy to see their children receive unemployment benefits. I believe that one of the scourges of this nation has been the continuing level of unemployment. The last thing that parents want is to see their children sitting around at home, living on the dole. The honourable member for Capricornia was absolutely correct in his reference to New Zealanders coming to this country and not being subject to the income tests that apply to Australians making application for similar assistance. I do not know whether there need necessarily be a residential qualification, but I cannot see why the Australian Government cannot demand of New Zealand that it verify the incomes of parents in exactly the same way that New Zealand co-operates with our Government by monitoring the recipients of various pensions taken from Australia to New Zealand.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Capricornia and I come from the same State. In an article in the Sunday Mail last weekend I highlighted the fact that 25,000 people, living in more than 40 countries throughout the world, receive various pensions from the Australian Government. An amount of $120m is involved. Those people are not subject to the same checks as are Australians who receive similar pensions. So I say to the honourable member that there are a couple of areas in which I believe that our beautiful Australia and the Australian people are being ripped off by those who seek to take advantage of our loose systems.

One unfortunate comment of the honourable member for Capricornia was his advocating the application of an assets test on eligibility for Austudy. I notice that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) is bubbling over in his reaction to the honourable member for Capricornia. I understand what the honourable member for Capricornia was saying. He was saying that if someone has hundreds of thousands of dollars of assets, it is perhaps unfair to make a benefit or grant available to that person. On the other hand, let me say to the honourable member that someone could have a business worth hundreds of thousands of dollars, but because of the economics of these times his family income might well be in the qualifying range. That might not be due solely to his clever accountant; it might result from a genuine downturn in his business. The reality might well be that that family would wish for nothing more than to be independent, for their business to be successful, and for their income to be relative to the money they have invested. I ask the honourable member for Capricornia to take that on board.

The other aspect is that certain professions have a very high income level. I have heard the same stories as has the honourable member for Capricornia, and I do not want to select particular professions. However, some people have arranged their affairs so that their income levels are below the cut off level of approximately $25,000. I suggest to the honourable member that if the Government reduced the upper levels of taxation so that they were more in keeping with the New Zealand levels, a diminishing number of people would so arrange their financial affairs that ostensibly they are losing money, and therefore have a lower income level.

I understand that there may be a poor boy in a street whose parents have hardly two cents to rub together. They might live in a very ordinary, unpainted home that has wood rot, yet up the road there may be a family that has a huge, beautiful brick home, two Mercedes Benz cars, and a boat in the yard, living a different lifestyle. That would prompt people to say, `What is going on? If there is a means test applied, that family must be jiggling their income'. I believe much of the income rearranging in this country has been born out of our high taxation levels. When we manage to reduce those levels further we will find that people will be prepared to preserve their actual income rather than write it off in an income loss situation.

This Bill, the Student Assistance Legislation Amendment Bill, is designed to allow the Department of Employment, Education and Training in future to recover overpayments, fraud and the like. My first comment on that relates to the explanatory notes to the Bill, which include a financial impact statement. That statement reads:
The measures in the Bill are expected to result in significant savings.
That is fair enough. It continues:
It is not possible, however, to quantify the savings until compliance surveys have been undertaken to investigate further the extent of fraud under Austudy.

How can one say, on the one hand, that the savings will be significant, and then on the other hand that it is not known upon what basis that statement is made? That statement has come from the Department of Employment, Education and Training; I hope that an explanatory statement such as that was not prepared by Treasury. It is almost gobbledegook. We will be flying in the dark if we legislate that particular measure.

It is proper to bear in mind also, when we refer to that statement, that in 1979 the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, in its 176th Report, on the report of the Auditor-General for the financial year 1977-78, presented a parliamentary paper on this very subject of pursuing overpayments by the Department and the prevalence of fraud at that time. The Committee's figures suggested that between 1976 and 1979 the number of cases a year involving unrecovered overpayments were, respectively, 6,000, 9,000, 8,000 and 8,000, and the total overpayments were, respectively, $1.2m, $2.4m, $2.6m and $3m. It is very hard to obtain any up-to-date information from the Government on what is happening with regard to fraud. I guess that comment of mine is supported by the financial statement that I read from the explanatory notes a moment ago.

It is interesting to see that the work done in 1978 by the Public Accounts Committee broke down the causes of overpayments in the field of education. The reason for the highest number of overpayments was that a person discontinued a course and the Department was not notified. That accounted for 60 per cent of all overpayments in that year. Other reasons given were: students failed to commence a proposed course; reduced study load to part time status; accepted another award; entered a bonded arrangement with a future employer; parental income found to exceed income declared on application form; student's income exceeds permissible limit; death of student but payments continued; and brother or sister ceased study, thereby terminating means test concession.

But the second biggest reason for overpayments at the time the last study was made was none other than departmental errors. Departmental errors were responsible for the second largest number of overpayments in the late 1970s; as far as I know there are no figures available which show what is going on now. But the Department was the cause of 7.1 per cent of all errors. At that time the Department was having great difficulty liaising with the tertiary institutions. The tertiary institutions were not very helpful in giving details of who was studying what. As a result of that inquiry by the Public Accounts Committee, the Department made a deliberate effort to improve its liaison with the tertiary institutions. As a result of that, I guess, there has been great improvement in the notification of students who have given up their studies.

I noticed also that the recommendation of that Committee at the time urged the Department of Finance to hasten the introduction of guidelines to formalise the then current practice of the Department of Education not recovering overpayments resulting from departmental error. I have checked that out and, apparently, through the Audit Act, attention was given to that.

What concerns me about this legislation-the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), who is at the table, may seek to explain this at some later stage-is that it appears that the Government is taking unto itself the right to delve back as far as six years for the recovery of overpayments. If I am correct in thinking that the Government is taking this right unto itself, that seems to me to involve retrospectivity.

In talking about departmental inefficiency, I give the House the case of a constituent of mine who in 1986 was living in Japan and wrote to the Department and said, `I want to come home to study at university in Brisbane'. He explained all of his details and the Department said, `You will be eligible'. So what did my constituent do? He came home from Japan and enrolled at Griffith University. Last year he flew through with considerable merit, even obtaining high distinctions. But the departmental error component arose in his case. At the end of last year, or the beginning of this year, the Department told him, `We are sorry, but you are no longer eligible for Austudy'. This man is an Australian by birth and had been gainfully employed in Japan for only four or five years but wanted to come back to Australia. He built his life on the departmental advice. He had hardly any money because, although he earned money in Japan, the cost of living was high. But he thought he could survive because he would receive Austudy. But then, after one year at university, they told him, `It is not on'. He asked why and was told by the Department, `Oh, we misunderstood and, because of your having attended a course at the Queensland Institute of Technology in the 1970s, less than 10 years ago, you are caught by the 10-year rule and you can no longer continue to receive Austudy. We have made a mistake'.

I ask the Minister now at the table, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones)-the Ministers at the table keep changing in the same way as the Ministers on the front bench; I was talking to the Minister for Administrative Services a moment ago-whether he thinks it is fair to do this sort of thing to a person who has planned his life around Austudy. This person was as honest as the day is long about everything he had ever done in his life--

TALK.START.PARA: —Does he vote for you?

—I do not know how he votes. I do not say to people, `I will help you only if you vote Liberal'. I stand up for fairness and justice. This man has been subjected to unfairness and injustice and that is why I am speaking on his behalf. The Department has blundered and now this man is suddenly deprived of income. What I fear from this legislation is that the Government will now take unto itself the right to say, `You have to pay back all that we did not mean to give you last year'. The Department has said to him that he will be able to get Austudy again in the year 1990 if he does a higher degree after his bachelors degree.

SPEECH.PARA: This person thought he had problems when he rang me to say that he was no longer eligible for Austudy. I said to him, `But, wait a minute. The Government is putting through legislation which will strengthen its hand to retrieve overpayments. Your major problem could be that you will have to pay back your high living last year on Austudy'. That is an example of just one error made by the Department.

I say this more in sorrow than in anger: there is a lot of misinformation given out by public servants in the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training about Austudy. I can well understand the confusion that exists in the community about various government programs. But I believe-I know there are departmental representatives in the chamber-that there has to be a determined effort to educate better not just the population but departmental officers about the services that their departments dispense. The ramifications of misinformation can be as disastrous as those on my constituent. This man is now betwixt and between. He is at university but suddenly deprived of all means of income unless he goes out and mows lawns, scrubs cars and the like. That is what he will have to do as a result of misinformation. I raise that aspect of the administration of Austudy because of its serious implications.

I also seek to take the opportunity during this debate to refer to a recent Government announcement concerning a $120,000 grant given to Macquarie University to conduct a nationwide study to determine the key factors contributing to increased retention rates in secondary schools. An amount of about $50,000 was handed out a couple of years ago to Monash University to do a similar exercise relating to tertiary students. It was established that there were so many imponderables that it was difficult to determine why people dropped a subject, left and went to another institution or simply gave away higher education. I suggest that it was coincidental that, even though that study was done in 1986, an article appeared in the Australian in January 1988 referring to that study and then, some two weeks later, the Government announced that it would hand out $120,000 for this latest study to be done. I suggest that the Government has been overgenerous in the amount of money it has given. Perhaps a pilot study would have established that that which pertains to the tertiary level is not much different from the secondary level.

Earlier, the honourable member for Capricornia referred to the high retention rate in the number of young people going on to grades 11 and 12 in my State. The Government beats its chest about improving the retention rate nationally from about 30 per cent to 50 per cent. I suggest to the Minister at the table that the reason so many people are staying on to do grades 11 and 12 is that they cannot get work. Many people who continue at school with the assistance of Austudy would be happy to be in the work force if job opportunities were available. This creates problems in the classroom, firstly because students are there not because they really want to be at school but because they have no where else to go, and, secondly, the Government's approach is to promise Utopia saying, `If you stay on to grade 12 you can go out and get a job'. That is not so. The grade 13s-I use that term to describe the people who more recently left school-have about 20 per cent of their ranks unemployed. I ask the Government not to tout Austudy as a panacea.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has elapsed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to a number of speakers on the Student Assistance Legislation Amendment Bill and found some of the propositions put forward by members of the Opposition to be carping and others to be quite bizarre. One of the more interesting propositions was put forward by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), who suggested that it would be reasonable to compare a study on the retention rates of students at universities with a study on the retention rates of students in high schools. I do not know how much thought the honourable member gave to that issue, but I would have thought that even the most cursory consideration of the attitudes and positions of people in high schools, vis-a-vis people in tertiary institutions, would show that the reasons for people dropping out of tertiary institutions are markedly different from the reasons for people not continuing to years 11 and 12. It would be very valuable for the Government, and for the Australian people as a whole, to come to some understanding as to why young people do not continue to years 11 and 12.

SPEECH.PARA: If we accept the dangerous proposition put forward by the honourable member for Moreton that somehow or other encouraging people to go on to year 12 does not help them, it will put Australia in a very bad position.
