One of the reasons that Australia is finding that we are not in a good position to compete in the world at present is the attitude of previous conservative governments in Australia which did not put sufficient assets into training and education. It is ridiculous that in Australia in 1988 we are trying to tell young people that it is a good idea to stay on to do years 11 and 12, and that they should apply themselves to do that and if we do not encourage them to do that, Australia can look to being a second rate nation in this part of the world. The thing we should be able to sell in this part of the world is the fact that we have a very good, broad-based education system. But in recent years we have seen the less developed countries in the region overtaking Australia. We have been too complacent, we have been too lazy and governments have shown too little leadership in the education debate. We seem to pick up on whatever the flavour of the month is, run with it for a little while and then switch to something else.

The discussion on this Bill has been fairly wide ranging but we have heard mostly carping discussion from the Opposition. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) and the honourable member for Moreton told us about small problems they have come across with the student assistance programs that the Commonwealth Government runs. The new form of student assistance, that this Government has implemented, is one of the great landmark changes in education funding in Australia. Rather than recognise that, all we heard from Opposition speakers was carping criticism which, unfortunately, is becoming typical of what we hear from the Opposition today. The Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Mackellar, moved an amendment to the second reading motion that states:

. . . whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its disgraceful mismanagement of the Austudy scheme, causing distress and financial embarrassment to thousands of students and their families who have had to wait for lengthy periods before receiving their entitlements.

The Opposition should recognise that the Austudy system provides a great opportunity for young people who otherwise may not have been able to complete their education to do so. The Opposition has not given credit where credit is due. Instead of the Opposition saying, `Let's see whether we can go down the path of better education together', all we hear is carping criticism.

I want to say a few things that are quite positive about education, in particular the gains for people in my electorate from the Austudy arrangements and the gains and the goals that the Government sees in its education policy. Before I do that, I will look at the Government's strategy. The Government's target is to achieve a retention rate of 65 per cent of students completing year 12 by the early 1990s. That in itself is an indictment of the way in which the previous Liberal-National coalition Government let education run down in Australia. If the Government's target can now be only 65 per cent that is something of which we should be ashamed, not because of the work that this Government has done in the education field but because of the lack of work done by the previous Government.

The previous Government had a tertiary education assistance scheme which allowed very restricted access to higher education by people from low income families and which subsidised those who were well off. This Government has turned that system around and has put in place a form of assistance for young people which will help people from low income families to make the decision about whether the young boys and girls in the family will continue to years 11 and 12. Families will not have to make that decision entirely on financial grounds, which they often had to do before; they will be able to make the decision on the grounds of the academic merit they feel their young people have.

It is interesting for the House to note the type of assistance that the Government is giving to low income families to help them make that decision on the basis of academic merit and not on the basis of whether the family needs a 16-year-old student to go out and work to help supplement the family income. Take, for example, a family on weekly earnings of $300 and with three children at various stages of their education. Such a family would be eligible for almost $175 a week in Commonwealth Government assistance.

That amount would be made up of $91.20 Austudy for the eldest child, who would be 18 years old and living away from home to attend a tertiary institution; $50 a week Austudy for the middle child, who would be 16 years of age and at school; and a $28 family allowance supplement plus a $5.25 family allowance for the youngest child, who would be 14 years of age and at school. That family would get $15 a week rent support if it were living in private rental accommodation. Of course, the family would get a further increase in Austudy payments when the youngest child turned 16 years of age.

What this Government is doing to help low income families to send their children to school is nothing short of phenomenal. We will provide up to 58 per cent of a family's income-$175 for a family with an income of $300 a week. That is the most generous package that has ever been put together by a government in the history of this country. But what do we hear from the Opposition about that generous, fair and equitable package? We hear carping criticism. We hear the honourable member for Moreton tell us that it is a scandal that we have spent $100,000 on trying to find the reasons why young people are not attending years 11 and 12. We hear him then make the rather foolish statement that we ought to look at an old survey that was done on why young people drop out of universities. He argues that somehow or other that is going to tell us why students do not go on to years 11 and 12.

I suppose that, if we delved into this matter a bit more, we might even find that the honourable member for Moreton is the chairman of the Opposition's education committee, because the types of policies that it is coming out with are indicative of the types of policies that he brings before the House. To my mind, the type of criticism that the Opposition is making of the Government's very generous and equitable programs to help low income families have a chance in life is scandalous.

Over the years, honourable members opposite presided over a system of educational assistance which put hundreds of millions of dollars into tertiary institutions-schools and universities-that were attended by the children of the rich but by only a few children from the western suburbs of Sydney. The people from the western suburbs, through their taxes, paid for the institutions that the children of the rich went to. In the last few years we have turned that around a bit.

I must say that I view the criticisms that were made by the honourable member for Mackellar more with sorrow than with anger. If anyone ought to understand the situation of people from low and middle income families, who went to schools where class sizes were too large and the kids did not get a fair go, it is a person with his background. Rather than criticise this legislation, he should be in a position to get his Party to bring in policies to redress this situation. When the honourable member for Mackellar completed his Leaving Certificate, only four or five of his fellow students went on, as he did, to university. But now most students at the school he attended who get to years 9 and 10 continue on to years 11 and 12. The children who now go to the school he went to have a far better chance of getting an education than was the case when the Government of which he was a member was in business.

In fact, we see sitting on the front bench of the Opposition the real problem with the Opposition's education policies. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) represents all of the positions of privilege that the Liberal Party of Australia wants to support. The honourable member, who went to all of the best schools and all of the best universities, is typical of the sorts of people who would profit from that Party's types of education policies. If the Liberal Party were fair dinkum, it would come up with education policies that would do something for the people with whom the honourable member for Mackellar grew up. Unfortunately, the honourable member for Mackellar has sold out. He is interested in seeing that we have education policies in Australia that support people such as the honourable member for North Sydney. I think that sort of elitism is a scandal.

One of the great things that this Government has done has been to provide very substantial financial benefits to low income families to enable them to make decisions about letting their children continue on at high school and sending them to university on the basis of merit alone. When I look around the schools in my electorate I see far better facilities now than there were five years ago; I see far more young people continuing on to years 11 and 12; and I see far more of those young people going on to university. The people of my electorate are at last, under the policies of this Government, getting a better chance to share in the opportunities available to give their children a better education than they had under the dead hand of the previous Liberal-National Party governments.

In conclusion, I want to make two other points. I support what the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) said in this debate. I think there is a fair amount of merit in introducing some sort of assets test as well as some sort of income test on tertiary allowances. There is no doubt that people in my electorate, as in the honourable member's electorate, find it a bit strange that the children of some families which are very asset rich, but maybe cash strapped at present, can get tertiary allowances, while their children might fall just outside of qualifying for Austudy payments. Although the husband and wife might be working, they might have a small home and be paying off a big mortgage.

I think a good argument can be mounted that the only fair and equitable situation is one that is both assets tested and income tested. As the honourable member for Capricornia said, it is recognised that this is a better way to test eligibility for social security payments. It might be better, in the early course of events, to add assets testing to the Austudy system. I can understand the attitude of some people, whose family income might be a little high because both are working, when they see the children of some other family which has very substantial assets receiving Austudy assistance.

I congratulate the previous Minister for Education, former Senator Ryan, who persisted with the Austudy scheme which has resulted in a very substantial increase in the participation of people from lower income families in the education system of Australia. I particularly pay a compliment to the present Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), who has persisted in ensuring that Austudy is paid to young people in years 11 and 12. This has meant that a whole lot more of the young people in my electorate have continued with their education. At last, they are getting a fair chance to participate in tertiary education. He has ensured that the Government's policy of access and equity has become a reality and that the people from the western suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne-the battlers of Australia-have a chance of their children getting a better education than they did.

The House should reject the carping criticism of the Opposition. The House should reject the rather spurious arguments put forward by the honourable member for Moreton. The Opposition ought to ask the honourable member for Mackellar to remember what life was like when he was a boy, and the honourable member for Mackellar ought to do his best to get the Opposition to adopt policies such as this Government has, which will see a family on $300 a week get $175 per week in assistance to help them with the education of their children. I commend the legislation to the House, and I commend the Government on the very progressive approach it has taken to a redistribution of educational assets in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I crave your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker. I seek to clarify a matter.
—So long as the honourable member is seeking to clarify a matter, not to introduce new material to the debate, he may proceed.

—The honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) has, either deliberately or accidentally, misrepresented some of my comments in relation to the grant which was given to Monash University and recently made available to Macquarie University for an inquiry into the secondary sector. I suggested that a pilot scheme would have been better to see whether the problems that existed in relation to the tertiary inquiry were present, instead of going in straight off with $120,000 of expenditure. Secondly, the honourable member referred to my raising small matters. In relation to the constituent whose problems I raised, they are a disaster in his life and I make no apology to anyone for raising people's issues in the people's place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government welcomes the fact that the Opposition chose to turn this debate into a wide-ranging debate. The more we have the opportunity to demonstrate to the public the validity of the education policies that are being pursued by this Government the better it will be for this Government and our standing in the community. There is no doubt that the exercise that has been undertaken by this Government in reviewing educational policies and educational funding policies leaves us in very good standing when one compares it with the record of the Liberal Party of Australia when in government during the wasted Fraser years. I should like to review just a little of that, since the Opposition chose to deal with a number of matters during the debate, before I deal specifically with some of the matters that were raised, particularly by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), to which I should like to respond in some detail in a few moments.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1983 the Hawke Government has conducted a major review of youth programs and policies and, of course, has initiated a wide-ranging set of reforms, particularly in relation to income support arrangements for young people in the education sector. Following decisions taken in the 1985 Budget, the new age-related student assistance scheme, Austudy, was implemented in 1987, replacing the three previously existing schemes. Then in 1988 a further step was taken in rationalising allowances, with the maximum education allowance payable under Austudy to 16- and 17-year-olds being aligned with the maximum allowance payable to this age group under the new job search allowance.

Many people will know that for years and years the complaint had been made that the payments under the unemployment benefit were higher than the payments made to people remaining in education, and thus a real financial incentive was provided to people of that age group to leave school to go onto the unemployment benefit. This Government has bitten the bullet and addressed that issue, and now the rates applicable for young people, whether they are in school or on the job search allowance, are essentially the same. The young homeless allowance was introduced in July 1986, and from January 1987 it has been incorporated into Austudy. The Government has also maintained assistance through separate schemes to geographically isolated school children, to migrants undertaking advanced English language courses, and to the ablest of postgraduate students pursuing higher education.

There has been a very significant increase in the number of students assisted since 1983-the dying days of the Fraser Government. That assistance has been very well targeted. These figures will be of considerable interest to honourable members on both sides of the House. The number of people being assisted as at 30 June 1983 was 132,208, and at 30 June 1987 it was 184,022. That is a 40 per cent increase in the number of individuals who are being assisted under Austudy, a very dramatic increase and a very important policy initiative by this Government to ensure that far more younger people stay at school and are not encouraged to leave the education sector simply because of financial disadvantage.

Expenditure on these schemes has also increased dramatically: from $378m, in 1988 prices, for the 1982-83 year, to $678m in 1987-88. That is a 74 per cent increase in real dollars. That is a clear demonstration of the fact that this Government is targeting dollars where they are needed. Over this period the apparent retention rate to the final year of schooling, Year 12, has increased from 40.6 per cent in 1983-the last year of the Fraser Government-to 53.1 per cent, while the apparent retention rate to Year 11 has increased from 63.6 per cent to 71 per cent. So, again, the Government is well on target to increase dramatically the retention rate in our school system.

Overall government policy is for significant increases in educational qualifications in the population at large, and student assistance has a major role to play in increasing participation in education and in enabling disadvantaged groups to participate to a greater extent. Austudy has greatly increased the benefits available to students, particularly at the secondary school level, and has resulted in a much larger number of students being assisted.

The honourable member for Mackellar raised a number of matters in relation to which he sought to attack the policy and administration of Austudy. It is pretty cheeky of the Opposition, which did nothing for the education sector during those wasted Fraser years, to come into this Parliament and proceed in a mealy-mouthed fashion to attack this Government over our excellent record. Sure, there were some administrative teething problems as Austudy was introduced. There is no doubt that this Government has now introduced an excellent scheme which is well recognised in the community as being the sort of scheme that should have been introduced a generation ago. There is no suggestion from the Opposition that we hear in this place or elsewhere that it would dismantle Austudy. It clearly obviously supports the general thrust of the Government's policy. So what is left to the Opposition but a little bit of nitpicking. Let me deal with some of the nits.

The honourable member for Mackellar said that the treatment of income from scholarships at non-government schools was inadequate. I would concede that it was originally. It is true that the rules as applied initially had the effect of taking tuition scholarships into account in the student income test. This was an unintended consequence of the rationalising of benefits and conditions for secondary and tertiary students. The important point is that, when the full implications of the Student Assistance Legislation Amendment Bill became apparent, the Government changed the conditions to exclude such scholarships from the income test, thus ensuring that students were not disadvantaged.

The honourable member for Mackellar then said that the decision to give parents the option of receiving the tertiary allowance in lieu of the student was wrong, and made a couple of points about that. In deciding who should receive the allowance, the parent or the student, the Government had to balance the conflicting considerations. The Government recognised the rights of parents and the important role of the family in decision-making about the education of children. On the other hand, there were educational arguments for paying students directly, as an incentive to stay on at school, bearing in mind that if they left school and became unemployed, they would receive the unemployment benefit in their own hands.

In the 1986 Budget, the Government announced that the allowance would be paid to the students. However, following representations from school and parent bodies, the Government decided that parents of students under 18 years of age could have the option of receiving the allowance. At the same time, it arranged that this would not have taxation disadvantages for the families. The point of the honourable member for Mackellar that parents are not sufficiently aware that they can apply for the benefit has absolutely no basis in fact. Every application from a student under 18 years must contain a signed statement from the parent as to who should receive the allowance. To say that parents are not aware of their rights in this matter is an absolute fabrication and is completely incorrect.

The honourable member for Mackellar also raised the issue of living away from home allowances, which he says should be used to give more help to isolated students who have to live away to study. The present rules for receiving a living away from home allowance have operated since 1974. Honourable members will recall that from 1975 to 1983 the Fraser Government was in power. So the honourable member's Party chose not to change the rules during the whole of that period. Those rules have been endorsed by successive governments. There are strict rules for receiving an away from home allowance. The student must live too far from the institution to travel back and forth each day or, because of the diversity of courses, different entry requirements, quotas and the like, students are not always free to choose a course at the institution closest to their homes. In those circumstances, living away from home allowances are paid. The rules have existed since 1974 and have been endorsed by successive governments.

The honourable member for Mackellar then said that Austudy should not be restricted to courses funded by the public sector. His logic for this, which I found quite extraordinary, seemed to be that the Government would save money if Austudy were paid to people studying in certain private institutions. This Government's policy, again I might say endorsed by successive governments, does not restrict benefits to students in courses at government-funded institutions. The policy has been amended to some extent to cover students in institutions that are funded by State or Territory governments as well as those that are Commonwealth funded. The present restrictions are necessary to contain costs. If Austudy were available for the very wide variety and range of privately-funded institutions, the costs to the taxpayer would increase quite significantly. They would not be reduced.

The honourable member for Mackellar made some comments about payments to pensioner students. I would like to make it clear to the House that the Government's position on pensioner students is that, prior to 1987, people receiving pensions such as the supporting parents' benefits were able in many cases to receive almost the full amount of the pension and the tertiary allowance including, where applicable, child allowance from both sources. This was an obvious duplication, since both entitlements were designed for much the same purpose. The Government has decided that under Austudy such pensioners would be entitled to an education supplement of $15 per week. There were concessions to ensure that those pensioners who had already started their courses would have their benefits maintained until they finished those courses. Because of the wide range of course arrangements there have been cases where the equitable application of these transitional arrangements have proved difficult. There were situations such as the one cited by the honourable member for Mackellar where the decision was not in the student's favour. The Government's overriding concerns have been to apply the rules strictly in the interests of equity. These examples do not present a picture of policy being hastily conceived. Overall, the rules are coherent and have been applied consistently and fairly.

The honourable member for Mackellar cited examples of payment delays experienced last year by students. This amendment which has been moved is amusing in the extreme, to some extent, in that it is completely historical in its ambit. It refers to the situation that applied over 12 months ago. It does not apply to the current situation. Those delays during 1987 arose because it was necessary to introduce new processing systems at the same time as the new system was being implemented. The old computer systems could not have coped with the big increase in numbers of beneficiaries and the changes in the rules. The new system became operative in stages with some aspects, such as payments to pensioners, being made manually for a time. Initial delays led to large numbers of inquiries which, of course, diverted resources from assessing the applications that had been made.

During 1987 there was a thorough review of implementation problems. Various systems problems were systematically rectified. The result is that for 1988 there are no processing delays. The system is functioning smoothly. The Department has set a standard of service finalising the vast majority of applications within three weeks of receipt. This is being achieved. Despite an increase in the number of applications, 85 per cent of applications received have been processed, compared with 28 per cent at the same time last year. The strategy for handling inquiries also has been improved and new equipment used to facilitate the processing of telephone inquiries. All in all, the teething problems with the administration of Austudy have been overcome. Therefore, the amendment the honourable member has chosen to move in this place has been rendered quite redundant.

The only other comments I want to make are in relation to a couple of matters that the honourable member for Mackellar raised which relate specifically to this Bill. He said that there was a need to ensure that the penalty provisions against corporations included the full range of Commonwealth and State instrumentalities. I can tell the honourable gentleman that this matter has been raised with the Parliamentary Counsel who has advised that proposed new sections 31h and 31j apply to public corporations. The honourable member's concerns on that matter-I appreciate that they were legitimate concerns-have been met.

The other matter that I took note of that the honourable member raised was that there was need for careful consideration of the costs of implementing the anti-fraud measures in relation to the funds available to assist students. We, as a government, are very concerned about the need to ensure that the measures to be undertaken are cost-effective. Additional staffing costs for anti-fraud activities for Austudy will be $0.4m in 1987-88, rising to $1.79m in 1989-90. Whilst these amounts are quite large, they need to be seen in terms of the overall expenditure on Austudy which will be in the order of $620m in 1988, rising quite rapidly possibly in the ensuing couple of years. However, staffing level costs will be carefully reviewed early next year and resources curtailed if it becomes apparent that this level of expenditure on fraud control is not justified. It is intended to undertake a sample survey of applications and some additional checking during 1988 to try to arrive at some estimate of the possible level of real fraud against the scheme.

All in all, this legislation is important. It will ensure the integrity of the Government's Austudy scheme, a scheme for the assistance of students in secondary and tertiary institutions. It is part of the Government's continuing concern to make sure that where it is spending public funds it is spending those funds efficiently and properly. I commend the Bill to the House and indicate that the Government will not be agreeing to the amendment.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Carlton's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Duncan) read a third time.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Precincts Bill sets forth for the first time in the history of the Australian Commonwealth a legal definition of the parliamentary precincts. In so doing, the Bill seeks to incorporate into law the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, namely, that the area of the parliamentary precincts for the new Parliament House be defined by legislation. In making this recommendation the Committee was addressing the concerns of the 1969 report of the Joint Select Committee of the New and Permanent Parliament House, that down through the years the Parliament had been embarrassed by lack of clarity over the issues addressed by this legislation, especially lack of certainty about the extent of parliamentary control over the land surrounding the parliamentary buildings; lack of certainty about matters of traffic control, parking facilities, police activity, control of demonstrations, public access to the buildings, roadway design, and so on; and lack of certainty over the exact area appropriated for Parliament's use, and the formal title to it.

SPEECH.PARA: These sentiments were again echoed by the Senate Committee of Privileges, which in May 1978 called for legislation to define the boundaries of the Parliament, and again in October 1984, when the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege recommended:
The precincts of the present parliamentary House and of the new parliamentary House be defined authoritatively.

Committee after committee have raised concerns over the precise definition and identification of the parliamentary precincts because of the way in which in 1927 the Governor-General vested in the Federal Capital Commission all the Commonwealth land in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) except the land shown in a schedule attached to the notice. The schedule set out the site for the permanent Parliament House, an area on Camp Hill reserved for the temporary Parliament, and areas for parliamentary gardens on each side of the House, to be delineated with a hedge. But these areas were at no time passed over to the Parliament for its control. There was no instrument setting out the precise area over which the Parliament has exclusive jurisdiction or the conditions under which that jurisdiction is to be exercised. For example, uncertainty has been expressed as to whether the steps and verandahs of the present Parliament House are included in the precincts.

In addition to the concern about the boundary, concerns have also been expressed about the enforcement of parliament's power. Three major defects have been raised. Firstly, although the Houses have the undoubted power to take a person into custody and to commit a person to prison, and consequently to expel a person from the precincts, there is no clear legal obligation upon the police to carry out the orders of the Presiding Officers. Secondly, although persons may be prosecuted for criminal offences committed in the precincts, the Crown has the usual discretion as to prosecution of such offences and is under no clear obligation to prosecute offences at the direction of the Presiding Officers. Thirdly, although there is no doubt that the ordinary law applies in the precincts according to its tenor, there appears to be some doubt, whether well founded or not, about particular criminal offences in their application to Parliament House.

This situation reminds me of our Treasurer (Mr Keating) who, whilst being responsible for the administration of the tax law, did not comply with the law by failing to lodge his own return. Similarly, while parliament has been passing laws defining the ordinary citizen's rights, it has failed to define its own rights and its own land holdings. This Bill therefore belatedly, on the eve of the opening of the new-and, we hope, given the cost, permanent-Parliament House, is intended to remedy this situation. The Bill spells out in precise detail the physical definition of the parliamentary precincts. It confers management and control over these precincts by the Presiding Officers of Parliament-the Speaker of the House and the President of the Senate. The Bill provides that the laws of the Australian Capital Territory shall prevail within these precincts. The Bill enumerates the exceptions to the laws which apply within the precincts, and it provides for agreements between the Presiding Officers and the Ministers responsible for the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Protective Services and the Director of Public Prosecutions for law enforcement within the precincts. I will come back to some of these points in a moment.

The Bill also places limitations on the authority of the officers of parliament in the exercise of their control and management to the extent that they are properly subject to any order of either House. The Bill further provides that the exercise of control and management of the precincts with respect to the ministerial wing shall be subject to agreement between the officers and the responsible Minister. Given that the ministerial wing of the new Parliament, unlike that in this Parliament House, is in many respects capable of being a separate entity with its own separate entrances and a separate access roadway, one can therefore understand the desire to provide for separate arrangements to be made for the executive operation of government. I hasten to add the officers of Parliament should be mindful not to allow themselves to be browbeaten to concede special powers to the executive wing which are contrary to the best interests of the Parliament as a whole.

This particular provision is the most contentious in the legislation and we will be watching closely the agreements made to make sure the powers of the Parliament remain supreme. The concept of the precincts and the principles under which it operates would certainly be weakened if agreements between the officers and the responsible Minister regarding the executive wing in any way compromised the interest of the Parliament as a whole.

The definition of the parliamentary precincts includes the entire area within a boundary formed by a circular line drawn from the edge of the retaining wall right around the site, generally the area within Capital Circle.

I said before that the Bill enumerates exceptions to the laws of the Australian Capital Territory for purposes of control and management of the precincts and the enforcement of these laws. Exceptions to the laws of the ACT include those governing leases and licences. For example, the sale of liquor within the precincts is already specifically exempted from the ACT Liquor Ordinance of 1975. The granting and management of other licences and leases within the new Parliament House will be governed not only by parliamentary practice which has developed over the years but specifically by this legislation.

Another exception from the laws of the ACT which applies to the parliamentary precincts concerns application of the Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act 1971 within the precincts. Section 12 of this Act sets forth special penalties. A person who trespasses on, obstructs passage to or from, behaves in a disorderly fashion while in, or refuses upon authorised direction to leave Commonwealth premises is guilty of an offence punishable on conviction by a fine or imprisonment. Inclusion, by reference, of this section of the law ensures that order may be maintained within the parliamentary precincts. Clause 14 of the Bill modifies the boundaries of the parliamentary zone which was established by the Parliament Act 1974. The modifications extend the zone from Capital Circle to the inner kerb of State Circle, thereby encompassing the new Parliament House, and it specifically limits the zone to the inner boundaries of Commonwealth and Kings Avenues. The earlier zone included these avenues.

The rules governing the zone state that no building or other work is to be erected on land within the zone unless the building or work is approved by both Houses of Parliament. In my view it is appropriate that building within the zone be controlled by the Parliament so that no works are carried out which may detract from or not be in harmony with the new Parliament House. I might mention in passing that I await with some trepidation the completion of the new National Science Centre in front of the existing Parliament House by the lake. At the moment the top of that building looks like a gasworks more suited to an industrial site than the Parliamentary Triangle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I hear my colleague agreeing. Maybe on completion the total effect will be an improvement but I must say at present I am not convinced it is an appropriate addition to the parliamentary zone. But the purpose of establishing a parliamentary zone goes beyond the control of construction of buildings within that zone. The House of Representatives Practice states:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Parliament is confronted with the situation where its functioning is hindered by events outside the area normally considered to be its precincts, it may be able to take action under its privilege power. The House has the right to the attendance and services of its members and if, for example, a large gathering of people in front of the building was preventing members from entering the House, the Speaker, under the privilege power of the House, could order the police to clear a passage.
Pettifer goes on to say:
The Australian Parliament does not claim authority over the streets surrounding Parliament House although it does claim the privilege of access for its members to attend Parliament.

The parliamentary zone defined in this Bill describes the area in which the Presiding Officers may exercise the power of privilege in a sensible and practical way, bearing in mind the reasonable requirements of the Parliament. This Bill on the parliamentary precincts therefore provides this House with much more than certitude about title to the physical premises of the new Parliament House and its surrounds. The Bill gives the Presiding Officers of Parliament-the Speaker of the House and the President of the Senate-the authority necessary to ensure that both Houses of Parliament may proceed with their deliberations in an orderly fashion.

There are a number of other issues relating to the new and the old Parliament which I would like to raise. I was not present during the debate on the Speaker's chair and would therefore like to say that, to me, the chair is a symbol of the Westminster tradition which has been practised in the House of Commons and since Federation in this Parliament. I think it is a great pity that the Government has not seen fit to maintain the link between the old and the new. I recognise that this Labor Government would like to distance us from our ties with the Westminster tradition which is the cornerstone of our democratic system of government. I have no doubt that its refusal to allow the chair to go with us to the new Parliament House is seen by it as a progressive step towards a republic. I do not share that view.

We are an independent nation and I would have thought that was patently clear to all. We do not need to prove it to anybody. I therefore see merit in maintaining the continuity of our parliamentary tradition. In recognition of the development of our parliamentary system the Speaker's chair would, I believe, provide a unique link to the Westminster tradition. In pursuit of progress and development we do not have to cut all our ties with the past. The chair in this place is a symbol of a great deal of commonsense and convention built up over centuries of democratic rule. I might add that I see that I am in good company. I noticed that just before the end of last year three former Clerks of the House of Representatives-Messrs Norman Parkes, John Pettifer and Douglas Blake-petitioned the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Overstepping their mark again.

—As private citizens? It is interesting that, according to the honourable member, private citizens should not be allowed to petition this House. That gives us an insight into the sort of government the Australian Labor Party would like to impose on this nation.
