DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Video Films-Australian Press Council-Minister for Community Services and Health-The Environment-Gun Controls-Hunter Valley-New South Wales-

PROCTEXT.PARA: Brisbane Airport
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just on 12 months ago, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall I wrote to you and all honourable colleagues concerning parliamentary inaction on the issue of X-rated videos. I suggested that we as a parliament had reason to believe that harm is being caused to children and young people by X- and R-rated videos because of the criminal neglect and apathy of their parents and the community. I argued that we share that guilt because we have the power to protect our children from such neglect but refuse to act. A year has now passed and we have still done nothing. The reason given has been the ongoing deliberations of a joint committee which has been about to bring down its recommendations for three years.
—About to!

—Yes, about to, as the honourable member for Berowra says. Partly in response to our indecision and the consequent expansion of mail order video services in the Australian Capital Territory which have undermined State censorship laws, the Western Australian Government has in the last month moved to tighten significantly video controls. The Western Australian Government has removed a loophole which the pedlars of filth, exploitation and violence have made much use of. It has made illegal not only the sale and hire of violent and sexually explicit videos but their possession as well.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the Western Australian Minister for the Arts, Mr Parker, videotapes which depict child pornography, which promote or incite terrorism or which offend against generally accepted standards of morality, decency and propriety will be banned. His Government has moved to eliminate these videos, he says, to ensure that children and others do not see them, either deliberately or by accident. Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend Mr Parker and the Western Australian Government and I urge the new Federal Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) to have a talk with Mr Parker when he gets the opportunity, hopefully pretty soon.

The decision by the Western Australian Government should be seen by this Parliament as an opportunity to begin our preparatory thinking about the likely issues to be raised by the Joint Select Committee on Video Material which will report, one hopes, on schedule, in April. I would like to commend our Opposition shadow Attorney-General for the excellent seven-point plan that he put out yesterday which gives good guidelines to what ought to be a bipartisan approach to this very critical situation.

I have actively supported those in the community who have been speaking out against X-rated videos and I am heartened by the Western Australian Government's action. I believe it is now time to widen the debate to the question of our censorship laws in toto. I wish to explain why. In January this year the Institute of Criminology released a study of sex, violence and sexual violence as contained in 58 of the most popular videos available for hire. The most dangerous type of media material-sexual agression-was predominantly found not in X-rated videos but in R-rated videos, legally available in all States. The number of scenes of agression in M-and PG-rated films was roughly equal to the number in R-rated videos.

The research by the Institute confirmed the doubts that many people are beginning to express about the adequacy of our censorship laws and guidelines. People are beginning to seek explanations for the increasing levels of domestic violence, sexual abuse, assault and violent crime. It is dawning on them that television film and video media material are the elements to be involved in any social policy review. People are beginning to realise just how watered down our media standards have become. There are two reasons for this weakening of standards. Firstly, the censorship laws are vague; for example, G-rated family films can include expletives, verbal references to sex and depictions of violence. The qualifying criteria to guide the censors are embodied in words such as mild, discreet, incidental and justifiable.

In the M category, which dominates so much of teenage theatre going and which includes the infamous Rambo films, violence can be depicted so long as it is not gratuitous, exploitative, relished wholly or unduly explicit. If you ask what those qualifications mean in effect, consider the Rambo or the macabre horror mutilation films which are so regularly categorised as M. In the R-rated films depiction of sexual violence is approved so long as it too is discreet, not gratuitous and not exploitative.

Incest can also be portrayed in R films. The positive portrayal of incest, for example, is therefore often approved under these conditions. The rules for television are, to be fair, tougher but if one considers the predominance in cartoons of violence as a means of conflict resolution, one realises how ineffective the guideline is which states that violence cannot be presented if it will harm or distress a child. Obviously, cartoon violence does not alarm but it does influence and it should be noted that television programs which are suitable for unsupervised children can include portrayal of nudity where the program deems it discreet and necessary.

The impact of vague guidelines is compounded by the moral desensitisation of viewers which results from the constant extension by artists and directors of the definitions of justifiable, discreet, gratuitous, and so on. But the dictionary of psychological terms shows that one can construct the following definition of desensitisation: It is a decrease in reactivity or sensitivity; a weakening of the response with repeated presentations of the stimulus. The reason so much of what was once classified X is now classified R, R now M, M now PG, PG now G, is not that we have become more enlightened. It is that we have, individually and as a community, become desensitised.

Unfortunately, it takes the shock of a gun massacre, vicious rape or domestic violence figures to make us stand back and reconsider clear norms and principles. It takes such eye-openers to help us see how incrementally we have allowed nihilistic academics or pornography pedlars to convince us that the new permissiveness is reasonable, harmless and liberating. It takes such shocks, Mr Deputy Speaker, to make us realise that when people refer to their right to freedom-that is, freedom of expression and viewing-they are referring not to the opportunity to write, sell, or read a D. H. Lawrence novel, but to the right to be titillated by rape, incest, child pornography and sexual subjugation. They really mean they want to be free to fantasise about shooting up Viet Cong villages. They really mean that they want to be able to have access to material which degrades their wives and children and they do not want any regulations which might mean they have to admit that their interest is not artistic, but debased.

They want the right to rent rape and mutilation from the newsagent, to have Daddy's Little Girl, an incest video, on the same shelf with Disney videos when the family goes to the service station. I believe that much of what is freely available on television, at theatres and in newsagents harms our children, harms women and harms society. It is time we tackled the problem of media standards which allow human life and human relations to be treated with contempt. It is time we shrugged off the fear of being labelled wowsers, of being labelled repressed or new prohibitionists, and acted to restore those standards which nurture the values which characterise a loving and just community.

At the moment we have censorship laws which allow for film material which is harmful to the community. What we need is a set of censorship guidelines and laws about which we can say with certainty, these laws enhance this community. The seriousness of this situation, Mr Deputy Speaker, cannot be overestimated. It requires immediate action, which is not optional but imperative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is against the Australian Press Council. The Press Council is one of those self-regulating bodies that tend to pat themselves on the back for a job well done. I firmly believe, from personal experience, that this Council is a sham whose function is to protect the Press from criticism. I hope that at some time this Parliament will look at means to make the print media much more answerable, much more accountable, especially the country Press operating in the rural areas. I would like to see conditions applied to the print media somewhat similar to those which are applied to the electronic media.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us examine the statement of principles put out by the Australian Press Council. It claims that it will treat the public interest as the first and dominant consideration; that readers of a newspaper are entitled to have both news and comment presented to them with complete good faith and therefore with scrupulous honesty and fairness in both statement and omission to ensure the truth and exactness of its statements. The statement of principle goes on to say:
A newspaper is justified in advocating its own views on controversial topics-
and no one disagrees with that-

provided in doing so it treats its readers fairly by not misleading or suppressing facts which are relevant to conclusions which it encourages readers to accept and not distorting or unfairly colouring news either in the text or its headline.

That extract from the statement of principles of the Australian Press Council is very important. During the last election campaign we heard a lot, especially from the Opposition, about media bias. Interestingly, one of those who were talking loudest was Senator Michael Baume. I remember that, when I stood against him as a candidate in 1983, one of the newspapers in the area we were both contesting at that time-the Macarthur electorate-refused to print my name once during the campaign. We heard very little from Senator Michael Baume, although I challenged him on it, at that time about media bias.

Any Labor candidate in a non-metropolitan electorate can tell you all about media bias. We suffer very much from media bias. During the last election two newspapers, both in my electorate-two newspapers but both with the same editor-also were very biased against me. Let me give a couple of examples of this. The newspaper editor, one Mr Peter Attwater, was very much supporting the Liberal candidate and every time a shadow Minister-and there seemed to be one there a day, not that it did the Liberal candidate much good-came into my area he would get massive coverage.

I had several Ministers in my electorate. I had the then Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, in to Jamberoo, which is a dairying area. One would have thought that that would have been of some interest. The local newspaper did not even mention it. When the present Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) launched my campaign and spoke about the difficulties in the coal industry, which also is in my electorate, again this local paper ignored it completely. When the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) visited the area his comments were distorted.

I could go on with a whole list of the distortions or omission from these newspapers and I felt it was hardly fair comment; so much so that I raised the matter with the Australian Press Council after the election. I put a complaint against the editor of the Kiama Independent and the Lake Times. Obviously, I lost; I always lose when I put a case before the Press Council. As part of its judgment it said:
The Kiama Independent is correct in stating that it is entitled in its editorial columns to support one candidate over another in an election.
Then it says:
It is, of course, incumbent upon the Kiama Independent and any other newspaper to be ethical and accurate in its coverage of an election.

If it was ethical, I am afraid I do not know the meaning of that word because I felt that it was most unethical; I felt that the editor of that newspaper, Mr Peter Attwater, frankly was a disgrace to the noble profession of journalism. The judgment goes on to say:
No evidence has been put before the Council which would suggest that the Kiama Independent in any way failed to maintain this standard.

Not only did it fail to maintain the correct standard during the campaign but at the time of the declaration of the poll it again distorted completely the speech I made and, by a strange coincidence, several key words had been misunderstood and it gave a completely different interpretation of my speech.

So much for the high ethical standards and so much for the self-congratulatory role that the Australian Press Council has. As I said before, I think it is a sham; it should be done away with; it serves no useful purpose; the only purpose it serves is to protect journalists or newspapers from criticism. I must say that newspapers never hesitate to criticise us in this place. Let anyone criticise journalists or the newspapers and see how they scream about it.

Having said that, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would now like to turn to a topic that is dear to some of our hearts. That is a certain event that is to take place in New South Wales on 19 March when the Unsworth Labor Government is going to be returned to office. Interestingly, the headline of the Sydney Morning Herald today is: `The case of the poll pledge that could die on March 19'. It refers to a statement from Mr Pickering who, as I understand it, is the shadow Minister for Police but would be much better known to many members of the House and many people in New South Wales as Taxi Ted, because it was Taxi Ted who ran up a massive account of about $20,000 of taxpayers' money for his jaunts in a taxi.

Anyway, Taxi Ted is now saying that the pledge he has given is: `This is just for the election. When I am Police Minister, they won't know what'll hit them'. I would like to suggest to the House that if the New South Wales people, for some reason, decide to elect the current Opposition as the new government in New South Wales they really will not know what hit them. Taxi Ted is right, they will not know what hit them. Let us look at some of the areas that Taxi Ted and his friends will hit in New South Wales: childcare, for example. This Government has worked with the Labor Government in New South Wales to provide a massive increase in childcare facilities.

There are roads, housing and, indeed, as I am sure my friend the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) would endorse, the environment. What will Taxi Ted and his mates do to the environment if the people of New South Wales decide that they should have a change of government? I represent with the honourable member for Hughes and the Minister at the table, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), the south coast area of New South Wales. It will be very severely hit if there is a change in government.

I must say that the New South Wales Opposition at the moment is making a lot of noise and getting a lot of media coverage. But in all this noise that I am hearing about members of the New South Wales Opposition, I am yet to hear of any of their policies. I do not really know what their policies are, what they are going to promise the people of New South Wales. The only thing they are promising to the people of New South Wales is a change. Quite frankly, with Taxi Ted and his mates it most certainly will be a change for the worst.

I really doubt very much whether the people of New South Wales would be prepared to gamble on the Opposition in New South Wales, to change the trusted Government of Barrie Unsworth and the fine record of that government and of the Wran Government before it in a whole range of areas. I will give one small example. It is not so very small for the people who have benefited in my own area on the south coast-the electrification of the railway line there. Are the people going to exchange that for the unknown quality of the Opposition? I look forward, in my area, after the New South Wales election to continue working with Bob Harrison who will be returned as the member for Kiama, Laurie Kelly who will be the new member for Wollongong, Terry Rumble the new member for Illawarra and Colin Markham, the new member for Keira. They will all excellently represent the south coast area of New South Wales in the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this Grievance Debate because I guess in an order of even 1 : 100 I would consider my concern for the Australian system of justice as very, very high were I to see it demeaned in any way or under a course of destruction. Therefore, I have a very severe grievance when I refer to these matters. I bring your attention, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the actions of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) yesterday on a very serious matter. He brought before this House in political defence of one of his colleagues a legal opinion prepared by the Solicitor-General which seeks to exonerate the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) from any charges, allegations or accusations regarding his actions in terms of the now well-known Medigate case where in fact, without lace, without doubt, the situation is that an offence has been committed.

SPEECH.PARA: We are at the position of deciding who committed the offence and I refer in this case to the opinion as tabled by the Prime Minister. I first complain, of course, that it has pre-empted proper police inquiries and it certainly will restrict their activities; even more so because the Prime Minister then announced that he is retaining the Minister in his position. Although actions within his Department are now to be the subject of police inquiries, he will be directing those police inquiries. That is a case of putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank. We must of course take note that it will be impossible for members of the staff to properly give evidence to the police when those sorts of circumstances arise.

My major complaint about this particular case is not one of bias or anything else. It is clearly a complaint about the professional standards that have been used in providing this advice. When one deals out in the private sector with lawyers, one deals with those who give good and honest advice. Even if it is something that one would like to proceed with, it is a good lawyer who tells his client that he cannot win; it is the good lawyer who tells him to save his money and gives him advice that he may not even like to read. That is what good professional lawyers do.

In this case, an opinion has been given which has very little to do with law. Were the matter before this Parliament or the matter for which an opinion had been sought a matter of, for instance, a takeover of a major company in Australia and the particular functions there, that would be a matter of law. It is not what people are doing or what they have done, what they have done behind closed doors or who rang up who; it is a question of legal rights or, in fact, the prohibitions that are placed upon people by the law. Such a legal opinion can be given and it can have great weight.

When a matter is won, where a law has apparently been broken, and we are at the point where we are seeking to find who broke the law-whether it be one person or a number of people-of course that matter, when in court, is always considered on the grounds of the evidence of the witnesses. That is always preceded, if it is a Crown case, by police activity, by police getting proofs of evidence and discovering what the case is. It is at that time, based on the proofs of evidence, that, for instance, someone like the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) makes a decision. We do not hear the DPP providing opinions to the Government on what he might do as a result of certain inquiries in progress, as the Solicitor-General has done. The Solicitor-General has given an opinion to the Government, his client, paid for of course by the taxpayers of Australia, and it carriers no qualification whatsoever as to the paucity of information available when this particular opinion was given and, as such, it is scandalous.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to parts of that report. In the beginning the Solicitor-General advises us: `Attached are the following: (1) the text of the statement made in the House of Representatives this evening by the Minister for Community Services and Health'. That was the statement in which he admitted he misled the House. The report goes on: `(2) a copy of a minute dated 7 January 1988 from the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission to the Minister for Community Services and Health'. That has been touted round this place as the Minister seeking advice from the Manager of the Health Insurance Commission (HIC), when, in fact, it is a letter written to the Minister approximately three months after certain information was released from the HIC to the Minister's office and subsequently to the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear).

It is not a case of a Minister going out and seeking advice as to what he could rightly or not rightly do. It is damage control and all that period before this letter was put out which the Solicitor-General uses as the basis of his advice to government, all of that previous information whatever it might be, is apparently ignored. The Solicitor-General then goes on to say:
I read the Minister's statement-
this is the statement he made in this Parliament-
as stating that the Minister himself had not seen the particular documents prior to their communication to the Member for Canning . . .

Now that could be so, but on what grounds does the Solicitor-General state that it is accurate? Did he see other proofs of evidence? Did he see supporting evidence from every member of the Minister's staff and the HIC that says that that is a fact? If it is the basis of his decision, is it not his responsibility to establish the facts? He goes on to say:

It is apparent that the Minister gave an authority in relation to information of a kind limited to information which did not contain anything which would identify doctors or patients including provider numbers.

What evidence has this Parliament been given of that? Why in the attachments to this opinion is that written instruction to the HIC not included? The Minister has not given us that. The Solicitor-General has just blithely taken the word of the Minister in declaring him innocent. The whole thing is that this is not an opinion of the sort of professional status that one would expect from the highest public legal officer in the land.

The realities of our courts are, when we go before a judge, that the law as it is written is significant, but so are the facts of evidence as to who might have broken that law. We are past the point as to whether the law was broken. The Minister has come in here and told us that his office received information regarding doctors and their remuneration-expressly forbidden by section 130 of the Health Insurance Commission Act-that the Health Insurance Commission passed that information to his office and, presumably, the original request was on his authorisation. We know that. We know that that information eventually ended up in a newspaper. We know that provider numbers were on the documents provided-on the Minister's admission-and we know the provider numbers, and I quote from the Act, `enable people to be identified'.

The Act, irrespective of all its other requirements, expressly forbids any action that would allow for the identification of an individual patient or practitioner. So why have we been able to declare the Minister innocent when there are no proofs of evidence provided for the Solicitor-General to make that judgment? He is entitled to make any judgment he likes but he should have informed the Parliament, through the Prime Minister, that he must qualify it on the paucity of the information. I say it is paucity of information because, firstly, he goes no further than to provide those two documents. Secondly, I know that he could not have had more than five or six sleeping hours to arrive at his decision; and, thirdly, we have not received any advice in this Parliament yet as to the progress of the police inquiries.

All we know is that as a result of this opinion, the Prime Minister in his inimitable fashion, a man of some legal training many years ago, has declared the Minister innocent and has said that he can retain his position and direct the Federal police in their inquiries. I repeat, that is putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank. It creates an impossible situation for the members of his staff and, of course, the members of the HIC.

More importantly let us get down to the last thing. We know a law has been broken; we know somebody broke it. The Prime Minister has told us that it was not the Minister. We just want to know who is going to be this Minister's Stephen Loosley. Who is going to carry the can for this Minister? Which member of his staff is he going to enter the witness box and give evidence against because that is where you have descended to in the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue I seek to raise today concerns the Opposition parties, the Liberal and National parties' attitude towards the protection of the Australian environment. In speaking, as I will, about the policies of Federal parties, I want the people of Australia to remember that the same parties are going to contest an election in New South Wales in a few weeks time. They are the same parties with the same priorities as the Federal representatives here in Canberra; only the faces are different.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a tragedy to see what has happened to the Liberal and National parties and their environmental policies. It once used to be the case that at least the Liberal Party could keep in check the more extreme elements of the National Party. Back when the Fraser Government was in power it was to the credit of that Government that it intervened, using Federal powers, to override the State of Queensland and protect Fraser Island. But such is the state of the Liberal Party these days that rather than override the National Party, it has embraced the policies of the extreme Right. It is very much under the domination of forces outside this Parliament. A party that was once a small `l' Liberal Party, in name at least, has now become, as I say, completely dominated by an extremist and alien political philosophy.

This is nowhere more evident that in its abdication of responsibility for protection of the Australian environment, because the Liberals say: `No matter how important the issue, no matter how special places are of natural significance in Australia, whether it be South West Tasmania, Kakadu National Park, the Uluru-Mount Olga National Park or the wet tropical rainforests of Queensland, no matter how special these areas and the recognition given to them as World Heritage areas, this national Opposition will refuse to override the States. From now on it is open slather for the destruction of the natural environment depending on the whims of the State Premiers'.

Not everyone in the Liberal Party shares this view. To his credit the former spokesman on the environment for the Liberal Party, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), before he was sacked went on the public record as saying that the main problem with the Liberals' environment policy is that it is utterly wedded to its position on State's rights and he called for a review of that policy. Indeed, the shadow spokesman for the environment, Senator Puplick, has made some attempts to change that policy. I will come to Senator Puplick's contribution in a moment.

The problem is that Senator Puplick in no way represents the Opposition. He is, regrettably, only a token wet on the Liberal Party front bench. He is attempting to give a human face to what is an entirely unacceptable and extremist policy, as I will point out. I know that Senator Puplick does have convictions in a number of areas and I respect his stand in relation to human rights and on some other matters. But on this issue, on the issue of the environment that falls within his responsibility, he is completely at odds, not only with his Leader, but also with the majority of his own Party and certainly totally at odds with the National Party. He has admitted himself that there are potentials for deep rifts between the parties on environmental issues and within parties. He was quoted in the Australian as saying precisely that on 3 February.

He has published a document which is entitled `Environment Policy Options, a Discussion Paper'. It was quite cleverly presented with a green cover. But as the Minister at the table, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), will see, when the green cover is removed, there really is not very much left in that policy that has any real substance insofar as the protection of the environment and the greening of the Liberal Party are concerned. That document is, in fact, only a discussion document; it does not have one single commitment to any policy. In fact Senator Puplick in the document says, `Until that policy is adopted, then the 1987 policy remains in place'.

Let me remind honourable members about the 1987 policy. That was the policy given before the election by the then Senator Collard, who is not even a member of the Liberal Party. He is one of Sir Joh's former apparatchiks who, I might add, was also unceremoniously dumped by Sir Joh and replaced with the even more extreme Senator Stone. I will turn to him in a moment. The great irony is that when this policy discussion paper was released by Senator Puplick, he did so at a Young Liberals Conference and said that Young Liberals have a very great and deep interest in environmental issues and would be welcomed as participants in consultation about the new policy. He was certainly right. They had an abiding interest in the environment because at the very same conference they put up a resolution calling for Australia to withdraw from the World Heritage Treaty, such was the attitude of many people at that conference.

It is not just people in the Young Liberals who have now been taken over by the same extreme forces that caused the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to jump but it is also the States, because the conservative States just will not accept anything other than total control over the environment. Many reports show the organisational attempts of those State Premiers to ensure that they stop Senator Puplick in his tracks. In fact, the Hobart Mercury reported only a month ago that the Tasmanian Premier, Robin Gray, will be attempting to bypass the Opposition spokesman and go directly to Mr Howard to make sure that there is no intervention over the rights of the Tasmanian Government. Of course, Mr Ahern and the National Party are not going to have a bar of any national responsibility either.

I ask people to think what the attitude of the Tasmanian Liberals is going to be in this place. Of course, they are going to jump when Mr Gray tells them. Senator Puplick, I regret to say, is going to be decimated by the likes of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who are just two of the hardline National Party members with no commitment to the preservation of the environment. His own leader, Mr Howard, has already gone on public record as recently as a few days ago saying that he would go on record and restate the coalition policy of opposing unilateral action in relation to environmental issues by the Federal Government. He ruled out the option of using the foreign affairs power and the World Heritage convention, a convention I might say that most small `l' liberals, most genuine liberals, fully support and endorse.

Mr Deputy Speaker, that brings me to the question of how the Liberal Party and the National Party relate to the environment in New South Wales because that State more than any other State of Australia has set a world trend. It has taken some initiatives that indeed have been noticed around the world because of their deep commitment to the preservation of the natural environment. I have the highest regard for the New South Wales Minister for Planning and Environment, Mr Bob Carr, who has taken this battle for the preservation of World Heritage areas to the very heart of the Government. I believe that history will show that future generations owe Mr Carr a great debt.

All that work of that Government is at risk if the Opposition wins government in New South Wales. One has to look only at the attitude of those conservative parties to see that time and time again they have gone on the public record as opposed to wilderness legislation, as opposed to the listing of the rainforests of New South Wales for World Heritage. I remind people that when that proposal went through the Parliament every member of the National Party opposed it; every single member. Not only that, but four Liberals actually voted with them. One of those four members was the increasingly unpopular honourable member for Bligh, Mr Yabsley, who is likely to lose his seat in the coming election.

The Liberal Party, showing the great courage of its convictions, did not even vote against it; its members walked out; they were not prepared to support that listing of those World Heritage rainforests in the New South Wales Parliament. They are on the record in this area as they are in so many other areas with their support for logging and their complete disregard for the environmental movement. Mr Deputy Speaker, for the sake of the New South Wales environment I could only hope that Bob Carr and the New South Wales Labor Government are returned in the New South Wales election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few weeks ago I attended a meeting in Broken Hill. At that meeting was a large attendance of 3,000 people and it is probably the largest meeting that I have seen in Broken Hill in my time there. The people were not there to protest about the lack of government action in support of the mining area, or anything like that. They were there to protest about the State Government's proposed regulations in relation to firearms laws that are about to be implemented with an amnesty lasting until 29 February. Broken Hill, as honourable members would know, is a fairly strong Labor stronghold. It has a voting pattern, I would say conservatively, of about 70 per cent Labor.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite all this, the people of Broken Hill are very conservative, law abiding people, and people who follow their government laws as well as anyone does in the State. But those people who attended that meeting were very cynical about State Government regulations which have been brought in and imposed before the forthcoming State election. Why are these regulations being imposed on the people? I suppose it was because the State Labor Government has done some research and has found that there is a poll out which shows that it is very soft on law and order. Law and order is almost unknown in New South Wales. The situation is almost critical.

The New South Wales Government is bad in its support of the hospital system. We all know that the Medicare system has just about ruined health support in this nation, but in New South Wales it is particularly bad. Of course, its support of education is also lacking. We all know about the famous Summary Offences Act which the New South Wales Labor Government has done away with and made things almost impossible for police in the State of New South Wales. So we find that the New South Wales Government wanted to be seen to be doing something about law and order.

What did it do? It had a knee-jerk reaction and brought in these gun control regulations. Who are these regulations affecting? Mainly, I would say, they are affecting the New South Wales police force because the New South Wales police force is under tremendous strain. The Government is saying to them, `Look, we want you now to try to enforce this law'. I believe it is unenforceable.

I am not one who would say that the shooters of New South Wales should defy the law. Certainly if they do, that leads only to anarchy. I would be the first one to say that that is not on. But I do believe that what the New South Wales Government has done in bringing in this legislation is making it very difficult for the New South Wales police force to enforce. Under the regulations that are coming in, all self-loading rifles are prohibited. This means it is an offence to use a self-loading rifle unless a ministerial permit is held. The maximum penalty for this offence, firstly, for having a self-loading rifle without ministerial approval, is seven years gaol with a $2,000 fine; and if that weapon is used to shoot a rabbit or something like that in the bush, one could get 10 years gaol with a $2,000 fine.

Let us have a look at some of the offences that have been committed in Broken Hill alone. I know many members of the House could tell me of some right throughout Australia. Recently, a gentleman fired a firearm at another person and wounded him in the ear. He got nine months gaol and was out within 7 1/2weeks. Let us compare that to other offences. Just to own one of these firearms involves about seven years and 10 years imprisonment. Seven and a half weeks for wounding somebody does not seem very long to me.

Recently in Broken Hill four people were seriously wounded by a gunman who almost completely destroyed their lives. He got 3 1/2 years gaol. Does this mean that if an offence of trying to murder someone with a knife, a brick, a single-shot firearm or with some other implement, or by electrocution, or whatever scheme might be dreamed up will attract very lenient sentences? But if some other thing is used the penalty is seven years or 10 years. So the whole thing is a nonsense. What we are really talking about here is that the Government really does have to tighten up on law and order. I am sure that if it did, it would not have to bring in these nonsensical laws that it is talking about here.

At the meeting in Broken Hill, it was interesting because a young lady rose to her feet to address the meeting, or to ask a question. She said that the Government is proposing to pay compensation to the people handing in firearms. We estimate that the compensation for the handing in of the firearms will cost the State Government $60m to $90m. Where that compensation is to be found I really do not know.

She went on to say that in the State of New South Wales they have spent about $3m in fighting the AIDS epidemic. We know from most reliable sources that it is estimated that in the next five to 10 years 5,000 to 10,000 people in New South Wales will be infected with AIDS. Many of those people will die and yet we are talking here about $3m on the AIDS campaign and $90m in compensation for firearms. Would you believe, Mr Deputy Speaker, that next Thursday at Kings Cross we are going to have another Gay Mardi Gras with government support? I ask the House: How could a New South Wales government which is supposed to be concerned about the welfare of the people who live in the State want to pay $60m to $90m in firearm compensation and then allow a Gay Mardi Gras to take place with its support? I really just cannot believe that. I know that the whole exercise is just completely cynical.

On the way the New South Wales Government is going to collect the $25, which will be another tax imposed on the people, for the registration of these firearms. The coalition, and the National Party in particular, supported the amendments to the Gun Laws Act which was brought in on 6 March 1985 and which required individuals owning or wishing to purchase long arms to acquire a shooters licence by applying to the nearest police station. Police were then to examine the applicants and certify an applicant as a fit or proper person to hold the firearm.

The National Party accepted the provision that a shooters licence was also necessary to purchase ammunition. However, the National Party rejected that section of the amendments to the Act which required the full registration of all long arms. It supported the existing controls in regard to pistols and revolvers. By the way, some of those regulations are some of the toughest in the world. I see this whole thing as a cynical exercise and such was the Government's rush to bring in this regulation that it was brought to my attention by Mr Bill Woodroffe, who is a prominent pistol shooter in Broken Hill and also one of those who organised the meeting, that the Government has said that under certain conditions, of course, a rifle can be owned. One of the main conditions is that it is to carry out vermin control. The requirement is: `People wishing to shoot vermin will be eligible to obtain a licence as follows: the applicant indicates a wish to shoot vermin . . .' And so on and so forth.

I wonder whether the people drafting that legislation know that the dictionaries-we checked six dictionaries, including Websters, Oxford, Collins, Readers Digest, Britannica-include in the definition of vermin `noxious or offensive insects, grubs or worms, lice, fleas', et cetera. Then it states: `low, noxious or repulsive persons'. I think the New South Wales Government had better check up on that and had better give us a definition of what it means by `vermin'. It is giving these people who are able to obtain a licence almost a 007 licence; they can get rid of noxious people or people whom they regard as noxious. Even the dictionary that I picked up here in the Parliament, the Cassells New English dictionary, has that definition that I just read out.
I think, Mr Deputy Speaker, these gun laws of the New South Wales Government can be no better summed up than in the editorial in the Wagga Wagga Daily Advertiser of 27 January 1988. It says:

From this time forward no private property of any kind is sacrosanct under the Unsworth or any socialist government since, by the gun law precedent, all that the Unsworths of this country will require is a sufficient excuse to declare individuals incompetent, unpredictable, or antagonistic to legislate away specific property rights in the name of some vaguely plausible belief that the public welfare is at risk. The hypocrisy of politics is evidenced by the Unsworth, and certainly the Cain Government in Victoria, since both have preyed on public fear to carry their particular case against private firearms ownership and their unstated program against private ownership generally.

I think that is the crux of the matter, Mr Deputy Speaker; that we are not really on about law and order or protecting society or anything else. It really is, firstly, a socialist ploy but, secondly, it also is out to win votes particularly among city voters. But I am sure that the Australian electorate and the New South Wales electorate are much more educated than the Government gives them credit for and will show their protest at this action by the New South Wales Government at the next poll.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was rather surprised that the previous speaker did not finish with a punch line suggesting that there are commies under the bed. I want to tell members of the Liberal and National parties that voters in the Hunter Valley are not the fools they believe them to be. The Liberals and Nationals in the Hunter Valley are pushing a line in the State electorates in an attempt to deceive the voters. The conservatives, Mr Greiner's whiners, are preaching the nonsense that a Labor government spends nothing in safe Labor seats. They certainly do not push this argument in safe Liberal and National seats. This line was tried in the Hunter electorate in last year's Federal elections. `Hawke is neglecting Hunter', they screamed. They shut up quickly, however, when I produced evidence of more than $100m of Federal expenditure in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: The same is true of State electorates in the Hunter Valley. The Unsworth Government has poured millions into Labor seats in the Valley. Only the other day I joined New South Wales Minister Janice Crosio in the opening of a $17m water project to benefit Cessnock, Maitland and the lower areas of the Hunter Valley. Other projects which come quickly to mind include $4 billion spent on two new power stations; millions of dollars on new schools, technical and further education colleges, hospitals and community projects; $160m on Rankin Park Hospital alone; $400m on electric trains; and millions on road improvements. Will voters forget the $40m spent on a second Hexham Bridge or the millions spent on Newmed and the new oncology unit and operating and cardiac units?

The Unsworth Government, Mr Deputy Speaker, has provided a record number of Housing Commission homes; it has spent $20m on the Newcastle grain terminal and millions on harbour foreshore projects. Barrie Unsworth and the Labor members are certainly good value for the Hunter Valley and are diverting unprece- dented levels of funding to the Hunter Valley. Voters will know which side their bread is buttered on on 19 March and will support trusted and proven Labor members.

During the New South Wales election, the Liberals and Nationals and some so-called independents should not escape close questioning on major issues. People want to know what their real motives and real policies are. Unsworth policies are there for all to see; they are sound policies and now we know the truth about the Liberals' policies. A New South Wales member of parliament, Mr Pickering, has revealed that the Liberals have two policies on every issue-a dummy one to fool the voters and a real one to sock the voters should their duplicity succeed and they win power in New South Wales.

Mr Greiner and his mob appear happy to see the Government of New South Wales suffer criticism for its laudable toughening of gun laws, but what is Mr Greiner's real policy on gun laws? The New South Wales Opposition has used monstrous scare tactics, trying to scare the pants off people, but the sensible, silent majority supports a saner, safer society and detests needless carnage caused by sick minds, sick Rambos. Sensible, responsible shooters have nothing to fear. They will not be fooled by public meetings called and promoted by political beings for political gain. Go and talk to some of the people who express some concern about gun laws and ask them: `What are the things that really worry you? What are your chief concerns in life? What are your main priorities?'. Ask them: `Your own home? A good job, sufficient money to buy food for yourself and your family, a good wife and healthy kids, good roads, hospitals, good schools, good educational opportunities?'.

Then one might ask: `Are they the most important things in your life?'. They could say: `Yes, I cannot think of anything more important, anything enjoying a higher priority'. Then you say to them: `Where the hell do guns come in that list? How important are guns really?'. I believe that out there is a great silent majority and it will endorse the Unsworth Government's laudable attempt to create a safe and saner society.

This is just a trivial little thing. I do not believe that sensible voters, because they are opposed to the toughening of the gun laws, will forget all the other things that the New South Wales Government is doing, which is great for the greatest State of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I listened this morning to your fine contribution in the debate on the Students Assistance Bill. I was struck by your expression of concern for the battlers of our society. What you said is correct because traditionally the major concern of the Australian Labor Party has been for those in our society who are less well off. That concern has been evident in the policies of the Hawke Federal Labor Government and it has been equally evident in the policies, priorities and activities of Labor governments in the States.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the federal system the State governments are charged with the responsibility of providing services that are so important to ordinary people. The well-off in our society may be able to buy the health care of their choice. They may be able to buy an education of their choice. They can afford to travel by private means. The less well-off, the great bulk of ordinary people, depend upon their State governments to provide quality services in health, in education and in transport. That is exactly what the New South Wales Labor Government has been doing over the past 12 years.

An enormous backlog in the provision of services developed in the Liberal years from 1965 to 1976 in New South Wales. Only since the election of Labor has New South Wales moved forward. There is, of course, a battle on in New South Wales at the moment and the pendulum appears to be moving.

After the election of the Wran Government in 1976 with a majority of a single seat to the great landslides of 1978 and 1981 we had Labor firmly in power in Macquarie Street. As I say, it is clear from public comment and from the media that this election may be different. There are reasons for this: firstly, the media appear to be preoccupied with trivia, rather than with the substance of achievement. Secondly, the New South Wales Opposition is running without policies. Of course, it is always safer for an Opposition to run without policies. In the Federal campaign of last year the Opposition federally produced its policies and got into deep trouble. The third factor, Mr Deputy Speaker, I refer to as the short memory syndrome.

Let me take honourable members briefly for a trip down memory lane to look at what conditions were like in New South Wales before the election of Labor in 1976. Let me refer first of all to public transport, to our trains. In 1976 the New South Wales public railway system was literally falling apart. I can remember that in my district in the early 1970s derailments were a regular event. Coal trains and other trains were falling off the tracks because those tracks had not been maintained and were falling apart. Trains frequently arrived late. Many simply did not arrive at all. With the election of a Labor government in 1976 a track upgrading program was commenced; fares were cut; new interurban trains, the air-conditioned double deckers were provided; the suburban system was made more efficient. That work has continued. The Tangarra train has arrived. I think it may be in my electorate today or, if not, it will be very soon so that people can have a look at this magnificent addition to the suburban fleet.

What could we expect under a Liberal government in New South Wales in public transport? We could certainly expect a return to the neglect of the past. Commuters could also expect dramatic increases in fares. I have some material which illustrates what would happen to rail fares under a Greiner government. Just as an example, currently a worker's weekly, a periodical weekly to the city from the stations of Emu Plains, Lapstone, Glenbrook and Blaxland, costs, I understand, $19.50. Applying the Greiner user-pays principle, the cost of that ticket would increase to $53.80, an increase from $19.50 to $53.80 for a worker's weekly. From the stations of Kingswood and Penrith a worker's weekly to the city currently costs $16.70. Applying the Greiner user-pays principle, the cost of that ticket would increase to $46.10.

The provision of educational services has equally seen dramatic improvements, particularly in the area that I represent. Before 1976 there was a poor provision of schools locally, the technical and further education system was run down and very few of our young people stayed on to enjoy a full secondary education. Under a Labor State government, schools in the area have been built when the were needed and not five or six years later. I can recall that not so long ago there were only four high schools in my district, in the early 1970s; now there are seven and one is nearing completion. At the same time, retention rates have improved dramatically through the good work of the Federal Labor Government and also with the active co-operation and support of the State Labor Government in New South Wales. That work is continuing in western Sydney with the ministerial task force on educational opportunity in western Sydney due to report very shortly. I am confident that some new measures will be adopted to further improve educational opportunities for our young people in the west.

I refer to the new technical and further education (TAFE) colleges that have been built in the district. The Werrington TAFE college is operating this year and the Mount Druitt TAFE College was built under the State Labor Government. Anyone visiting either of those colleges can see exactly what the existence of a State Labor government working as the Unsworth Government can do to provide additional educational opportunities for our young people.

In the area of higher education we have seen under Labor in New South Wales a rapid expansion of the Nepean College of Advanced Education, the Macarthur Institute of Higher Education, and the Hawkesbury Agricultural College. In March of last year we saw an historic agreement between the Federal and State Labor governments to establish the Chifley University College of Sydney University in western Sydney. The Liberals have never been interested in this project; they have never been interested in expanding higher education in the west. They proved that when they put Macquarie University in the wrong place back in the 1960s. They have failed to back this particular project. In fact, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), when he was in my electorate in October of 1986 at a gathering there, said that he did not support the establishment of a university in the west of Sydney.

I am very much afraid that should the Liberals be elected in New South Wales they would stop this project dead in its tracks or relocate the university college to areas that would provide them with support because that is exactly what they did with Macquarie University back in the 1960s.

Looking at our achievements in the public hospital area, there has been a lot of hysteria in this field. The truth is, as established by the New South Wales Healthline, that our hospitals in New South Wales are doing a magnificent job. It should never be forgotten that it was a Labor government that built the Westmead Hospital at Parramatta. A Labor government built Mount Druitt Hospital and it was a Labor government that provided those magnificent extensions to the Nepean District Hospital in Penrith. Our record in the health field has been magnificent.

Turning to roads, before 1976 I can recall local roads were in poor condition; they were frequently choked at peak hour, but under Labor four-lane divided roads have been provided or are under construction through the Blue Mountains; the F4 freeway has proceeded; much additional work has been carried out on that freeway in the form of ramps; more work is to be undertaken on the missing link in the F4 freeway from Mays Hill to Prospect and, of course, under Labor in New South Wales, the F4 freeway bridge over the Nepean River was widened from two to four lanes. It gives one an idea of Liberal priorities, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Liberal Government built a four-lane freeway but only a two-lane bridge over that particular river.

The achievements in recent years, Mr Deputy Speaker, are a result of a magnificent co-operative effort between Labor in Canberra and Labor in New South Wales. It is in the interests of ordinary people, those battlers of whom you spoke this morning, that this co-operation should continue. The advances that have been achieved need to be preserved and we need to continue to make further progress. That progress is possible only under a Labor government in Macquarie Street.

I commend local sitting State members in my area. Peter Anderson is a great Minister for Health in the New South Wales Government. Bob Debus is the Minister for Finance. Both of them will be re-elected on 19 March. Ron Mulock is retiring and exciting new blood will enter the New South Wales Parliament on 19 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, we are told that the official opening date of the new Brisbane International Airport is to be 20 March. This date, I am sure, is being welcomed by all Queenslanders and, indeed, it should be welcomed by all Australians because we have been waiting for this Government to give us an indication as to when this huge construction, the biggest construction undertaken in Australia since the Snowy Mountains scheme, is to open. In fact, the new Brisbane International Airport was supposed to open in September last year and since then the Department of Aviation and the various Ministers of this Government have been procrastinating about just when the event is to occur.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally 20 March is the date that Brisbane comes on line with a fully operational runway and a brand new domestic terminal. But the travesty of the whole of the Brisbane International Airport operation is simply this: this Government has decided not to proceed with the new international terminal for Brisbane and at a time when we are about to enter the Expo 88 phase; at a time when Queensland is generating 48 per cent of the inbound tourist traffic into Australia, we have a case where a storage shed that was constructed at the old terminal site is still going to serve as the gateway to Queensland. Brisbane, of course, is the third major international airport terminal in Australia. It is fast coming up on Melbourne and I would predict that with the facilities of the new international runway it will not be too long before Brisbane overtakes Melbourne as the number two airport.

Basically, the problem is this: we are stuck with an international terminal that was designed as a store shed, that will require taxiing of more than 7 1/2 kilometres by international aircraft before they get to the new runway, a problem that in itself causes all sorts of technical problems for 747 aircraft.

We are stuck with an air terminal that has only five gates available to it. Really we can see no way out of the problem of the overcrowding and congestion that befalls Brisbane as the result of the lack of foresight and the ineptitude of the members of the Labor Government. I think we should go back over the history of the new Brisbane International Airport development. It was a move by the Liberal Government of 1969 that gave the go-ahead for the redevelopment of Brisbane. In the Whitlam years that particular project was shelved. In 1977-78 the then Liberal Government gave the go-ahead for the construction of this airport complete with that new international terminal. Since then and with the advent of the present Labor Government we saw that particular terminal put on hold. That decision was made, I believe, in a most short-sighted way.

It was short-sighted because the decision not to proceed with the terminal was made prior to Brisbane hosting the Commonwealth Games and we know what dreadful congestion we saw at that time. It was made prior to the expansion of the international tourist industry in Australia and especially in Queensland. That decision was made prior to the decision of Queensland to hold World Expo 88. Now we are stuck with this situation with no indication whatsoever from the Government that it is even going to consider the rebuilding of the international terminal prior to 1992.

I think it is going to be an absolute travesty if people arriving into Australia through Brisbane for World Expo 88 are to be delayed because of the lack of facilities, because of the lack of space and the lack of parking bays that will be the Brisbane International terminal. I would suggest that one thing that the Government might do to try to redeem itself in the eyes of Queenslanders is to make a very quick decision to proceed with the construction of the new international terminal, because that terminal was designed, it was there with the initial plans for the airport.

The prime reason the Government gave for not proceeding with that project was its cost. Yet more than 12 months ago private consortia were going to the Government and saying, `Look, if you do not want to proceed with that terminal let us do it and it will cost the taxpayer absolutely nothing'. In the initial designs of that new international terminal there were full facilities. There was an international standard hotel involved, there were rail links with the cities, but no, this Government and the then Minister, Mr Morris, refused to listen and refused to give any credence to the private development of the Brisbane international terminal. We are now stuck with this mess.

The fact is that more than 800,000 international visitors will be coming into Queensland and into Brisbane specifically for World Expo. There is a very real fear in the community, in the business area, in the tourist industry of Queensland, that we are going to give a very bad impression as people arrive at the old tin shed, the old storage shed, that serves as the Brisbane international terminal. The fact that it has no covered walkways, the fact that it has no air bridges, means that international arrivals coming into Brisbane are stuck with the elements of the weather and that can often prove a very difficult period as they transfer from their international flights into the international terminal.

It is indeed an absolute disgrace that the people of Brisbane have been denied this proper facility for so long. They have been denied that facility by this particular Government and this particular Government has now been found out as not really being fair dinkum in its terms of approach to the international tourist industry and the arrival of tourists in Australia. Not only is Brisbane a debacle; Sydney is an absolute debacle. One wonders at the intelligence of some of the people in the government of this country when they would seem to do their absolute best to ignore completely this critical problem.

It is true that Australia is riding on a tourist boom, but the great difficulty with tourism is that if a bad impression is created with our international visitors, they will go back and tell the people of their particular country of the problems that they experienced, and the worst form of publicity that can be generated is word of mouth publicity. I would think that some of those 800,000 people coming into Brisbane for World Expo will do just that-go home and bad mouth us; and this Government and the Ministers responsible for aviation are to blame.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m. in accordance with standing order 106 as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to the opinion prepared by the Solicitor-General on the Blewett affair. Who gave the Solicitor-General his instructions? When were the instructions given? What was in the brief given to the Solicitor-General? Will the Prime Minister table the brief? Will any further opinions or reports from either the Solicitor-General, the Australian Federal Police (AFP) or the Director of Public Prosecutions also be tabled at the appropriate time? In view of the fact that a police report has been called for, why was the Solicitor-General's opinion sought before all the facts had been collected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The process of briefing the Solicitor-General was, of course, properly undertaken by the Minister responsible. I personally had no part in the briefing of the Solicitor-General. As I say, the proper processes were followed. Clearly, as I said in an answer in this House yesterday, a question had been raised with regard to the Minister for Community Services and Health and, properly, therefore, that question was referred by my Minister in his briefing of the Solicitor-General.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said yesterday in tabling the legal advice from which I had my judgment confirmed-in opposition to what has happened on the other side of the House-I have had confirmed unequivocally the total confidence I have in the Minister. As I explained yesterday-I should have thought to the satisfaction of anyone with a minimum understanding of this matter-the proper processes have been undertaken with regard to the rest of the matter, at the request of the Minister himself. He requested in writing the Acting Minister to ask the Australian Federal Police to undertake its investigations as to whether a breach had occurred and, if so, by whom. On the basis of the report from the AFP, if any further action is required, the appropriate policies will be followed.
