TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to reports that have appeared in the media today concerning an alleged claim by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) that a national wage system be adopted that would have the effect of increasing by 6 per cent immediately all wages and salaries paid in Australia. I ask the Minister whether he can confirm that that report is correct, and can he give an indication as to the basis of such a system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the reports to which the honourable member for Charlton referred. I am aware that yesterday the executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions adopted a resolution with regard to the wages system that should operate after the middle of this year. That resolution included the need for a simpler system, the maintenance of living standards, assurance of outcomes, tax and social wage bargaining to take place, maintenance of the restructuring and efficiency principle-which is the existing principle in the present wages system as a means of achieving an increase, but with more emphasis on restructuring than on the efficiency side-regard to be had to the prospective cost of living, and to both minimum and maximum outcomes.

ANSWER.PARA: If I could make a few points with regard to the resolution, I say, firstly, that all this is not new. It has been substantially foreshadowed in recent weeks. Secondly, it comes at the start of a long period of negotiations and, eventually, advocacy before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. As Mr Crean has said today, it is essentially a negotiating position. Thirdly, the ACTU resolution said nothing about figures, despite what was in the Press this morning. As far as I am aware there has been no mention of figures in Press briefings, either. This morning's headlines which featured 6 per cent and $25 are, I think, a quite misleading representation of the ACTU's resolution. The figures are purely a figment of someone's imagination. Fourthly, the prospective rate of inflation will depend substantially on the wage outcome. It is fairly obvious that there is clearly a chicken and egg problem with regard to the ACTU's position, and that problem would need to be sorted out if the ACTU's position were to be adopted.

The Government's position is that as the process of developing the wages system for the next financial year gets under way, we will be seeking to have a number of principles established in that wages system. They are, briefly, that within the context of a centralised control of the overall outcome we would want to see an outcome that is conducive to continued structural adjustments, and for current account deficit reduction; a greater variability of outcome than we have had under the present system, or, indeed, its predecessors since we have been in office; a continued inducement to increase productivity which, of course, the present system provides. For the first time in our wage fixing history we have a system which specifically provides for increased productivity. That is something that we would seek to have maintained in the wages system. Further, we would want incentives for skill formation and, finally, provision for industry and enterprise-level bargaining. Whether such a system can be put into place remains to be seen. The Government would certainly hope that it can be. We believe that that could be compatible with the ACTU's objective of maintaining living standards, but that will depend crucially on improvement in our productivity performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health. Will the Minister outline to the House what procedures must be followed for obtaining from the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) information of the kind that was supplied to the Minister's office? Has the Health Insurance Commission expressed any concern about the nature of the information sought in this instance?

—The Health Insurance Commission provides material of a statistical nature on request from members of this Parliament, and to other bodies in the community. As I have indicated on several occasions, it frequently happens that other organisations in this society ask for statistical information from the HIC. Indeed, many members of the Parliament have been provided with statistical information from the HIC.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister inform the House whether the passing over of doctor provider numbers to the honourable member for Canning has any implications for the Government's attitude to the protection of civil liberties?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to the honourable member for Calare that this Government has set the highest standards for the protection of civil liberties. I repeat that this Government has set the highest standards for the protection of civil liberties and of individual privacy. Yesterday I pointed out to the House the hypocrisy of the Opposition in this matter when, last week, the Opposition's claim was that this Government should ignore the rights and privacy of individuals by maintaining that the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, should break all the standard precepts and practices of this House, should ignore the specific advice of the Australian Federal Police and, against all that advice and practice, should disclose confidential information relating to an individual. Of course, this week the Opposition's story is a different one. But we are not in any sense deluded by its hypocrisy. As I have said, we as a government adhere to our high standards in this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable members will know, special privacy legislation, designed to provide greater protection of privacy than has been afforded by any previous government, is currently on the House of Representatives Notice Paper. The Minister for Community Services and Health and I have said all along that the inclusion of provider numbers on the material passed to the honourable member for Canning, though inadvertent, was both regrettable and wrong. As I have pointed out, an investigation into that matter has been initiated by the Minister for Community Services and Health. However, the Leader of the Opposition has sought to protect that small minority of doctors who engage in overcharging by claiming that any attempt to expose overcharging is an invasion of the civil liberties of doctors. On Tuesday night in this place the Opposition Leader said:
Even if the Minister . . . had deleted the provider numbers . . . what he was doing was still an unacceptable exercise of Big Brotherism.
He went on to say:
The information was made available with a malicious intent to do one thing: to damage the reputation of the medical profession in Australia.

It is remarkable to notice that the hopelessness and the hypocrisy of Opposition members puts them at odds even with Dr Bruce Shepherd on this issue. As we know, Dr Bruce Shepherd is President-elect of the Australian Medical Association. He was asked:

But is there anything wrong in the Government's price control network saying that some doctors are overcharging: beware of those doctors, in the same way as they say some supermarkets charge too much for coffee: beware of those supermarkets.

Dr Bruce Shepherd was asked that question and his answer was, `We have no objection to that'. So members of the Opposition are at odds even with Dr Shepherd on this issue. In the past, under the guise of protecting civil liberties, the Leader of the Opposition, in his capacity as former Treasurer, protected tax cheating which we know happened at that time because Commissioner Costigan, a royal commissioner appointed by him, described it as the fastest growing industry in this country. Just as the Leader of the Opposition protected those people at that time and allowed the tax avoidance industry to become the fastest growth industry in this country, so, again, the Leader of the Opposition seeks to protect that small minority-I emphasise a small minority-of doctors who overcharge their patients. Once again, and with total consistency, the Leader of the Opposition is the champion of the rights of the privileged few to rip off ordinary Australians.

In conclusion let me say that this Government is proud of the medical profession in Australia. It is proud of the excellent standard of health services that it delivers. But, having said that we are proud of the medical profession in this country, we will not sit back in a conspiracy of silence with that small minority of doctors who overcharge their patients and support their attempts to rip off ordinary Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question again to the Minister for Community Services and Health, and remind him of the part of the question that I asked which he did not answer. I asked: Has the Health Insurance Commission expressed any concern about the nature of the information sought by the Minister's office in the instance under discussion?

—The Health Insurance Commission has not expressed any concern to me about the information provided to my office. I point out quite clearly that we encourage the Health Insurance Commission to provide statistical information to all requests that are made of it because we on this side of the House believe that it is very valuable for the Australian community to have that kind of information so that there can be informed debate about our health system based on effective statistics.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MARINE ANIMALS AND PLANTS: PHARMACEUTICAL TESTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. I ask the Minister to inform the House whether work being conducted by the Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS) and the James Cook University of north Queensland involves collecting large quantities of marine animals and plants from the Great Barrier Reef. Is the Minister aware of newspaper criticism that the Institute of Marine Science and the university are acting as collecting agents for American pharmaceutical companies which may derive great profits from any commercial products? Is the criticism soundly based? What is being done to protect Australia's intellectual property?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Herbert for his question. There are two separate projects involving research into potential therapeutic substances in marine organisms found in the Great Barrier Reef. The James Cook University is working with the United States of America's non-profit foundation, and the Australian Institute of Marine Science with the National Cancer Institute (NCI) of the United States. Of course, AIMS is one of the world's great marine facilities, very ably represented here by the honourable member for Herbert. The university's project involves Dr Joe Baker, now the Director of AIMS, and Dr Peter Murphy as co-chief investigators. The American foundation supports the research which is aimed at understanding the role of different naturally occurring substances in marine organisms and testing those substances for biological activity and pharmaceutical tests.

ANSWER.PARA: The foundation has sub-contracts with American commercial companies and with the National Cancer Institute where tests are conducted for anti-tumour, anti-viral and, very significantly, anti-acquired immune deficiency syndrome potential. There is no opportunity in Australia to expose the marine extracts and substances to such a wide battery of tests as are available in the United States; that is a situation which must be changed in Australia if we are to have an international pharmaceutical industry on our own.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—I am glad that the honourable gentleman agrees. It is an absolute precondition. The quantities collected for initial testing are generally about one kilogram for each species. The area is surveyed before collection to ensure that only a small fraction of the available resource is collected. Permits are acquired through the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in all areas; these have been obtained and the obligations have been honoured. No endangered species of marine animal or plant is exported.

ANSWER.PARA: The AIMS agreement is direct with the National Cancer Institute. If an active substance is obtained, all rights to the commercial development will remain with AIMS. That is very important. The research being conducted is fully consistent with Government policy. My only regret is that at the moment in Australia we do not have the infrastructure for all the necessary steps in this high risk but potentially very high profit research and development industry. So the AIMS-NCI agreement is very much in Australia's best interests, both scientifically and commercially.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a simple and straightforward question for the Minister for Community Services and Health: On what date was the request to the Health Insurance Commission for the information provided to the honourable member for Canning made? How was that request made? Who made the request? When was this information received in his office? When was it conveyed to the honourable member for Canning?

—I am not able to give precise dates. What I can say to the honourable member is that the requests and the handling of that information were made toward the end of October-November. I am quite prepared to get him the specific dates.

—I address my question to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care. I draw the Minister's attention to a proposal by the New South Wales Opposition to sell public rental housing at a discount to existing tenants. What would be the effect of such a proposal on existing Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement funding arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question and for her involvement in the housing issue. I have seen the Greiner proposal but, for those who have not, the highlight of the housing policy of the New South Wales Opposition is the proposed scheme to sell off public housing at up to $10,000 below its real value. Mr Greiner, in his enthusiasm for buying votes in the coming election, seems to ignore the fact that the Commonwealth and the New South Wales Labor governments have invested hundreds of millions of dollars over the last five years in building up public housing stock in New South Wales. The New South Wales Opposition simply assumes, and expects the ordinary voter in New South Wales to accept, that it can flog off this major national and New South Wales asset without any regard to its legal and moral obligations.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been advised by senior officers in my Department that this policy scam is in direct contravention of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Under this agreement the sale of public housing is restricted to market or replacement cost only. The money from the sales must be directed back into public housing. The whole idea of this is to ensure, with the Commonwealth and the States, a commitment to maintain and expand the stock of public sector housing. Under this ill-considered scheme only a few people will benefit from this short term fix-that is all we can expect from the policies of the Liberal Party-while a major national resource is squandered and the waiting list for affordable public housing for low to medium income families will blow out. This will cause higher rents and much greater homelessness in New South Wales. The President of the Real Estate Institute in New South Wales, Mr Bevan, raised this matter yesterday.

As the Minister responsible for the investment in public housing of such large amounts of taxpayers' money, I do not intend to sit back and allow the intent and the legal requirements of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement to be sold out in this way. Under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement of 1984, which was signed by the Commonwealth and the New South Wales Labor governments, we provided stability and greater long term planning for housing initiatives in the States. Over the first three years 50,000 new public housing dwellings were constructed or purchased, 130,000 families have been housed, and 40,000 home loans have been provided to low income families. This Government has lifted funding under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement by over 40 per cent in real terms and nearly $1 billion has gone into the first home owners scheme. The people who have been helped by the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement are the people on low incomes, single parent families and single pensioners or pensioner couples.

What do those opposite intend to do? Will they let this situation go on? I heard when I got up all the `hear, hears' at the proposal to sell off public housing. Is that the Opposition's policy? Does it follow along with the policy of the New South Wales Opposition? The Opposition has been quite silent on this three-card trick that the Opposition in New South Wales will attempt to perpetrate on the people of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —In five years of your Government--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Bradfield.

—They are conspicuously absent, as they are conspicuously absent in New South Wales. The New South Wales Liberals do not want these losers up there, with their lynch mob mentality. They have a dirty name.

—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister is well aware that this is Question Time and it is not the time to make statements. He is also well aware of the 160,000 people on the public housing list who do not have housing.
—Order! The honourable member for Bradfield is not raising a point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.
—In five years what have you achieved?
—Order! I have already warned the honourable member for Bradfield. I suggest that he take heed of the Chair's warning.

—When the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement was passed in this House only a couple of years ago it brought support from all parties, but now honourable members on the other side want to change it. That shows the discredited policies they have got. The talent of the Liberal Party for economic vandalism, the greedy recruiting the needy, its fistful of dollars attitude to elections is not confined to the Canberra club here. The New South Wales Opposition thinks just like the absurd claims made by the Opposition in the election last year, that it can manufacture money to pay for these bribes. I am afraid that that cannot happen. This attitude to the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement cannot be allowed to go on. The proposal to flog off this major public asset will do nothing for the people of New South Wales.

—I refer the Minister for Community Services and Health to the fact that the only written evidence he has presented to the Parliament is a letter written approximately three months after the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) illegally provided confidential information to his office for transmission to the honourable member for Canning. I ask the Minister: What other written evidence exists regarding this matter? Who authorised the request to the HIC for the supply of this information? Who made the actual request to the HIC and by what method of communication? Who provided the information to the Minister's office and in what form? Who in the Minister's office provided the information to the honourable member for Canning and was the information modified or rewritten in any way? And the Minister should not tell me he cannot remember; it is burned on his brain.

—As I indicated to the honourable member for Richmond, members of my office are in constant touch with the Health Insurance Commission about a whole range of statistical information. I am not, therefore, able to give the precise dating and timing. I did indicate to the honourable member for Richmond that I would provide that precise information.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH AFRICA: RESTRICTIONS ON POLITICAL OPPOSITION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Prime Minister concerns the disturbing new developments in South Africa. What is the Government's position on the new restrictions on political opposition announced by the South African Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government strongly condemns the new restrictions aimed at banning all political activities by black opposition groups such as the United Democratic Front, the UDF, and trade union groups such as Cosatu. These measures underline the totalitarian, intransigent nature of the apartheid regime in South Africa. The racist Botha Government has moved once again to strangle non-violent, political self-expression by the black majority and the capacity of black working people to defend their industrial rights. These measures will affect even the valuable humanitarian work of organisations such as the Detainees Parents Support Committee.

ANSWER.PARA: I note that the main white parliamentary opposition party, the Progressive Federal Party, has condemned the new restrictions as `horrific in their content' and as another massive step towards authoritarianism. I would have hoped that it would be increasingly obvious that negotiations hold out the only hope of a non-violent resolution of the South African tragedy. I can say from my own contacts with them that black leaders in such organisations as the African National Congress (ANC) and Cosatu favour negotiations as a means of ending apartheid.

It is a tragedy that, in a situation where we still have in the front line states, in the ANC and in the other relevant organisations, a generation of leadership which sees negotiation as the best way of resolving the tragedy which is South Africa, there is not only a continuation of the previous refusal by the Botha regime to enter into negotiations but, indeed, as evidenced in these latest measures, an apparent increase even in its intransigence on this issue.

As I have had cause to say in this House and in other places on many occasions, the tragedy of South Africa will be resolved in only one of two ways. It will be resolved by the processes of negotiation or it will be resolved by the processes of violence. It is only through the processes of negotiation that white South Africans and foreign interests in South Africa will have the opportunity of continuing to make a constructive contribution to a future South Africa. It is, as I say, an enormous tragedy that we have these new measures which seem to underline even more firmly the lack of preparedness of the South African regime to grasp the only hope that is available for a non-violent resolution of that tragedy.

The effect of the new regulations can only be to increase bitterness and to drive opposition underground and into other forms of expression. I make it clear to the honourable gentleman who asked the question that Australia will be expressing clearly to the South African Government, both at ambassadorial level here in Canberra and in South Africa, our condemnation of the new restrictions. These new measures to which I refer, and which have been mentioned by the honourable gentleman in his question, confirm this Government's view-a view shared by the Eminent Persons Group which involved as co-chairman my predecessor as Prime Minister-that international pressure, including pressure through economic sanctions, is indispensable in these last continuing desperate attempts by reasonable men and women around the world to bring the South African Government to its senses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, by indulgence could I say that, although in some areas there is a difference of policy and emphasis-and I make no bones about that-between the Government and the Opposition in relation to South Africa, I and my colleagues wholeheartedly associate ourselves with the condemnation by the Prime Minister of those latest restrictions.

—I again address a question to the Minister for Community Services and Health. Given that the Minister has admitted in the House that some doctor provider numbers were included in the information provided to the honourable member for Canning, which doctor provider number was recorded on that Health Insurance Commission information-the number used for Medicare transactions, the number used for pharmaceutical benefits scheme transactions, or both?
—As far as I know, it was an abbreviated provider number. I am not able to answer as to which of the two it referred to. It was simply an abbreviated provider number at the top of the document.

—My question, which I direct to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, concerns the treatment of ex-servicewomen. Can the Minister inform the House of the progress made in providing treatment benefits to ex-servicewomen of World War II?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable for Forde for her question and also for the great work she does on behalf of veterans in her electorate. In 1984 the Government commissioned a study of World War II ex-servicewomen. That study showed that these women, who had provided such a valuable service for their country, had in fact suffered discrimination and disadvantage both during and after service. Providing treatment benefits for these women was a promise made by the Prime Minister in the policy speech which opened the Government's 1987 election campaign. This promise was kept in the 1987-88 Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to inform all honourable members that since 1 January this year approximately 1,000 women have been identified and granted their new entitlements by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. This new entitlement will give full treatment benefits to these ex-servicewomen who were not previously eligible. Increased pharmaceutical benefits and travel expenses will become available to many women who are already covered by the repatriation treatment system.

This is once again a further indication of the Government's continuing commitment to the veterans in this community. Many of the women have been identified from departmental and Commonwealth Army records, and the major ex-service associations are also helping. Women who believe that they are eligible but have not yet been in contact with the Department should contact their State branch of the Department or make inquiries through the relevant ex-service associations.

TALK.START.PARA: —With some hope, I address another question to the Minister for Community Services and Health. It will be the first answer I have got, if I get one. Did the Minister provide guidelines to his staff regarding the `standing office instructions' which he referred to in his answer to me on Tuesday, in writing? If not, why not? What written instructions, if any, has the Minister provided to the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) regarding communications to his staff or himself? Will the Minister undertake to table such written communications which he no doubt already has to hand?

—Of course I have not written instructions to those people working in my own office. I have indicated that it is a quite clear practice in my office that any statistical information coming from the HIC must be checked back with the HIC to ensure that that information does not contain any identifying material. And in the particular case in debate, that was done by persons working in my office. In relation to the instructions to the HIC, I have not instructed the HIC on this matter. Clearly, it is bound by the Act. In the light of recent events, I have directed it to ensure that provider numbers are not included in any statistical material provided to my office in the future. The standing instruction, as I have said, from my office was clearly an understanding between me and my staff and was carried out on this occasion.
—I ask a question of the Minister for Social Security: How do present arrangements between Federal and State governments ensure that pensioners are assisted in meeting government charges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Government clearly shares responsibility with the States with respect to fringe benefit assistance. Under this Government, the income limit for the pensioner health benefit card is lifted according to rises in the cost of living. Of course, people who have this card do not have to pay the Medicare levy. The existence of the Medicare system is one of the major benefits to the aged population in Australia. The new policy regarding fringe benefits, which was announced in the last Budget, means that since 1 January this year pensioners have been able to retain fringe benefits for up to three months as long as their income does not rise by more than 25 per cent above the fringe benefits cut-out levels.

ANSWER.PARA: The essential relationship between the Commonwealth and the States is that the States take their lead from the Commonwealth in providing concessions. So eligibility for major concessions at the State level depends on the possession of a pensioner health benefit card, which is issued by Social Security. The States are relying on this card to identify those people who are in need of assistance.

Of course, the actual fringe benefits that are provided vary a great deal in Australia. I think it is very well known in this Parliament that, at one extreme, Queensland provides much less adequate fringe benefits as a State than any other State. I think it would not be unfair to say that no State in the Commonwealth provides more adequate fringe benefits than New South Wales. In two weeks time all retired people over 60 in New South Wales will be entitled to a new package of transport concessions, including half fare travel and $1 excursion tickets for rural pensioners. The real value of concessions and services in New South Wales varies between $500 and $1,000, so it is a very significant part of the real incomes of pensioners in New South Wales. The total cost of concessions in New South Wales is about $500m. Those concessions include reduced council, water, sewerage and electricity charges, rent rebate for pensioners in public housing, ambulance services that are free to anyone on a social security pension, and significant assistance in terms of free drivers licences and reduced vehicle registration charges.

It has been one of the achievements of this Government that we have been able to sustain the real value of pensions at the cost of more than $1m a year. It has been one of the real achievements of this Government that we have been able to ease income test limits and that we have indexed the limit for fringe benefits charges. It has been one of the benefits of this Labor Government that we have protected those who are most vulnerable, and in terms of fringe benefits there is no State in this Commonwealth that has done more to look after pensioners with respect to those real elements of their standard of living than New South Wales. You take your choices. We say that that is one of the great traditions of this Party. It is a tradition maintained here federally, and it is a tradition that has been magnificently maintained within New South Wales.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

QUESTION.PARA: The fact is that there was no written request by me or brief in that sense. What I asked Dr Griffith to supply was an opinion on the matters in issue relating to the communication from the Health Insurance Commission to the office of the Minister, and from his office in turn to the member for Canning, of certain material relating to medical service profiles.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like all members of the House, I am astounded by this new understanding that has dawned upon the Leader of the Opposition. How does the opinion which I tabled in this House yesterday start off? It starts off:

ANSWER.PARA: The matter in issue relates to the communication from the Health Insurance Commission to the office of the Minister for Community Services and Health, and from his office in turn to the Member for Canning of certain material relating to medical services profiles.

Those are the exact words that the Leader of the Opposition has just read out. The Leader of the Opposition has proved himself unbelievably pathetic in the discharge of his duties as the Leader of the Opposition. It is already running. He has not got the numbers. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I should like to draw to the attention of the House the fact that Mollie Cranswick retires next Wednesday. Mollie Cranswick has served the Parliament and around the Parliament for a period of 46 years. She started in 1942 with the Department of Commerce and Agriculture. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

—Indulgence is given.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radio- active substances and to immediately disallow the irradiations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Kent,Ms McHugh,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of ``Food Irradiation'' as there is a disturbing uncertainty regarding the possible health effects of this process on humans. This process has also been shown to reduce the nutritional value and affect taste, colour and texture of food, thus necessitating further unwanted additives.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate a) the ``Food Irradiation'' process by State Governments, and b) the dumping of irradiated food products on Australia, to the detriment of our food producers.

We call on the Government to impose an immediate moratorium on all aspects of ``Food Irradiation'' in Australia. We urge extreme caution in processes involving radiation, where there is evidence indicating possible detrimental health effects.
We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of Cobalt 60, Caesium-137 or other radioac- tive substances.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bans on Smoking
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
1. That we are totally opposed to the Governments discriminatory Anti-Smoking legislation in the workplace bans and on Domestic Airline travel.
2. Note that so called Environmental tobacco smoke has not been proved as a major pollutant either in the workplace or on aircraft.
3. This legislation will discriminate against thirty per cent of the citizens of Australia, and
4. Call upon the Government to lift all bans and not proceed with any discriminatory smoking legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
That the Hawke Federal Government ease deep community concern that it intends supporting Telecom's proposal to charge local telephone calls according to the length of the call;
That the undersigned call on the Hawke Government to indicate immediately that it will not give the approval required to make Telecom's proposal a reality.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:

Any proposals to time local telephone calls gravely concerns all country people. Isolation and communication was the second biggest problem facing rural women according to the `Survey of Rural Women' questionnaire and any attempt at timing local calls will only add to this problem not decrease it.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to: Ensure that Telecom do not proceed with the timing of local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should not be considered any further, and in the event of it coming again before parliament it should be rejected because:
We do not accept the concept of an I.D. card as necessary to control social security fraud or tax evasion,

It would be an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy and our democratic society, in particular because it being required to work, operate a bank account, enter hospital or enter into any transaction,
It would cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on tax payers,
It cannot be guaranteed that the aggregated private information would not be misused for other purposes,
The people of Australia should be fully informed and consulted in a referendum before legislation for any such change with such wide-ranging effect is considered, and
We call upon the Government to cease immediately any endeavour to introduce this invasion upon our lives.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reacting and intrusive piece of Australian legislation yet introduced, and that on all the evidence available, it will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID Card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayer's money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows-
We object to the proposal of Telecom to charge for each three minutes of a local call, as we feel this would disadvantage the elderly and people who are unable to leave their homes.
The telephone is often the only contact relatives can have to check on the safety and well-being of those they care for.

The inordinate time span which elapses between connection to a business premises and speaking, as the caller holds the line or is transferred between departments, would also disadvantage subscribers who can ill afford it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Telecom abandons the proposal to time charge local telephone calls as we believe that the charges Telecom makes at the moment are quite adequate.

PETITION.TITLE: Gymea Bay Post Office, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Post Office at Gymea Bay be closed. The Post Office serves a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our postal requirements, or even to collect registered letters and parcels, cash Pension cheques and transact banking. Many of us are Pensioners and the cost of such travel would be an unnecessary imposition. The nearest Post Office is 2.3 KMs away with no convenient transport.

We maintain that the purpose of the Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer, and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Gymea Bay Post Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Therefore your petitioners request a national referendum on the Australia Card bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Fringe Benefits Tax is an iniquitous and unjust impost which will further damage the Australian economy and further increase costs to employers.
The tax will:
(1) further increase the level of unemployment;
(2) increase the administrative costs and overheads for business and Government;
(3) particularly disadvantage small business and farmers; and
(4) act as a disincentive to those who are the most productive and skilled;
and we the undersigned call upon the Government to immediately repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:
That we, the undersigned, believing that Parliament should investigate:
(1) The anguish caused to the general public in relation to timed local calls
(2) The illogic of timed local calls in regard to general ``pleasantries'' involved in conversation
(3) The public will pay for poor business management, or extension call delays, when calls are channelled through various sources
(4) The trauma that the house-bound and invalids will suffer through the loss of phone contact
(5) The number of suicides that may increase because Life-line calls will be ``out of reach''
(6) The indignity caused to pensioners and lower income groups who are fighting a losing battle against rising costs
(7) Voluntary organisations and honorary office holders on committees will be penalised
(8) The users of facsimile machines and similar services should be the ones to pay for these services

Your petitioners therefore humbly request that the Government give regard to these eight reasons why timed local charge calls should not be introduced and rescind any decision to introduce timed local calls by Telecom Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Personnel Injured in Peacetime
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petitions of the citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that we, the undersigned are totally opposed to the callous treatment of the survivors, widows and next of kin of HMAS Voyager and all other service personnel injured in peacetime.

Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take action to rectify this matter by allowing the Voyager survivors' widows and next of kin to put their case to a jury and by providing compensation to these people.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sale of Violent Videos, Books and Toys of Violence
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The sale of violent videos, books glorifying violence, and toys of violence encourages violence in the community, and has a deleterious effect on the more vulnerable members of the community who are easily influenced.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Ban the sale of violent videos, books and toys of violence, in an effort to put an end to the increasing number of violent crimes committed in this country.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
Time-charging for the business sector is also unfair and unreasonable as any charge increase to business will be borne by consumers in the end.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Reject out of hand any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls and prevent both Australian people and Australian business from being seriously disadvantaged by yet another ludicrous charge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage elderly and disabled people, families and businesses, adding significantly to the cost of living.
Your humble petitioners pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will urge the Government to:
Reject any plans by Telecom Australia to time-charge local telephone calls.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Reject plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.

Reject out of hand any plans by Telecom to time charge local telephone calls and prevent the Australian people from being seriously affected by yet another ludicrous charge.

PETITION.TITLE: Flags Amendment Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the Major Recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to Outlaw Destructive Experiments on Human Embryos
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
Make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
Close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and it's avail- ability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography pedlars are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Hunter Valley respectfully showeth:
That the Government's decision to terminate an existing agreement with N.I.B. Health Funds Limited for the provision of facilities for the receipt and limited processing of Medicare claims will:
Deny ready access to cash reimbursements of Medicare claims.
Deprive citizens of a personalized reliable claims payment service.
Reduce job opportunities in the area.

And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The threat to individual privacy posed by the Hawke Government.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ever since the Australian public was alerted to the great damage that could be done by such a thing as an identity card, and, in particular the Government's proposal for an identification card called the Australia Card, the debate has never really ceased. Personal privacy is still a matter of grave concern in the community. It has now risen to a point where in certain groups there is massive concern. Many members of this House are receiving masses of correspondence and finding that the most populated public meetings they attend are on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We know about the identity card. We know how determined this Government was to proceed with it and we know how arrogant the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) became in telling the public, as it became concerned, that he was not going to listen to what he called its decibel democracy. He was going to impose it; the people fought back; and fortunately the Opposition, technically, was able to defeat the Government. What were we promised at the time? We were promised all sorts of wonderful things such as secure data lines that no one else in the world has. Above all, we were promised absolute security of our personal information in government data banks under the law. We were promised that the law would protect us. We were to be given a keeper of the law, a protector of public privacy. The person nominated for that job was none other than the present Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). He is the protector of public privacy, the person who told us, `Don't you worry about that' when people said, `Can you guarantee my privacy?'. He was the person who was to be charged with that responsibility along with his Department and the Health Insurance Commission (HIC).

Recent events have completely vindicated the Opposition and the public in their concern that the Government cannot guarantee privacy. It is a lot more than a guarantee of privacy because, as the Opposition was at pains to point out to the people at the time, the more information a government has, particularly in sensitive areas such as health-and maybe one's mental condition at some time-the more that sort of sensitive information in the hands of a vindictive government or politician can be used very seriously and with great damage to an individual. It gives to government huge power to deal with its enemies. The Government has an enemy at the moment-an enemy of its own philosophy. The Government decided to give Australians a universal health scheme and it is consuming it. Just a few years ago it was costing 6.9 per cent of the Government's total expenditure; now it is 10.3 per cent.

The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, is desperately trying, along with the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to curtail those costs. The Government has a fair few strategies. It has waiting lists-quite deliberately-to ensure that not too much money can be spent. But that is not enough. The Government is worried now that doctors' fees are rising and it is unable to contain them. It is not the doctors who are being criticised. Letters are flowing to the Minister. People are saying, `Why is it that the scheme you promised me would pay my doctor's bills and medical bills is no longer doing it? I have to pay extra'. There is no question in this Government's mind that it might be its fault that the scheme is no longer adequate. It seeks to blame the doctors. It seeks to follow the Treasurer's dictum, `Nothing is wrong if I can blame it on somebody else'. The reality is that the Government sought to blame the doctors for all the problems from Medicare that are now being visited on the Australian people.

To blame the doctors, the Government needed a strategy. It arrived at quite a simple one. It did not want the Minister to dirty his hands too much. Those opposite said, `We will select an expendable individual from our back bench; one who is not too bright and who will do our bidding. We will send him out into the community to bucket the doctors'. He started doing that with some success but, of course, he was called upon to provide some evidence. The evidence needed was held in the computer records of the Health Insurance Commission. Back in 1973, the Parliament of the day, when it brought in the first Health Insurance Commission legislation was very concerned about public privacy. The politicians of that day recognised the power that would go to the Government if health records were abused. Those politicians passed some laws. Section 130 of the Health Insurance Act very clearly tells the Minister, the Parliament and the Health Insurance Commission that they will not make available:
. . . any information with respect to the affairs of another person acquired by him in the performance of his duties, or in the exercise of his powers or functions . . .
That is simple and straightforward. It says `any information'. There are a few exclusions. `If the Minister certifies' has been amended to say `by instrument in writing'.

There is no doubt, from his answers today, that this Minister never learnt to write. He has not put anything in writing, and there is good reason for that. One lesson he has learnt in his political career is `Do not commit it to writing, you might get caught'. We have that answer today from his non-answers. But he can certify that in the public interest certain information can be provided. He can divulge such information to a prescribed authority. By giving this Caucus committee that was formed for the purpose of denigrating the medical profession a big name like the national price watch network, the Government attempted to imply to the Australian people that that was some form of prescribed authority. Honourable members know it is not, and the Minister admitted to that yesterday.

Of course, there is the opportunity for the Government to produce statistics. Honourable members know what that means. We know that a statistic is a publication of the Government that advises us of the costs of operating the Health Insurance Commission, that advises us as the Australian Bureau of Statistics does. It never has meant and never will mean grubby little notes that contain some numbers being sent out the back door. That is not a statistic. It never was a statistic and never will be a statistic in the legal sense. We know what statistics mean and we know why the Act excluded them. The Government knew that that would not infringe on personal privacy, but just in case it added the rider:
Such statistics will not be published in a manner that enables the identification of an individual patient or an individual practitioner.

The Minister was getting ready to feed his hit man, this rather dull but otherwise willing person who was going to take all the flak. If it went wrong the Minister was going to wash his hands of him, just as he has now washed his hands of his own staff-a most disgraceful act-when they were doing his bidding. He did not want to make much noise about getting the information. The Minister did not choose, as he was legally entitled to do, to say, `I believe the provision of this information is in the public interest and I will so certify in writing'. No, he grabbed one of his staff members-I wonder whether he can remember who; he would not tell us today-and said, `Ring up someone at the HIC to see whether you can get a bit of dirt on a few doctors'. That is what he did.

Having done that, he went through the process of giving that information to the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), who gave it to, amongst others, the Sydney Morning Herald in November. The matter was published on 10 November, which suggests that the Minister's recollection that it might have been in late November is a little wrong. Nevertheless, the Minister wanted to be a little careful about this and it appears-we are not too sure about this because there is nothing in writing-that there was never any formal memo to the HIC to the effect, `I instruct you never to pass to my staff any matter which might, as the Act says, enable the identification of an individual patient'. No, he said `Send us up something', someone in the HIC has hit the computer button, out has come a printout, and it has been passed in that form to the Minister's staff-and it might even have been passed to the Minister. Then it was passed on. It just happened to contain some doctor provider numbers. There is no dispute on either side of the House that doctor provider numbers can be used to identify doctors. They can certainly be used to enable a person to do that. It is amazing that the Minister cannot even tell us what number was used. I suggest that on that printout were both numbers and by the use of those numbers much information could be obtained.

This wonderful opinion of the Solicitor-General, this outrageous document, is based on nothing but a statement of this Minister in the House and a letter posted to him as damage control three months after the information we are debating now was passed to his office-and then only in response to the complaints of the Australian Medical Association. It is interesting that in this outrageous document the Solicitor-General has the temerity, after about five hours consideration, to tell us the material does not identify patients. Let me remind the Solicitor-General that we are not talking about identifying anybody. We are talking, under the law he should have studied, about mechanisms which enable the identification of people. That is forbidden by this law. It is a pity that the Minister is not going to defend himself this afternoon, although I thought he might have had the competence to answer these things at Question Time today. I thought he might have had at least an answer to what one can get with a doctor's provider number--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why doesn't he stand up and say it himself?
-Order! The honourable member for Moreton will cease interjecting and using offensive words.

—The material provided does enable the identification of patients who attended those doctors because one can access the computer records of that doctor if one is an experienced hacker or has a friend within the Department. With that provider number one can access the records of patients, so one is able to gain that information. It is a pity that the Solicitor-General cannot even get his facts right. This Minister and the then Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, who is now gone, were going to be the public protectors of our privacy. Just like her assurances, his are found wanting. Their assurances were that they could give us a system, both mechanically and personally, that would protect the privacy of Australians. Of course, that has not been the case.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a situation where quite deliberately a section of the community has been attacked, a group of doctors browbeaten. It was not done, as we have been told in the past couple of days, to protect a few individual patients who have had to put their hands in their pockets for a little bit more. That did not worry the Minister when he changed the schedule for skin cancer. It did not worry him that he knocked that off the list because his public awareness campaign had increased expenditure. He is quite happy for those people to pay the difference in the fee because he has cut the rebate. He did not worry for months about the cancer sufferers who had to make three trips a week to their physicians and who could not get the full rebate after the third visit. This issue is about imposing on the Australian medical profession the participating doctor scheme that now exists in Canada. It was a softening up campaign and this Government was prepared to use confidential information given to it under the law to attack the medical profession.

This is the worse possible example of a Minister directly involving himself and his staff, and the Minister might like to tell us, if he is entering the debate, as he has his clearance, who will be his Stephen Loosley. He might tell us who he will finger. He might tell us which member of this staff he will go into the box and give evidence against. The Minister conspired to get the doctors and he did exactly what we warned Australia would happen if we made him the protector of its privacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Evidently, from the quietness of the Opposition benches, the mumbling nature of the speech just delivered and the total absence of members from the Government benches, this debate is suitably petering out. Some things still need to be picked up from the speech of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). He has a reputation in this place as a man of some force but he has not made a reputation in this place as a protector of people's privacy. Whatever might be said about him as an advocate in this case, I cannot really imagine anyone worse to be the proposer of this motion. If he were going to be the proposer he might have tried a different set of words.

SPEECH.PARA: As we pointed out yesterday, the question of the Opposition's commitment to privacy matters is highly selective and tends to be ahistorical. In other words, they operate on 24-hour memories. Indeed, the Opposition in this place has made a fetish of taking opportunities, in the absence of a developing policy, to utilise Question Time and other forums of the House persistently to attempt to get the Government to offend the sort of privacy protection we believe is essential for Ministers.

As I pointed out in this House yesterday when speaking in the debate on the censure motion, when I was Special Minister of State-and this has been the experience of others in that portfolio since then-I was the object of persistent questioning on matters such as police investigations, material provided to crime authorities or whatever. Without any notion of due process or of protecting the individual's right to privacy, efforts have been made consistently to get us to expose what no government exposes-that is, details of matters which must remain private until charges are laid. As Ministers, we have been condemned and vilified in this House when we have taken this stand. We have had censure motions moved against us, we have faced endless matters of public importance debates, one after another, and we have sat here determined that Parliament will not be turned into a kangaroo court.

The Opposition comes into this place without clothes on the question of the protection of rights to privacy. The Opposition has not just made efforts to secure from us information that compromises innocent individuals. Over the past few years there have been debates in this Parliament which go to the heart of privacy. These debates have been based on persistent Government efforts to get onto the statute book measures which protect individuals' rights. Just as persistently as we have sought to get these measures on the statute book, the Opposition has opposed them. We had the case of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the last Parliament introducing the Privacy Bill and the Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill, the first such legislation in Australia. This legislation would have applied to virtually all Commonwealth agencies and established information privacy principles, which were rules for agencies to regulate the collection, handling, safe storage, access, correction and disclosure of personal information. It also would have given the Data Protection Agency power to guide agencies in their application of those principles and power to investigate complaints of interference with privacy. Remedies for such interference would have included reports to the Parliament by the powers of the Ombudsman, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Data Protection Agency, which could have recommended compensation.

It is noteworthy, in the context of this debate today, that members of the Opposition chose to oppose this legislation when they had the opportunity to vote on it. The names of individuals who have participated in these debates over the past couple of days stand in the division lists against that legislation. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has given notice that there will be opportunities for them to vote on that privacy legislation again so once again they will be tested. We will see whether their current concern-this 48-hour concern for the protection of people's privacy-will be carried over into support for that legislation. It will require a sea change in the Opposition's attitude if that is to be the case. It is not required of this Government that we should offer any apology to anyone on the question of our willingness to protect the privacy of Australian citizens. A great deal of explanation is required of the Opposition as to why it has been loath to support our efforts to do that in the past. Nor do we need to apologise on the question of a right to privacy in so far as this matter and the debate of the last couple of days are concerned.

The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who corrected his answer in this place of his own volition and not under pressure from the Opposition or anyone else, made it amply clear that he has at all times been motivated by what he believes is a requirement upon himself in giving out this information from the Health Insurance Commission. As he pointed out, a plethora of information proceeds from the Commission into the public domain. He has always regarded himself as under an obligation to protect rights to privacy as far as that information is concerned. He has been assiduous in his balance between what is essential to protect an individual's right to privacy and what is essential to put into the public domain on matters affecting the public purse about which the public is entitled to know. At all times, the Minister operated on the advice of the appropriate authority in his Department. Again I will read into the public record the material handed to the Minister for Community Services and Health by the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard that.
—The honourable member says that he has heard it before, but he will hear it again because it is appropriate that it be quoted in this debate. The second paragraph states:

SPEECH.PARA: Last year the Commission supplied your office with information about the charging behaviour of a sample of different specialist groups and this information was the basis of Mr Gear's public statements. The information supplied to your office did not identify either the doctors or their patients. It was in the form of statistical data which may be released by the Commission where the information does not identify an individual patient or practitioner (Section 130 (5) of the Health Insurance Act refers). This is the section under which statistical information is provided to requesting organisations including the Australian Medical Association.

Therefore, at all times the Minister operated under the instructions conveyed by him and his office on the question of the protection of the privacy of individuals who might be concerned in this matter when statistics were handed out. The Minister was not the only one who protected that privacy.

The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) received some gratuitous abuse from the honourable member for O'Connor during his remarks in this debate. The honourable member for Canning has made himself a consumer advocate without peer in the history of this Parliament. Basically consumer rights have been regarded as rather boring and prosaic in this place. Over the years, very few honourable members have been prepared to pursue consumer rights, but the honourable member has. We have tended to regard that as a matter properly handled by the States and not by the Federal Government. But the honourable member rightly believes that in defending the interests of his constituents across the board, the question of their rights as consumers is one matter that has to be considered and fought for. Despite the fact that he is now the focal point of correspondence from all over the country, detailing many matters including those in the medical area-a raft of complaints from people who have suffered in the pocket or in other ways as a result of shoddy dealings by people they have approached on a professional or business basis or whatever-he has never come into this place or entered any public forum and identified doctors. He has a very fat file of complaints by patients about that very small minority of doctors who overcharge. He has not, at any point, chosen to expose the individuals concerned in public. Therefore, the point made by Opposition members that there is a motive on the part of this side of the House to offend people's privacy is simply not sustained by the record. It is further not sustained by the record when it comes to a consideration of the release of information related to the various documents that are the subject of this debate.

Whatever may be said about the Minister's willingness to correct himself when he said in this House that he honestly believed that the information that had been handed out contained no means whereby a person could be identified, and despite the fact that his endeavour was evidently not successful, none of those documents have produced a situation where an individual doctor has been held up for vilification. Of course, that will not happen. The suggestion has been made that there is justification for a privacy debate, related to this particular issue. But any privacy debate cannot be specific, it must be general. Nobody has been identified specifically. Any possibility that a person's right to privacy may be offended has in fact been pulled back.

The Opposition spokesman for Community Services and Health skated across issues of health policy. He described the campaign by the honourable member for Canning to ensure that the fact that a minority of doctors-and it is a very small minority of doctors-engage in overcharging is exposed as a `grubby' campaign. That was the expression the honourable member for O'Connor used. Right through the discussion of the issues concerned here and the general question of overcharging, both the Minister and the honourable member for Canning have identified that we are dealing with a minority situation.

Does the Opposition believe that the practice of overcharging ought not to be exposed? It is difficult to say whether the Opposition believes that. We have the thrust and vehemence-not in this place lately-of the honourable member for O'Connor on this matter. From the way he has conveyed his views in the various discussions on this matter, apparently he would place himself on the list of those who do not believe that that is the case. However, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is more ambivalent. The Leader of the Opposition was given an opportunity to discuss the matter on yesterday's Today program. When the interviewer, George Negus, tried to get something out of him it was like throttling it slowly out of a plucked chicken. At the last squawk he finally got something out of him. George Negus asked:
Isn't it reasonable to blackguard doctors if they're charging six times the fee?
The Leader of the Opposition replied:
It is reasonable to give legitimate information but is it legitimate to selectively leak information?

The interview continued. Evidently, the Leader of the Opposition, when finally his feet are put to the fire, will accept that if doctors are charging six times the fee or whatever, it is reasonable for the Minister, the honourable member for Canning and anyone else to expose them. That was the motive involved in the exchange of that information. On all occasions it was believed by the Health Insurance Commission, the Minister's office and the Minister himself that the information was legitimate. That is not in doubt. There are absolutely no grounds for the Opposition to bring forward a matter of public importance on the protection of privacy as far as the Minister is concerned in this case or on the general matter of privacy. The Opposition has no record of defending privacy in such cases. Its record is all of offending an individual's rights to privacy and attempting to engage the front bench in doing exactly the same thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourth report of the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report are being circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.
