DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW TELEPHONE EXCHANGE BUILDING, CHARLOTTE STREET, BRISBANE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of new telephone exchange building at Charlotte Street, Brisbane.

The proposed building will provide local customer requirements for the southern sector of the central business district. It will also support a wide variety of telecommunication services and provide equipment and other network facilities throughout the central business district and the State of Queensland. The new building will be medium rise and will contain a basement, ground floor, office and amenities floor, eight telecommunications equipment floors, plant floor and roof plant area with a satellite dish and antenna area. The proposed construction timetable indicates a construction time of approximately 20 months. The limit of cost estimate for construction of the telephone exchange is $20m at July 1987 prices. I thank the Committee for its prompt consideration of this important proposal. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition concurs with the motion. The Public Works Committee has reported on this proposal for a new telephone exchange building in Brisbane, although I note from reading its report that not much detail has been provided as to the work to be undertaken within the building by Telecom Australia. I specifically drew attention to this because a problem arose with the latest major Telecom building in South Australia. In that instance, because Telecom did not finalise its plans on partitioning of the building until construction was well advanced, the ceilings put into it, at a cost of some $30,000 per floor, were not suitable. Lighting, wiring, air-conditioning and fire sprinklers had to be rearranged. We were advised that the cost of that change was in the vicinity of $20,000 for each of the 23 floors of that particular Telecom building, or around $500,000 for the whole building. The community cannot afford such waste and inefficiency, be it by the Government or one of its statutory authorities-in this case, Telecom. I say to this House, as I did when the motion for reference of this work to the Public Works Committee was brought into this House, that Telecom should take note of our concerns because we will be watching the construction costs of this building very closely. We do not want to see a cost blow-out of the nature that occurred in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF STATE HEAD OFFICE, AUSTRALIA POST, REDFERN, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of State Head Office, Australia Post, Prince Alfred Park Centre, 219-241 Cleveland Street, Redfern, New South Wales.

The proposal to reconstruct the Prince Alfred Park Centre, the former Redfern Mail Exchange, by demolishing the existing building down to the top of the first floor slab and constructing a five-storey office block, will provide, in the reconstructed premises, accommodation for the State head office administration, a postal training school, an electronic mail acceptance centre, a regional post office, an engineering workshop, and a car park. The building will have a gross floor area of 47,000 square metres and will meet the needs of Australia Post until the year 2000. Relocating the New South Wales head office to Prince Alfred Park is the most economic means of satisfying administrative accommodation needs. One of the recommendations contained in the report of the Public Works Committee is that the fit-out of the accommodation, details of which have yet to be finalised, should be referred back to the Committee for examination when Australia Post determines its requirements. Officers of my Department are currently working with Australia Post to that end. This element of the proposal will be referred back to the Committee in due course.

The limited cost of the proposed work is $62m at September 1987 prices. I should like to thank the Public Works Committee for its prompt consideration of this important proposal. If the House agrees to support the motion, planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendation of the Committee. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose this motion. This proposal will be the final stage of the termination of what, unfortunately, was one of the great white elephants undertaken by Australia Post. Right from the start, the building of the Redfern Mail Exchange was a disaster. This proposal involves knocking it down, all bar the bottom floor, and rebuilding it. Again, I think it is unfortunate that this Parliament is confronted with proposals which I consider in the circumstances to be a waste of money. Certainly, the original decision to spend money on what turned out to be an industrial relations disaster was a failure.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of points should be made. Apparently the Public Works Committee did look at proposals for the relocation of the staff from the General Post Office to alternative locations. The Committee suggested that there is not another single location available which would suit Australia Post, at a cost comparable with the cost of this proposal. I do not have the details of the alternatives that the Committee considered but that does surprise me a little, although I accept the Committee's decision.

The total cost of this proposal is not $62m, as suggested by the Minister. That is the building cost only. The total cost is substantially more. The $62m does not take account of $8m for professional fees, nor does it take account of the fit-out cost, which has been estimated by the Public Works Committee to be in the vicinity of $12m. I am glad that the Minister is to refer the fit-out works to the Public Works Committee for further review. It is very important that the fit-out be in accordance with the design of the building. I should not like to see a repetition of the South Australian Telecom building, where a fit-out decision was not made until it was too late, and substantial parts of the building had to be removed to enable the fit-out to proceed as finally determined.

My final point is that the Opposition wishes Australia Post well in this undertaking. As I said at the start, the Redfern Mail Exchange has been a disastrous white elephant. I hope, with this proposal, that the money will be well spent, and will provide a building that will serve Australia Post and the Australian community well.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: RELOCATION OF ALBION EXPLOSIVES FACTORY TO MULWALA, NEW SOUTH WALES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Relocation of Albion Explosives Factory to Mulwala, New South Wales.

The proposed work will provide a new production facility at the Mulwala Explosives Factory to enable the transfer of production capabilities from the Albion Explosives Factory in Deer Park, Melbourne. Arising out of the Review of Explosives Factories, Australia, the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) announced, in December 1985, the decision to close the Albion factory. For some years the factory had suffered from the pressures of urbanisation, and its location in a residential area was no longer appropriate. The important site of 496 hectares made available by this proposal will be released for development. A committee, chaired by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who is in the House, has been convened to advise on the future use of the site. The committee is currently seeking public comments on several options for public use of this site, which, as I said, is a very important site to the local communities in the western suburbs of the great city of Melbourne.

The transfer of strategically important high explosives and gun propellant production to Mulwala has significant cost-saving benefits. During peacetime, production facilities operate well below maximum capacity, creating operating difficulties and extra costs. Co-location of production facilities will reduce these effects. The new facilities will be constructed on a new site adjacent to the existing facilities at Mulwala within the factory's existing boundaries. There is a requirement to acquire some properties, totalling 340 hectares, to the north of the factory to provide a safety buffer zone. Negotiations are currently proceeding with the owners, and the majority of the acquired land will be available for lease back. A draft environmental impact statement for the Albion and Mulwala sites has been prepared. Pertinent findings are being incorporated in the design of the new facilities.

The proposed work involves about 60 buildings and facilities and includes: construction of buildings to house processes and service plant used to manufacture RDX-a military explosive-TNT and gun propellant products; construction of explosives storage buildings; construction of laboratory, administrative and support buildings; construction of roads and cleanways; construction of protective earthwork mounds around the production and storage buildings; construction of pits, labyrinths, evaporation ponds and burning grounds for waste collection and disposal; provision of water supply and reticulation; provision of an electrical distribution system; construction of steam raising plant and a reticulation system; decontamination, transfer and reinstallation of process plant, service plant and piping systems from Albion to Mulwala and installation of new processing plant and piping systems at Mulwala to be purchased by the Department of Defence.

I inform the House that the cost of the proposed works has been estimated at $78.4m at November 1987 prices and this estimate of cost comprises $40.5m for new buildings and infrastructure, $21.8m for reinstallation of machinery and plant from Albion, and $16.1m for the purchase of new machinery and plant. No expenditure is anticipated this financial year. Subject to parliamentary approval, it is intended that the initial tenders will be invited in June 1988, and that construction will commence in July 1988 and be completed some four years later by the end of 1992. Design and documentation will be undertaken by private consultants and also in-house by my Department's construction group; that is, they will share the work. During construction the on-site work force is expected to peak at 200 by 1990. I table selected plans of the proposed work and I commend this motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the Government's decision to close the Albion Explosives Factory, the Opposition will certainly support this reference to the Joint Committee on Public Works. My colleague the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) will speak after me as the proposed works will be in his electorate. I would like to make some short but general comments about this proposal and related proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has made a number of decisions in relation to Defence Force production facilities. Only recently I was contacted by some farmers expressing concern that they had been contacted by the Department of Defence with a questionnaire about a proposal from the Department of Defence to manufacture some sort of equipment to frighten birds. Not only did the farmers object to having to fill out this very lengthy survey but also they quite rightly asked, `Why on earth is the Defence Department getting into competition with the private sector by producing equipment to frighten birds in primary industry areas?'. I have subsequently asked the Government for more information.

I understand that the proposal was to use excess capacity in one of the Government's Defence Force production facilities. This raises a number of real concerns in my mind, and those of Opposition members, and if any government factory is to manufacture what is called Birdfrite, and if it is to go into commercial production, we would like to know on what basis that is justified. For example, the statement that it is just to use excess capacity in the plant certainly does not satisfy me. We would like to know what the capital cost involved in establishing the manufacture of this Birdfrite would be and what the expected annual return would be after deducting all the costs, including the capital costs. There is a great deal of information we would like from the Government before we are prepared to support further expansion of Defence Force production facilities.

Given the Government's decision to close the Albion factory, we understand there is a need to establish a new plant for production of ammunition and other explosives, and the honourable member for Farrer is certainly very pleased that the plant will be established in his area. We look forward to receiving the Public Works Committee report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a great interest in this project as chairman of the committee which has been appointed, through the participation of the State Government and the Federal Government, to work out proposals for the development of the Albion land. The committee has been operating for over 12 months and in that time has consulted widely with the community and has produced a number of plans, through the use of two consultants, including four specific plans which are now being put out to the community of the west of Melbourne for its consideration. We are awaiting the results of those inquiries before putting specific proposals for the many possible projects that can be taken up in that area both to the State and Federal governments and to the City of Sunshine for adoption.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not very often that land of this size becomes available suddenly in the middle of a residential area surrounded primarily by homes. It provides an opportunity for the creation of a large number of community facilities. I take this opportunity to thank some of the people who have been involved with the committee in the planning stages; in particular Mr Mark Bartley, who is the project officer from the State Department of Planning and Environment, and Carole Fabian from my office. I also thank the people involved in the community consultation committee which was established to make sure that the community had an input into these determinations, and in particular the chairpersons of the committee, Colin Thorpe and Renis Witham. I look forward to the community making its contribution and I look forward to the Federal Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) coming down to look at the final plans when they have been developed and to look at the enormous potential of the area. Once again I thank the Government for the faith it has placed in me by appointing me chairman of the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the reference to the Joint Committee on Public Works of the relocation of the Albion Explosives Factory to Mulwala in New South Wales and I support the comments made by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter). I highlight to the House one aspect of the comments made by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), which were most noteworthy. As background information, I inform the House that in the 1970s when I first came into State Parliament, the word `decentralisation' was very much to the fore. But more recently, in the 1980s, in parties on both sides of the fence and at State and Federal level, decentralisation has been pushed to one side as we have entered a period of harsher economic times.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have in this exciting proposal is a classic demonstration of the advantage of decentralisation. It is mainstream decentralisation, with the Federal Government moving to relocate this important high explosives and gun propellant production from in effect the suburbs of Melbourne to Mulwala, opposite the town of Yarrawonga on the Murray River in my electorate of Farrer. The really good news associated with this exciting proposal is the fact that, to quote the Minister, the move to Mulwala has significant cost saving benefits to the Government and the nation as a whole. So not only are we decentralising this factory; we are also saving money in the process of doing it.

I welcome the reference to the Public Works Committee of a proposed work which will inject some $78.4m in November 1987 prices into the town of Mulwala, which is in any event a bustling town strategically located on the Murray River. That will break down into some $40.5m for new buildings and infrastructure, $21.8m for reinstallation of machinery and plant transferred from Melbourne to the new Mulwala site, and $16.1m for the purchase of new machinery and plant to make it one of the largest and most efficient inland factories dealing with propellants, explosives and other defence capability matters.

I would like to highlight to the Minister, and more particularly to his Department and advisers, that there has been a fraction of difficulty associated with acquisitions on the north side which are still being finalised and also associated with the sale by the Department, in association with the Mulwala factory, of a number of houses involving 20 or more families on the southern side of the factory. I am pleased to say that officers of the Department have agreed to come to Mulwala on Thursday, 3 March, in the afternoon, to iron out some of the complexities which have arisen, to reduce the lines of communication, and hopefully provide a firm basis on which to go forward. They will be coming from the regional office of the Department in Sydney to Mulwala to facilitate that. I believe that the acquisition will not be held up unduly. It involves a large package of land, some 340 hectares to the north of the factory site. I hope that a fair and just arrangement will be made to facilitate that acquisition and to protect the rights of the vendors. Hopefully, that will allow this exciting project to proceed and proceed quickly, thus boosting employment on a permanent basis at Yarrawonga-Mulwala. In any event, employment will peak at 200 in the construction phase of this new and expanded inland facility which will take place after due and proper deliber- ations of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and after recommendations are made in its favour.

My area, in many ways, had a legacy from World War II. A number of airports were constructed during the war for pilot training. They were constructed at places such as Tocumwal and many other places along the river. An explosives factory was placed at Mulwala in that same period. Governments of all persuasions have kept the nucleus of that explosives factory going over many decades when inquiries were made and consideration was given to closing down Mulwala completely and focusing just on St Marys in Sydney and Albion in Melbourne. For once the right decisions have been made by the Federal Government in particular. The right decision is to proceed with some classic, positive, efficient and effective decentralisation by not only retaining the nucleus of that existing Mulwala facility but also boosting it greatly with nearly $80m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Opposition indicated, it certainly has no objection to the matter-the relocation of the Albion explosives factory to Mulwala-being referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. If the factory is relocated to the electorate of the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) it will be in the very best of hands. PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was speaking on the Parliamentary Precincts Bill which establishes for the first time in the history of the Australian Commonwealth a legal definition of the parliamentary precincts. I was concluding my remarks, in relation to the new Parliament House and the move from this Parliament House to the new Parliament House, saying that I regretted the fact that the Government had decided not to take the Speaker's chair from this place and put it in the new Parliament House. I said that I saw great merit in maintaining the continuity of our parliamentary tradition, and in recognition of the development of our parliamentary system the Speaker's chair would provide a unique link to the Westminster tradition. I was referring to the support I had for the suggestion to move the chair to the new Parliament House by three former Clerks of this House of Representatives, Messrs Norman Parkes, John Pettifer and Douglas Blake. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) at that stage interjected saying they were `overstepping their mark'. I thought it was an extraordinary interjection for the honourable member for Throsby to make. It suggested that private citizens should not have the right to petition this Parliament, which these three former Clerks had done. If that is the sort of government that this Hawke Ministry wants to run, where private individuals lose even their rights to petition the Parliament, it is a sorry day. It is part of the concern that I have that--

—Order! I do not mind a wide-ranging debate but the honourable member for Barker should relate the matters that he is discussing to the matter before us which is to define the precincts of the Parliament. No doubt he might be getting to the fact that the chair should be within the precincts but he should relate it to the matter before us.
—Certainly this Bill relates to the move up the hill and I suggest--
—We are not taking the chair with us.

—The Minister for Administrative Services, who is at the table, says again that we are not taking the chair. We rather hoped that the Government would review its decision. I understand that the plans for the new Parliament House did provide for the Speaker's chair to be an option for placement in the new Parliament House. Given the Minister's reiteration of the Government's decision not to take the chair, I condemn the Government for its failure to acknowledge the value, albeit symbolic--

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I have to raise a point of order. I do not want to take up the honourable member's time but this is a reflection on the Joint Standing Committee. It was its decision and not the Government's decision.

—Order! The honourable member for Barker might relate his remarks specifically to the matter before the House. The decision made by the Joint Standing Committee on the Speaker's chair does not fall within the purview of the matter before the House at present.

—The Minister, if he likes, can debate the issue by way of a point of order. It is quite clear that the decision has been made by the Government, not the Joint Standing Committee. I will conclude my remarks on this matter by saying that the Government should be condemned for its failure to acknowledge the value, albeit the symbolic value, of our very famous Speaker's chair. I am disgusted that the Government has determined that it should be left here to rot.

SPEECH.PARA: That leads me to another matter of concern, that is, the future use of this Parliament House once we have made the move up the hill. As I understand it, the Government set up some sort of interdepartmental committee (IDC) to consider the future use of this Parliament House. But we have not been given any information as to the progress of its deliberations, if any. I ask the Minister for Administrative Services, who is at the table: Has the IDC met; has it made some recommendations; if so, what are they; and when will the Government make a determination on this issue?

The public has enormous interest in the future of this building. In fact, the question that I get more than any other from visitors to this building is: `What are they going to do with the place when you move?'. I have found that there is general support for the establishment of a political-constitutional museum. But I would like to know what all the options are; whether they are being considered by the Government; and when we will know what the options are and what the Government's proposal is.

At the moment the Government has left too many loose ends regarding the move up the hill. I imagine that the ongoing maintenance and security costs of this building will be enormous, even when we have left it. In order to avoid wasteful expenditure, we should be considering now the future of this building and starting to implement the planning for its alternative use. It is no good in a year's time, once we are established up on the hill, then starting to plan for the future of this building. Action needs to be taken now. With the reservations that I outlined before lunch in relation to one particular clause of this legislation, the Opposition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before making some comments on the details of the Parliamentary Precincts Bill 1988, I wish to respond to a few of the comments that were made by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) on the future of this building and the future of the Speaker's chair which, of course, has been a feature of this chamber since this Parliament House was opened in 1927. I was totally astounded by the honourable member's comment that the Speaker's chair will be left in this chamber to rot. I think the honourable member has lost touch with what is being proposed for this building. It is not intended that all of the doors and the windows will be pulled out, with the chair being left to wither away and be eaten by insects and bugs over the next few years. This chamber will be preserved for generations to come.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite, to be fair to them, have argued consistently that the Speaker's chair should go into the new Parliament House. The problem with that argument is: what would happen to this chamber if the Speaker's chair were removed? Would all of the benches be kept? What would happen to the table around which all of the important debates have occurred and from which Prime Ministers Curtin and Menzies have addressed this chamber? What would be the result if the single piece of furniture which dominates this chamber were removed? Of course, if the Speaker's chair were transferred from this chamber to the new Parliament House, members of the Opposition would demand that a replica chair be produced, at enormous cost.

I am very proud that the Parliament decided that an Australian-made Speaker's chair be constructed from Australian timbers. I believe that that chair will become one of the features of the new Parliament House and the new House of Representatives chamber. As I say, a lot of history has occurred in this chamber. I think it would be a desecration of this chamber if the original Speaker's chair, which has been used for 61 years, were transferred from the chamber where all of the action has taken place.

Turning to the details of the legislation before us, I was very interested to read that in fact in 1927 the Federal Parliament passed an Act of Parliament called the Seat of Government (Administration) Act which vested in the Federal Capital Commission all Commonwealth land in the Australian Capital Territory, with the exception of Parliament House and the surrounding areas. In fact, on 9 May 1927, after the then Duke of York performed the official opening of this building by turning the key in the front door of this building, he handed over the keys to this building to the then Speaker of the House of Representatives and the then President of the Senate. This was a symbolic handing over by the Executive to the Parliament's representatives of title to this building. The problem has been that up until now no Act has set out the precise area which the executive government has handed over to the Parliament. As previous speakers have mentioned, there has been debate about whether the Parliament's control extends to verandas and roads.

It is very important, in terms of the tradition which we have inherited from Westminster, that the Speaker and the President, as the representatives of the Parliament, have exclusive jurisdiction and control within the Houses of Parliament. This ensures that Parliament can conduct its business without any interference or any attempt by outside forces to exert influence on members and senators as they carry out their duties.
In 1969 the Joint Select Committee on the New and Permanent Parliament House brought down a report from which I would like to quote. The report states:
Down through the years it has been an embarrassment to the Parliament to lack control or be unsure of the extent of its control over the area of land surrounding the building . . .
Further, the report states:
It recommends further that the desirability of having this power incorporated in a statute be considered at an early date.
Given that that was 1969, it is a bit disappointing that it has taken so long for such legislation to come before this chamber.

In 1985, the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, of which I am a member, recommended to the Parliament that the precincts of the new Parliament House be enshrined in legislation so that the extent of the Parliament House could be made very clear. The Bill before the House defines the parliamentary precincts as all land and buildings within a circular boundary drawn from the outer edge of the retaining wall which extends right around the new Parliament House. The Bill places management and control of the precincts in the hands of the Presiding Officers, the Speaker and the President.

Of course, the responsibilities and powers of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate have been the subject of much debate over the years. In fact, in 1931 the then Prime Minister of Australia, James Scullin, made the following comments during a debate in this chamber:

Mr Speaker's power, however, extends beyond this chamber . . . Under the ordinary law and practice which clothes all presiding officers with certain powers . . . the presiding officer of this House has control over the precincts of the chamber, and over this building, except that portion of it which is the Senate's, and that is controlled by the President of the Senate. Mr Speaker has control over the officers-
who work in the building-
and the offices of this House-
they, as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, can be quite small at times-
Who has control over the accommodation provided and over the conduct of persons passing in and out? No one but Mr Speaker . . .
That was the view of the then Prime Minister of Australia, James Scullin. Of course, that speech was made in this chamber, at that table and with that Speaker's chair dominating the surroundings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not in the chair at the time.

—Thank you for clarifying that, Mr Deputy Speaker. The police forces which are responsible for enforcing the laws within the Australian Capital Territory can be given certain powers by the Presiding Officers within Parliament House. The police have no power to enter the precincts of Parliament without the consent of the Speaker or the President of the Senate, and no power to arrest or carry out any other actions without the consent of the Presiding Officers.

SPEECH.PARA: In today's times, when there is always the threat of violence or terrorism, parliament must have procedures whereby, if an emergency arises, the Parliament can speedily authorise the police or other responsible people to take action to prevent violence or to prevent some serious disturbance from getting out of hand. I know that the staff of the office of the Serjeant-at-Arms and the Usher of the Black Rod always ensure that those procedures are ready if they ever have to be used.

On many occasions the Parliament is made aware of people's views on controversial issues by demonstrations, large and small, outside the front of this building. Of course, we believe that all Australians should have the right to express their opinions if they do so in a non-violent manner. The right given to all Australians to express their opinions outside the front of this building is very rarely abused. I am always very proud of the fact that Australians can express their opinions. Even when tens of thousands are participating in a demonstration or rally outside the front of this building, it is very rare that any action has to be taken-perhaps because a few individuals are not prepared to maintain a non-violent demonstration.

In the three years during which I have been a member of this House I can recall only two instances in which people have disrupted the proceedings of the Parliament. The first instance was when a number of individuals were jumping up and shouting slogans during Question Time one day. Those people were removed very speedily by the attendants. The second famous occasion, Mr Deputy Speaker, which I am sure you will remember, was when a gentleman jumped from the public gallery above us into the chamber, narrowly missing the current Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), and the gentleman was escorted from the chamber after being detained for a certain period. It is very important that we realise that there is always a risk in allowing the public easy access to any parliament house, because unfortunately, in any community, there is always the danger that one individual or a number could take some action which could harm a member of this Parliament or some of the staff who work in this building.

I understand that during the period of the previous Government, when the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, had carriage of some of the decisions that were being made for the new Parliament House, it was suggested that bullet-proof glass should be installed between the public galleries in the new Parliament House and the chambers. I am very pleased to say that that proposal was rejected-I understand by the then members of the Joint Standing Committee on the new Parliament House. I think it would have been very much to be regretted if the Parliament had installed bullet-proof glass separating the public from the chambers. It certainly would not have done anything to enhance the spirit of debate within the chambers for members and senators to know that they were surrounded by bullet-proof glass.

In addition, the then Government sought to institute a system whereby ordinary backbenchers, from both sides of the Parliament, would need special permission to enter the ministerial wing of the new building. I understand that at one stage two booths were to be erected at the points at which members of parliament would need to seek entry into the ministerial wing. Again, I am very pleased to see that under the current arrangements, this Government is not intending to require a special passes system to control the access of members of parliament and perhaps prevent them from visiting Ministers and exercising their duties. Of course, that also means that members of the Press and staff in this building do not have to go through such unnecessary security provisions simply to enter the ministerial wing.

The public will still need to go through metal detection apparatus, and I think there is to be also some magnetic measurement machine. That will ensure that people who seek to carry knives or guns will be detected by the ever-vigilant Parliament House staff. It is a healthy sign of a democracy that elected representatives can carry out their duties without the need to be escorted everywhere by armed guards. The fact that our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), when travelling around our country, do so with the very minimum amount of protection says a lot about Australia and the fact that we have a healthy democracy.

I mention in passing that this does not apply only to the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. The Premier of New South Wales caught a train last Tuesday, I understand, from Central to Gosford, just outside my electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —A man of the people.
—A man of the people, as the honourable member suggests. The fact that the Premier of a State can board a train at Central and travel on an ordinary suburban network just goes to show--

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I do not think it is unreasonable for me to request that you rule on the relevance of the movements of the Premier in New South Wales-which is a long way from the Parliamentary Triangle in Canberra.
—The honourable member was using that as an illustration. I am sure that he will get back to the substance of the motion before the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I understand that the Premier was mobbed by people everywhere he went, as well. The Bill also permits other buildings outside the precincts to have the same status as Parliament House itself when being used for parliamentary purposes. I expect that, in addition, there will be some debate as to whether this provisional Parliament House, the old one, will be defined as part of the parliamentary precincts, so that the Presiding Officers can maintain some control or management of this building. I am sure that that is a debate which will continue for some months to come. I know that Mr Simon Townsend has circulated to all members of this House a proposal suggesting that the old Parliament House should be used in a way which would not only help to create a new tourist attraction for Canberra but also incorporate a large number of imaginative, state of the art displays, which would be educational for the many school children who visit Canberra to seek to gain an understanding of the processes of government and would be very enjoyable for anyone who wished to tour the building. I would not be surprised if the executive government and the Presiding Officers received proposals from other individuals. I hope that the Government, when it makes a decision on the future of this building, will ensure that it will allow the people of Australia to appreciate the great history which is associated with this building.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the legislation before the House. As I stated earlier, it is important that the Parliament know the geographical limits of this building. As an aside on that point, during the Fraser years there was a proposal to establish a bomb shelter of some type in the new Parliament House. While the Bill outlines the boundary of the proposed precincts of Parliament House, nowhere in the Bill can I find how deep the precincts are meant to go. If Prime Minister Fraser's proposal to build a bomb shelter had gone ahead, I would have been intrigued to know whether it would have been included within the precincts of the Parliament. But given the fact that Prime Minister Hawke cancelled the former Prime Minister's bomb shelter proposal, I suppose that we shall never know the answer to that question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Behind the back of the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) I often say very nice things about him, his capacity to discuss issues before the Parliament and the intelligent contributions he makes. As I listened to his speech today I thought how well he had researched much of the same material that I had seen on the matter before us. With his concluding remarks and the occasional diversion he allowed to enter into the debate, I must say that he showed a surprising capacity for burrowing deep into political issues that may be able to be raised. I was fascinated by his casual reference to bomb shelters, just dropping the word `Fraser' in relation to that. I noticed that when it came to discussing the safety of former Prime Ministers, he managed to introduce some elements that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, suggested were merely by way of example. No doubt that was a very appropriate ruling in all the circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member mused about the safety with which the Premier of New South Wales was able to travel by train to the honourable member's electorate I thought, in the context of the election campaign that is taking place at the moment in that State and the Premier's popularity and that of his Government, that it says a great deal about the forbearance of the people of New South Wales that the Premier can move so freely. I suspect that it is because the people know that they will have the opportunity shortly at the ballot box to deal with these matters justly and appropriately. I am sure that by that time, rather than being dispensed with by actions of violence, he will be dispensed with in a much more quiet and appropriate way in the democracy that we enjoy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member is coming back to the Bill, I am sure.

—I am. I value the comments of the honourable member for Dobell because, in relation to a Bill which I do not think commends itself in terms of having a great deal of detail for discussion, he has given me the opportunity to respond to some very specific issues. The Parliamentary Precincts Bill has been sought by those who are interested in the future of the Parliament and the maintenance of the privileges of the Parliament. In a bipartisan way, I commend the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) and the Government for the introduction of this Bill. The purpose of the Bill is given in a quite straightforward way in the outline:

SPEECH.PARA: In November 1985 the Joint Standing Committee (JSC) on the New Parliament House presented a Report relating to the precincts of the New Parliament House and the Parliamentary Zone.

The Parliamentary Precincts Bill 1988 reflects the Government's acceptance of the substance of the major recommendations of the JSC Report and the outcome of discussions between the Government and the Presiding Officers over the form of legislation concerning the precincts.
It says as to its purpose:
define the Parliamentary precincts; and confer management and control over the Precincts on the Presiding Officers.
As we would normally expect, we are told:
There are no major additional costs which will result from the provisions of this Bill.

That is in the financial impact statement, which is necessary for inclusion with legislation these days. One wonders how one can talk in a relevant way about this legislation. The honourable member for Dobell showed us the way in which that can be done and the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) no doubt is going to follow. If he has also used the same research materials we may all be accused of tedious repetition. I want to make the point, and I think it has been made on several occasions before, that over time there has been a great deal of emphasis on the importance of the Parliament having control of its own precincts. In a slightly different way from the honourable members who have preceded me, I want to give reasons why this is so necessary. It was not raised for the first time in 1985 by the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House. As has been revealed, this matter was commented on as early as the time when the provisional parliament building was opened. We have before us a report of the Joint Select Committee on the New and Permanent House of April 1969, which brought this matter under discussion. The matter that was quoted previously states:
Down through the years it has been an embarrassment to the Parliament to lack control or be unsure of the extent of its control over the area of land surrounding the building.
That report brings out very clearly the issues that were seen to be involved. In paragraph 54 of that report the issues are clearly raised:

At present various Commonwealth Departments are concerned with aspects of the Parliamentary area and several statutes have application to it . . . correspondence has flowed . . . in the matters of traffic control, parking facilities, police activities, control of demonstration, public access to the building, roadway design . . .

This prompted many distinguished Australians to comment on the matter. One of them was Professor Crisp, who said that a statute should reserve to the Parliament `the ultimate disposal of the present Parliament House structure and those of the Nos 1 and 2 Secretariats'-I assume they are the buildings that adjoin the Parliament and the parliamentary zone-and he continued:

and all decisions regarding structures or parking areas to be erected in these Capital and Camp Hill areas. It should thus, in keeping with the interests and dignity of Parliament, preserve these areas from ever again being subject to purely Executive decisions or use-planning and from invasion by ring-roads or structures extraneous to Parliament's own functions and purposes.
He further said:
I believe that the present Parliament owes it to all its successors and to the people of Australia down the centuries to make this provision.

Another very distinguished academic, Professor Geoffrey Sawer, Professor of Law at the Australian National University, in an article published in the Canberra Times in June 1966, referred to the legal title of Parliament House and its surroundings and suggested that consideration should be given to legislation which would make Parliament a corporation for the purpose of owning property and of vesting in it the legislative buildings for the time being and a specified area around those buildings so that Parliament would have undoubted control over such matters as security, parking and access generally as well as management and the use of the buildings. That matter was again picked up in a report in the following year, again by the Joint Select Committee on the New and Permanent Parliament House. In paragraph 407 under the heading `Parliamentary Grounds and Precincts' that Committee commented on the same matter:

It is believed that Parliament's authority over the area it at present regards as its property may rest on doubtful ground. This should certainly not be the case in a new building in which there should be a written specification of the exact area that is being appropriated for Parliament's use, and formal title to it should be placed beyond doubt.

That raises the question which has been obliquely referred to and which this Bill leaves somewhat in doubt. The honourable member for Dobell commented on this and perhaps the Minister would care to clarify it, as I would value his comments on the matter. It says:
In particular, the position of the Executive block needs to be carefully delineated and any unusual situations arising from occupancy of a roadway, etc., need to be clearly covered.
Your Committee would reiterate its views and recommendations relating to control over the Parliamentary grounds and precincts made in its report of April 1969 . . .

So as early as 1970 this question, which I know has been a thorny one, about the way the Executive area might be separately delineated in the new Parliament House was clearly in the minds of members addressing this subject and is a matter on which this Bill comments, but it appears to suggest that the matter still has to be resolved.

I noticed also in the important report to which the Minister referred of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, Precincts of the New Parliament House and Parliamentary Zone of 25 November 1985, some very clear recommendations about the way this legislation should be drafted. I will comment on those matters in a moment. The Committee did serve to emphasise in a very clear way the three major defects it saw in the present situation. According to the Committee's report these were:

although the Houses have the undoubted power to take a person into custody and to commit a person to prison, and consequently to expel a person from the precincts, there is no clear legal obligation upon the police to carry out the orders of the Presiding Officers . . .

That is one of the very clear defects that have existed to this time although obviously co-operative arrangements have been in place such that I have not heard of or am not aware of this matter being an important issue. I have read from time to time that people have been taken into custody. I have not read of any failure to carry out the orders of the Presiding Officers when those matters have arisen, but clearly the question ought to be one that is beyond doubt. That is why this legislation is before us. The second defect identified by the Committee is:

although persons may be prosecuted for criminal offences committed in the precincts, the Crown has the usual discretion as to prosecution of such offences, and is under no clear legal obligation to prosecute offences at the direction of the Presiding Officers . . .

That is why this legislation has in mind that there should be capacity for prosecution, although under clause 10 of the Bill this matter is still left for arrangement between the Presiding Officers and the Director of Public Prosecutions. Presumably they will be able to come to sensible arrangements, and the Bill authorises such arrangements. Clearly, if they cannot reach agreement there will not be any arrangements. So the Bill does not clarify that matter or resolve this question. If no arrangement is made no clear legal obligation to prosecute offences at the direction of the Presiding Officers has been created. The third defect stated in the report is:

although there is no doubt that the ordinary law applies in the precincts according to its tenor, there appears to be some doubt, whether well-founded or not, about particular criminal offences in their application to Parliament House.

With the roads within the precincts as they are to be defined and having divided the Parliament from some of the grounds that are an important part of this building-the gardens and the Senate and House of Representatives-clearly the question of what road traffic laws apply is an important one. Questions of civil liability in the event that accidents occur could well be raised. These matters need to be addressed. Presumably this legislation clarifies those matters to the point of making sure that the appropriate laws of the Australian Capital Territory will not be inhibited in enabling those matters properly to be resolved.

I want to raise very clearly this question of the Executive. As can be seen from page 6 of the report before us, the area of the precincts was clearly in the minds of the Presiding Officers and the Committee when they looked at this question. Paragraph 10 of the report has this to say:

The location of the Executive area within the design of the new Parliament House and its proximity to part of the Parliamentary Library and other parliamentary areas may affect the possibility of the Executive area being divorced from the parliamentary areas and parliamentary precincts.

In other words, it was making very clearly the point that the areas above the Executive wing are occupied by the Library, as I understand it, and some of the other parliamentary offices, and for that reason one could not excise the Executive area on a plan. We would have to have it in the form of a strata title in much the same way as one does in relation to residential buildings if that were to occur. Obviously that meant one could not reasonably have two separate areas in the same building. I appreciate the comment by the Minister, quietly as it was, and in no way was it an improper intervention, that that was not the Government's intention. I accept that but it does mean that clarification is needed in relation to clause 6 of the Bill, subclause (3) of which says:

In respect of the Ministerial Wing in Parliament House, the powers and functions given to the Presiding Officers by subsections (1) and (2) are subject to any limitations and conditions agreed between the Presiding Officers and the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to agree to it.
—Those matters are already the subject of an agreement?
—No. They have to reach an agreement, and if no agreement is reached, by inference, they would have the power over the Executive wing.
—I am glad the Minister said that, because that was my interpretation of the clause as well.
—Perhaps the Minister will clarify it later.
—I welcome the Minister's intervention that if no agreement is reached then the Executive will be subject to clauses 6 (1) and (2), which are:

SPEECH.PARA: 6. (1) The precincts are under the control and management of the Presiding Officers.
(2) The Presiding Officers may, subject to any order of either House, take any action they consider necessary for the control and management of the precincts.

In the few moments left, I want to raise also a matter brought up for discussion by the honourable member for Dobell. It was an interesting matter and he brought, to my knowledge, information to Parliament that I had not heard given to us before. It suggested how this thorny question of the way in which access to the ministerial wing in Parliament House might be achieved. I welcome his statement that members will be free to approach Ministers' offices not necessarily by purview of the telephone but to walk down the corridor, knock on the door and walk in, as I do at the moment, and seek an appointment. If the Minister happens to be free we can just pop in and say good day to him as we would to any other member-in the openness that the honourable member believes is appropriate in our society. I for one would deem it most inappropriate that the privilege be denied me as a member of parliament, working as I do on behalf of my constituents. I would welcome the Minister clarifying, as I am sure he will when he speaks later to close this debate, that there will be no additional security arrangements through which members of parliament and others who ordinarily pass the security system will have to pass to identify themselves and be vetted to see whether they are allowed to approach those august wings that members of the Executive will no doubt occupy-be it members on this side of the House or members presently occupying those offices.

I also wanted briefly to pick up the other political point made by the honourable member for Dobell. That was the prospect raised at one time of providing a more secure presence for members in the chamber. I know from time to time this question has been raised. The level of interest in it subsides when there have not been any incidents likely to put at risk the personal safety of members or Ministers. When these questions were raised, security issues were very much before us. I do not want to talk about them in such a way as to increase the risk but it is something that is before us today and we see it in other parts of the world from time to time. Honourable members will recall that there was an occasion on which a bomb was let off in Sydney in close proximity to the Prime Minister of this country and the Prime Ministers of other countries. Thereafter the question of personal safety was an important matter for those who were considering it. I would not use it as a basis for deprecating the interest of Malcolm Fraser in this matter. I think it is quite appropriate that it should be considered although I have no quarrel about the decision that was reached.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record I will restate the purposes of the Parliamentary Precincts Bill. In the main, these are twofold: to define the parliamentary precincts; and to confer management and control over the precincts on the Presiding Officers.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not unusual for me to follow the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), as I do today. Our interests in a great many areas overlap and I am aware of the honourable member's ability to make sustained speeches on matters that might not otherwise attract great public interest or parliamentary debate. It is a skill that he puts to great effect in the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of which both he and I are members. I will comment on a number of his remarks in the course of my contribution but I want to, as it were, set the scene as to how this legislation came before the House.

This Bill follows from the report in November 1985 of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House on the subject of the precincts of the new Parliament House and parliamentary zone. This might seem a somewhat dry or academic topic, but I believe this is a Bill of substance which deserves to be debated seriously and considered by this House. We have a lot of debate about some of the more symbolic aspects of parliamentary democracy and, in the course of this debate, there has been reference to the Speaker's chair and the fact that in the new Parliament House we will have a new Speaker's chair-hardly anything which would excite great public alarm. It seems to me an inherently reasonable proposition and I believe it is an indictment of the Opposition that one of the main issues that it made some running on in 1987 was the removal of the Speaker's chair. I will be quite blunt about this: the Opposition would do far better to pay greater regard to the institution, practices and principles of the Parliament and give weight to them rather than simply devote its energy to the symbolism of the chair. I do not propose to go further on that subject today, but to deal with the substance of the Bill.

This Bill is important because it goes to the heart of the institution of the Parliament. I believe it is absolutely essential that this institution be separate from the executive government and, of course, separate from the judiciary. We should put in place mechanisms and institutions as much as possible to enshrine that principle in Australian public life. This Bill contributes to that process. It is often those who bleat the loudest about the institution of the Parliament who regrettably, by their actions and contributions in this place, demean the institution and its principles and practices. This occurred in no more dramatic way than in 1975 when the Parliament no longer became the sovereign body of Australian democracy, as had previously been thought by way of convention. I make it clear that nothing in my earlier comments, other than that last point, is intended to be directed towards the honourable member for Dundas who, I believe, makes a very important contribution to furthering the principles to which I have alluded.

The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) referred to Prime Minister Scullin and his statement to the Parliament about the power of the Speaker. Mr Scullin is quoted in House of Representatives Practice as saying:

Under the ordinary law and practice which clothes all presiding officers with certain powers . . . the presiding officer of this House has control over the precincts of the chamber, and over this building . . .
He went on to state:
Strangers have no rights or privileges in this House; they merely have permission to enter this building, and everyone knows that that permission is freely given.

That is an important contribution by a Prime Minister concerning the institution of the Parliament and I endorse it. The then Prime Minister also referred to the joint power of the two Presiding Officers over the institution of the Parliament. This is picked up and reflected in clause 6 of the Bill which states that the precincts are under the control and management of the Presiding Officers.

In this connection I remind the House that there has not always been a close relationship between the Presiding Officers. There is a celebrated case involving two very well-known figures in Australian parliamentary history-the former Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Cameron, and a then honourable member, Mr Dan Curtin. What occurred on that occasion is in very marked contrast to the peaceful and co-operative relationship that exists between our current President and Speaker. In 1953 the honourable member for Watson, who was Mr Curtin, was expelled from the House for being grossly disorderly and using unparliamentary language. That, of course, is not something that is reserved for 1953-it still happens. The Speaker directed the Serjeant-at-Arms to escort the honourable member from the premises. The ruling of the Speaker regarding the honourable member was that he was to leave `the premises'. Some time later he was seen in the precincts of King's Hall. The Speaker subsequently brought the honourable member before the House where he was accused of contempt of Parliament. That accusation was upheld by the House of Representatives. Subsequently, the then Deputy President of the Senate contested that view and the power of the Speaker to be able to direct a member of parliament to be removed from the building rather than simply from the chamber.

As a result of that incident in the House of Representatives on 28 April 1955, the then Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, moved a motion which was carried without a vote being taken that, in the view of the House, suspension from the service of the House involved exclusion from the chamber and its immediate surroundings, but did not involve deprivation of the other amenities of the building. That means that when honourable members are required to leave the chamber, they are no longer required to leave the building and may still use the amenities of the House.

The report that came before the Parliament and on which this legislation is based, outlines the practical reasons why the perimeters of the Parliament ought to be defined. The report referred to the importance of this definition, firstly, because of the law of contempt of parliament; secondly, because of the sale of alcoholic refreshments within the precincts of the Parliament which is exempted from the operation of the licensing laws; thirdly, because of the limitation on the powers of the police operating within the Parliament and its precincts; and finally, because of the application of security arrangements for the Parliament.

I wish to make some comments on a couple of those matters. First of all, on the applicability of the law of the land in regard to Parliament House, it is very clear, because of the Parliamentary Privileges Act, which was passed by this Parliament last year, that the ordinary law of the land does apply to Parliament House. There are some celebrated cases in parliamentary history that contested that question in other jurisdictions. In one case, the Kitchen Committee of the House of Commons was prosecuted for conducting unlicensed food premises. That prosecution was subsequently dismissed. Secondly, the issue of the police in Parliament House is, as the honourable member for Dundas indicated, one of continuing importance.

Honourable members should note that the precise recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House have not been implemented in this Bill, and, for my part, I think there is very good reason for that. It is appropriate that the Director of Public Prosecutions and the police have some discretion in the exercise of the power of arrest. In my opinion, it ought not to be left to this Parliament or indeed any member of the Parliament to direct the police or the Director of Public Prosecutions in that matter.

Although, as the honourable member for Dobell indicated, there will be no bomb shelter in the new Parliament House, there is to be a new facility which has not existed in this Parliament House, and that is some form of holding room-I will not call it a cell-which, of course, we hope will never be used. The origin of that development and initiative in the new Parliament House is, I understand, the two rooms in the Clock Tower of the House of Commons.

I refer to one other matter just to illustrate the difficulty that exists by not having adequate legislation to define the parliamentary precincts. A number of honourable members have indicated that, under the current provisions governing this Parliament House, the side roads separating the Parliament from the gardens, and now the parliamentary annexe, are not included in the parliamentary area. So the odd situation arises that when members of parliament, such as myself, with offices in the annexe hear the division bells, technically we leave the parliamentary precincts when we walk from our offices to answer the call for a division and then re-enter the Parliament to participate in the division.

Two other matters I wish to mention concern security and access. I find myself supporting very much the comments of the honourable member for Dobell. To my mind, it is absolutely essential that members continue to have free access to the Ministers of the government of the day. I too would hate to see put in place some artificial arrangements which impeded that access. I also believe that access ought to be allowed to representatives of the media and other people in the same way that the existing Parliament House is free and open to all those who work here. I do not want to say any more because my time is limited. I conclude on the note on which I began: I believe that the Bill plays an important part in enshrining the institution of the Parliament and giving it the sovereign standing that it ought to continue to have in Australian parliamentary democracy. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In summing up I will pick up several points that have been made and deal with them succinctly. As has been pointed out, the Parliamentary Precincts Bill defines the precincts of the new Parliament House. This is the first time that a definition of the parliamentary precincts has been enshrined in legislation. The Bill allows for the control and management of the area inside the precincts to be exercised by the Presiding Officers.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the first point raised by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). Clause 6 covers the management of the area, but it also allows the Presiding Officers to reach agreement with the relevant Minister regarding the exercise of control and management inside the Executive wing. As I said by way of interjection during the debate, in the event of there being no agreement in that area, the answer is quite simple under the clause itself. Obviously, the management and control role of the Presiding Officers will prevail. Therefore, the onus is on the Minister to reach agreement with the Presiding Officers. Clause 6 sets out clearly the power of the Presiding Officers.

I come to the honourable member's other point. It is quite obvious that the Executive wing itself is within the precincts of the Parliament. The Bill also allows for certain arrangements to be made between the Presiding Officers and the relevant Ministers as to the operations of the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Protective Service (APS). As to the issue of who has access to the Executive wing, under clause 9, quite clearly, agreement as to the duties of the APS could cover the issue of access to the Executive wing. I understand that those arrangements are already under way. Of course they would include free access to the Executive wing for members of parliament. In my view, it could be no other way. I agree with the sentiments expressed in that regard by various honourable members who have spoken in the debate.

The Bill is quite simple and straightforward. I am very pleased that the Opposition supports it. I am also pleased that both the Government and the Opposition have noted that, for the first time in our history, the precincts of the Parliament are to be defined and that the issue of who controls the area within the precincts is to be settled beyond doubt. Members of this Government and indeed the whole of the Thirty-fifth Parliament can take a moderate degree of pride in being the first parliamentarians since Federation to be involved in providing a statutory basis for the rights of the Parliament itself and those of the Presiding Officers. It has been clear in the past that the Presiding Officers have had jurisdiction, control and management only by virtue of their inherent powers based on custom and usage; in other words, tradition and the need for Parliament to control its own procedures. So for the first time we will have on the statute books a clear definition of the precincts of the Parliament, who controls it and the rights of its members within those precincts. I commend the Bill. I thank Opposition members for their support and sentiments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 2, page 6, in the items relating to the Parliament Act 1974, after the item relating to section 3, insert:
Section 5:
Omit subsection (1), substitute the following subsection:
`(1) No building or other work is to be erected on land within the Parliamentary zone unless:

(a) if the land is within the precincts as defined by subsection 3 (1) of the Parliamentary Precincts Act 1988 the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives jointly have; or
(b) in any other case-the Minister has;
caused a proposal for the erection of the building or work to be laid before each House of the Parliament and the proposal has been approved by resolution of each House.'

This amendment is moved as a consequence of representations made by Madam Speaker. It amends the Parliament Act 1974 to require that a proposal for the erection of a building or work within the parliamentary precincts be laid before both Houses of Parliament by the Speaker and the President of the Senate. At present the Parliament Act requires the responsible Minister to lay before both Houses any proposal for the erection of a building or work in the parliamentary zone.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report-by leave-adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr West)-by leave-read a third time.
Debate resumed from 17 February, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1988 amends the principal Act, that is, the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act 1986, to delete provisions requiring a minimum weight of consignments of exported dairy products, or a minimum percentage of dairy products exported in mixtures of product, to be exempt from the product levy on butter and cheese. The reason why those requirements were in the original Act was, as I understand, the belief of the Australian Dairy Corporation at that time that it would be easier administratively not to exempt the small packages from paying the levy. However, the opposite has been found to be the fact-that there is more paper work and greater administrative difficulty.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to make clear and specific that all dairy product exported, irrespective of the weight of the export consignment or the percentage of dairy products, be exempt from the domestic levy on butter and cheese; and that the exemption be retrospective to the date of the introduction of the principal Act, 1 July 1986, when the new dairy arrangements came into place. The amendment was recommended by the Dairy Corporation and, from my communication with the dairy industry, appears to have the support of the industry. If those who administer these exports say that the amendment is sensible, the Opposition parties will support the legislation. The coalition does not generally agree with retrospective legislation. However, when the intent is, as I understand it, to pay a rebate to those who were not, but now are, eligible for the exemption, obviously the amendment will add to all-round equity and should be supported.

On the subject of the export of dairy products, to which this Bill relates, it is interesting and encouraging to note that at the present time there is an improvement in the price being paid for a number of our dairy products on the export markets of the world. Two of the product groups that are the subject of international dairy arrangement agreements have increased prices, and we are selling those products well.

Discussion on the multilateral trade negotiations, generally called the Uruguay Round, featured at the Agricultural Outlook Conference in Canberra last month. There was particular emphasis on the review of the progress of those negotiations, the first meeting of which, I am informed, will take place on 5 December. However, the reality is that, because of the change of administration in the United States of America, it will probably be April or May next year before any real negotiations will be concluded.

Dairy products will be very much a central part of those discussions and that review. That ties in also with the common agricultural policy budget negotiations, which were finalised in Brussels only a couple of weeks ago. What is determined in the European Economic Community (EEC) with regard to support prices and export subsidy arrangements for dairy products has a tremendous impact on the world price of dairy products and, hence, the prosperity of the Australian dairy industry. The electorate I represent, the irrigation area of northern Victoria, is very much a major dairy export manufacturing sector of Australia.

Recently I was in the United Kingdom and Brussels. In Brussels I spoke to the EEC people on the two days on which the heads of government hammered out their agreement in the building next door. Much of the discussions I had were related to the dairy industry. I have a number of contacts and friends in the United Kingdom who are dairy farmers. I visited them and spoke to them about how they saw the dairy industry in the United Kingdom and Europe, particularly with regard to their reaction to mechanisms put in place to reduce the surplus production of dairy product in Europe, which has caused so much harm and pain to the market oriented dairy producers of the world, especially those in Australia and, to a lesser extent, New Zealand, and what they believe will happen with dairy production in the EEC in the near future.

There appears to be an acceptance that at last the Community has made some decisions which are having some positive effect. To a certain degree that is being seen in the strengthening of some of the dairy product export prices. The same cannot be said about other decisions that were made at the annual review meeting in Brussels. From an Australian point of view, adequate discipline was not applied either in the total level of expenditure available for agricultural support in the budget that was agreed to at 2 a.m. on the Saturday of the two-day meeting, or, particularly, in relation to cereals. The Europeans claim they have embarked on the correct path and that, given time, they will achieve their aims.

Australia's problem is that for most products in Europe the producer is receiving somewhere between two or three times the world price. That has various implications for surplus production, for reduced domestic consumption, and further disruption of the international market upon which we depend; not only in the sense of the farmers who so efficiently produce a product and have to meet the world price, but also with regard to Australia's balance of trade, and the standard of living of all Australians.

One of the consequences of the European Community's believing that it has made progress with restricting the surplus dairy production is that it will be quite difficult in the Uruguay Round to know what to do about what should happen to international dairy trade. It is adopting a holier than thou attitude and saying, `We have sorted out our dairy problem. We have reduced our production. We will now be looking to Australia, New Zealand and the other dairy exporting countries to do the same'. To us, that is an unbelievable attitude because it is the European Community which caused the problem and it is up to the European Community to solve it. It is like saying, `If I do not beat you quite as hard with this stick, you should thank me and do something to show how grateful you are that I have reduced the rate or the intensity with which I am beating you'.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like a Victorian.

—I will come to that later. My message to the honourable member will be reasonable but I think he will want to listen to it because the alternative answer will be bad news for everybody in the domestic dairy industry. The honourable member should remember that I represent more dairy farmers than the combined total in New South Wales and Queensland. One must look at relative significance when one talks about the dairy industry.
—I trust the honourable member will come back to the subject.

—Yes. The Europeans are talking about international market share. They will not quite agree that that is what they mean but they are really saying, `We are no longer flooding the world with quite so much dairy product. We deserve and we insist that we maintain our product', which really can be maintained only by their export restitutions or subsidies. From an Australian point of view and a genuine international trade point of view, that is insupportable.

SPEECH.PARA: The Europeans talk about their ability to trade in areas where they are comparatively efficient yet forget all about competitive, comparative or natural advantage when they do not have that advantage themselves. It is very much a one-sided argument. So the negotiations that will be taking place starting at the end of this year-certainly, some of the earlier discussions are already under way and positions are being established and discussed-will be difficult. But I hope that we can achieve a more sensible international trading environment with the EEC in the Uruguay Round by about this time, or a little later, next year.

It should not be forgotten that that is not the only important international factor affecting our ability to export and the price we achieve for those dairy exports at present. The United States of America has just successfully challenged Japan in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) on a range of processed agricultural products. That covers processed cheese, processed meat products, fruit juices, sauces, et cetera-quite a range. The United States, fed up with Japan's intransigent attitude towards accepting imports but wanting to export, took Japan to the GATT and won.
