In the discussions that have taken place some of the Japanese are being forced to yield in the sense of having to provide a procedure for greater access. That is both an opportunity and a danger for our dairy exports.

At present we export natural cheese to Japan and it is processed in Japan for distribution and consumption on the Japanese market. This decision could mean that that export market for Australian natural cheese will no longer be there because processed cheese will be significantly imported. Therefore, it is of the highest priority that we maintain all the pressure that we can on Japan to ensure that we gain equal access-that is, fair access-for these 10 agricultural products, including at least that one dairy product, and of course the even more significant one of beef, with the renegotiation of the four-year agreement, theoretically from 1 April onwards but really later in the year because a six-month extension of existing quotas has been put in place in the meantime. It is tremendously important for Australia to ensure that any greater access for agricultural products to the Japanese market, and this includes dairy products, is available equally to Australia as to the United States. The United States is applying tremendous pressure. A range of its senior negotiators, Ministers, et cetera are visiting Japan, and we have to do the same.

In talking about the future of our dairy industry, New Zealand looms large in that future. It does so in two ways: New Zealand has a 75,000- tonne butter quota into the EEC at present and that will be renegotiated later this year for implementation next year. The message from Europe is that that quota will be reduced, which has two effects. One is that, because of the pooling or equalisation arrangements in New Zealand, the very high price that the dairy farmers of New Zealand receive for that tonnage is spread across all of their production, which means that they can marginally price other dairy products into other markets such as Australia. Secondly, if there is a reduction in access to Europe, that butter will be looking for a home somewhere else, and that will be in competition with Australian exports.

The second point in relation to New Zealand and the future of the dairy industry is closer economic relations. I quote from a recent statement by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, (Mr Kerin) when he announced that the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) will be undertaking yet another investigation or inquiry into the dairy industry. He said that the review would be restricted `to the efficacy of the current arrangements in meeting their objective-a gradual reduction in assistance, consistent with the industry's ability to adjust, to enable it to compete with undumped, unsubsidised products from New Zealand. This would include an examination of whether the current level of market support provides fair import competition and of the future of the product levy after 31 December 1989'.

The importance of that IAC investigation and the date of the end of 1989 reinforces the point that I and others have tried to make over the past few months-and which the Minister initially denied, although I feel he cannot deny it any more with that date very clearly there-that from 1990 there will be an upsurge of dairy products from New Zealand available, or able to enter Australia. The only proviso will be this issue of fair undumped competition.

Once again the question of the EEC butter quota and other forms of assistance such as the writing off of about $600m or $700m of assistance to the industry from loans or grants must be taken into account; otherwise it will be terribly unfair on the Australian dairy farmer. But the race is on. The pressure is on the Australian dairy industry. What was to be first of all a memorandum of understanding in relation to controlling or limiting the exports of New Zealand dairy products to Australia, with no timetable on change to that memorandum-this is what was negotiated by the previous coalition Government in 1980-was changed by this present Government to a phasing out of that memorandum to allow more open competition from New Zealand by 1995, which has now suddenly been brought back to 1990. That is most unfair on the dairy industry and it puts tremendous pressure on the domestic price arrangements for that industry.

There are two dairy industries in Australia. There is the manufacturing industry which is subject to Federal legislation through the export powers, and there is the market milk, or city milk, industry particularly in the major cities with the exception of Victoria. Victoria had contracts, or quotas, for milk production and the sale of milk guaranteeing milk deliveries to Melbourne until 11 or 12 years ago. I give credit to Ian Smith, the then State Minister for Agriculture in Victoria, who introduced a scheme whereby over 10 years the owners of those contracts would be compensated as those contracts were phased out. The remaining dairy farmers in Victoria contributed a small levy to pay for that compensation because they were going to gain by the abolition of those quotas or contracts. Victoria now has an arrangement whereby the price mechanism is used to ensure that there is a more than adequate milk supply for Melbourne and the other cities of Victoria for 12 months of the year.

Victoria manages this very easily. Victoria makes up shortfalls in New South Wales at certain times of the year. The price mechanism and seasonal milking enable Victoria to handle this well. It is more sensible to milk cows through winter, spring or autumn, or whatever period it may be as it means that the efficiency of production is better, the cost of production is lower and the dairy farmers have a better life because they can have a holiday. There is a time of the year when they do not milk. Because of what is happening in the United Kingdom, some dairy farmers there are starting to think about doing something similar to what the Victorians are doing.

The problem of having two industries within one industry is unique to the dairy industry. I cannot think of any other industry in Australia which is still treated as though Federation had not come about. For many years after Federation it did not matter because there was not the technology to allow the transportation of fresh milk to any great distance. That ceased to be the case with refrigerated bulk milk tanks about 20 to 25 years ago. Now there is the technology and ability to transport milk in very good condition over considerable distances.

Now that this Government has indicated that there will be greater pressure on the domestic dairying industry after 1990 because of New Zealand we have something approaching a crisis situation. We have to try to resolve this internal problem in the dairy industry, particularly in the eastern States where this problem really bites. Unless the dairy industry in Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and South Australia can work out something which is sensible, and which provides equity for all dairy farmers in those parts of Australia, if there is increased competition from New Zealand, a most damaging situation could develop. Any greater competitive pressure-because of increased competition from New Zealand-on Australian manufactured dairy products sold in Australia, will be responded to by dairy farmers ensuring that the hitherto protected sectors of the industry-that is the market milk sectors, particularly in Sydney and Brisbane-are forced to share the burden with the remainder of the industry. When I talk about those sectors of the dairy industry based on the manufacturing sector, I am not just referring to those in Victoria; I am also referring to parts of New South Wales-just across the river and probably other places-and parts of Tasmania, South Australia and Queensland.

The dairy industry has to accelerate its discussions, its negotiations and its accommodation so that we can have a sensible plan in place by 1990 which will mean that all dairy farmers will not only gain from a more stable domestic industry which can meet outside competition, but also will share the burden that will come with it. I hope that we have an orderly transfer. I am not a supporter, and I believe the great majority of Victorians and other manufactured milk dairy farmers are not supporters, of the approach of `ship it over the border and let it rip; let us have a price war' because nobody wins from that attitude. If Victorian and other dairy farmers in the manufactured milk sector, that sector which does not have quotas any longer, are to gain they should pay some form of compensation for those dairy farmers who have had, with every expectation of continuing to receive, some capital value and protection through quotas. I believe that the Victorian method of doing this is worth serious consideration. If we can make some progress some of the unfortunate possibilities post-1990 will not occur. It means that what was considered only six months ago to be a time scale of about eight or nine years is now back to less than three years. That means that there is no use in quota holders saying that they do not want to negotiate or some of the wilder people in the southern States saying, `Let's pour it over the border to make them negotiate'. I hope that we can recognise what has to be done and get on with it.

My final point is that the dairy industry was quite rightly outraged when the Government in a recent Budget put a sales tax of 10 per cent on flavoured milk. It has interfered with consumption patterns for dairy products and it has, along with fruit juice, unfairly isolated two forms of food to be taxed, with the repercussions and inequities that brings with it, unlike all other forms of food that people have the ability to buy. There are rumours at present that that sales tax will be increased to 20 per cent in the May mini-Budget either because of pressure from soft drink manufacturers who already pay, I think, 20 per cent, or because the Government believes it needs to raise more money for its Budget rather than reduce its budgetary expenditure.

I make the point to the dairy industry that any criticism that it may have in relation to the issue of sales tax on flavoured milk should be directed fairly and squarely at this Government which brought in the tax. If the tax is increased, criticism should again be directed to the Government that introduced the tax and not to any of the Opposition parties. This measure was initiated and has been carried by this Government. The Opposition has played no part in it at all. We do not believe in the imposition of a sales tax on food items such as flavoured milk or pure fruit juice. I hope the Government has more sense than to increase that sales tax from 10 per cent to 20 per cent in the mini-Budget. I say to the dairy industry that it should direct its ire where it should be directed and that is at the Labor Government. The Opposition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) in this debate. This Parliament has a number of members who are closely associated with the dairy industry and the honourable member is one of them. He showed in what he said that he has a great deal of expertise. This side of the House has the benefit of the advice of a number of people who are associated with the industry. My colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) is the son of a dairy farming family. The fact that his opponent in the 1983 elections failed to compete with him in a milking contest contributed to his first being elected to this place. Certainly, the honourable member has made a great contribution in this House to debates on the dairy industry.

SPEECH.PARA: So, too, has the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), who is a dairy farmer from Victoria. The honourable member for Brand (Ms Fatin), whom I sit next to in this chamber, the honourable member for Throsby and the honourable member for McMillan have all come from and are experts on the dairy industry. One of the benefits that this House has when considering dairy industry legislation is the expertise that is available to it.

I agree with the honourable member for Murray when he says that the industry must establish a workable, rational solution to the present problems of interstate trade. But I point out that some of the problems are due to the fact that there is deep resentment among people who are paying the all milk levy which they believe is still being transferred to Victoria. For instance, the Bega Co-operative Society Ltd is paying an all milk levy which is being transferred to Victoria. In addition, the Bega Co-operative is forced to compete in the Sydney market against firms such as the Murray Goulburn Co-operative Co. Ltd, which is absorbing that levy. It is no wonder that the Bega dairy farmers are saying, `Here we are paying out a levy to farmers who are using it to discount prices in Sydney'. This is a cause of a lot of the problems.

I welcome the fact that the industry and members of this House are trying to recognise this problem. It is particularly difficult for dairy farmers in New South Wales to accept the present arrangements when firms such as Bonlac Foods Ltd and Murray Goulburn are doing fairly well in and making high profits from the export market. I think it can be clearly established that the industry in Bega is very competitive. I was looking at a 1976 survey on the average cost of production per litre of milk, which I do not think has varied a lot since then. This survey showed that, at $11.71 the Bega area had the lowest cost per litre in New South Wales. The highest cost, at $22.16, was incurred by dairy farmers producing in the Sydney area.

The Australian dairy industry has much to be proud of. More recently, in 1984, it was shown that, based on average weekly earnings, it took 4.9 minutes work to earn the purchase price of one litre of milk. It was also shown that it took 6.7 minutes in the United Kingdom and 8.6 minutes in Japan. It was also established that it took 21.4 minutes for consumers to earn the purchase price of one kilogram of butterfat in Australia. By comparison, it took 34.7 minutes in the United Kingdom and 53.6 minutes in Japan.

So, the industry is efficient overall. What is needed is for the industry to come together. There have been too many divisions between and sometimes even grandstanding by members of the industry. I guess they need to be reminded that we policy makers, as we are in this Parliament, are more strict on a divided industry than we are on ourselves. They cannot afford to come to us divided. So many industries have learned that. I believe that the dairy industry will come to terms with that fact. When it does, and as it does, we will find the sort of workable, rational solution that the honourable member for Murray talked about.

I conclude by briefly mentioning the strict purpose of the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1988. The Government has decided to delete subsections 9 (3) and 9 (4) of the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act to eliminate the weight and dairy produce content constraints. The result will be that any amount of butter and cheese exported in a mixture will qualify for dairy exemption. This followed the realisation that the cost of administration of the minimum weight limit outweighed the benefit derived from the exclusion. In addition, the limit discriminates against a manufacturer who exports a large amount of butter or cheese in a small consignment compared with one who exports small amounts in large consignments.

I congratulate the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) on the Bill and particularly on his willingness to work with the dairy industry so closely and directly, as he has done since long before he came to office. I think this is the reason why so many of our primary industries recognise and appreciate the co- operation of the Minister. I am pleased to support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In following the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), I begin my speech by quoting from the address given last month by Mr Gibson, the Managing Director of the Australian Dairy Corporation (ADC), to the National Agricultural Outlook Conference. In beginning his address, he said-and I think this puts the whole dairy industry into perspective:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past 10 years the Australian dairy industry has witnessed one of the most intense restructuring periods in its history.

I think this sums up some of the difficulties that have been faced by the dairy industry. The dairy industry, more than any other industry in Australia, has faced up to and has gone ahead with restructuring despite the intense hardship that this has caused so many people, To get some idea of that intense hardship, one need go back only as far as the opening speech made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) at the Outlook Conference when he said that in his time he has seen the number of dairy farmers shrink from 60,000 when he first went into farming to somewhat fewer than 18,000 today. That huge reduction is still continuing. In fact, it is estimated that 1,000 dairy farmers left the industry only last year.

I want to cover briefly three areas of the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1988. I want to look at the legislation; I want to say a little bit about the outlook, which the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) covered in some depth; and I want to take up another point that the honourable member for Murray spoke about, and that is the need to look more at rational sourcing. Before I go too far, it is interesting to note that in his speech to the National Agricultural Outlook Conference the Minister made reference to the fact that there is some need for further restructuring of the dairy industry. In the light of the number of dairy farmers who have left the industry in the last 20 years, this statement obviously must cause some concern to many of the dairy farmers who are still in the industry.

The Minister said that he had commissioned a review of all of his policies and programs. He made some reference to the fact that some of the arrangements and programs that relate to the dairy industry go back to the 1930s. So, it is quite clear that the message is that the Minister will continue to look at this industry. Obviously, all of us will be watching very closely to ensure that he does this in the fairest manner possible.

I would like to make another point, which I think is extremely significant, about the Minister's address to the Outlook Conference. It is all very well for him to talk about the need for restructuring in various primary industries, particularly the dairy industry which is the subject of the legislation we are dealing with at the moment. I would like to know whether he is going to insist that other members of the Cabinet who are responsible for other industries be prepared to take the same sort of medicine. In other words, are other industries prepared to face the same sort of restructuring as the dairy industry has been prepared, and is continuing to be prepared, to look at? We also have to look at what sort of restructuring the Minister really has in mind.

At the Outlook Conference the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics pointed out that the dairy industry can face the future with cautious optimism. In fact, the Bureau expects the price of manufacturing milk to rise in the coming year by about 6 per cent, which will be, hopefully, about the same level as inflation. The forecast was fairly heavily qualified on the premise that the current marketing arrangements do not break down, which is a fairly big question mark, and that the closer economic relationship with New Zealand will not lead to rapid growth in imports from New Zealand when the memorandum of understanding is no longer in place. I shall return to those two points later, but first I should like to quickly consider the Bill.

As has been pointed out, the Bill makes changes to exemptions from the dairy produce levy. Butter and cheese that was going overseas in small amounts were not exempt from the levy previously, the reason being that it was felt that there would be too much paperwork. Clearly, the ADC has realised that that is not so and that it would be much fairer just to allow a total exemption. As has been pointed out by the Minister, the financial impact of this is not expected to be anything at all. Obviously, this exemption will make matters much fairer for all those exporting cheese or butter.

In the Quarterly Review of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics (BAE) of December 1987, it was forecast that domestic milk production would rise from 6,172 megalitres in 1986-87 to 6,250 megalitres in 1987-88, and it is expected to reach 6,500 megalitres by 1992-93. Obviously, unless the market is expanding, domestically or overseas, this could create a few problems. The BAE, in that review and at the Outlook Conference, warns very clearly about the prospects of a market breakdown on interstate trading or an increase in imports from New Zealand.

As the honourable member for Murray has pointed out, the changes to the closer economic relations situation are of extreme concern to dairy farmers. Until late last year, it was understood that the memorandum of understanding would be in place until about 1995. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), on his visit, accelerated the move towards a freer market. There is now less than three years for the dairy industry to get itself into a situation in which it can withstand competition from New Zealand. That raises a very interesting point; it is one at which the Minister ought to be looking very closely. It would appear to some in the industry that the Government is prepared to throw the Australian and New Zealand dairy industries into the Colosseum and let them slug it out. Rather than having conflict, they should be trying to co-operate, first, in the Australia/New Zealand situation, but, more importantly, in developing joint export markets, because there are always opportunities there.

Looking at the world situation, it is worth reminding honourable members that it is very hard to draw any real comparisons in world export prices of dairy products. The world export market has always been a dumping ground for many other countries, and that continues to be the case. The fact is that Australians enjoy dairy product prices which are at most only 60 per cent of what the rest of the world pays, and in many cases they are much cheaper than that.

The situation in the European Economic Community (EEC), for example, has reached an absurd point. Because the price is maintained at such an artificially high level, EEC stocks of butter have reached such a level that at times the only way the EEC could reduce the stockpiles was to recycle old stockpiles of butter back through cows-in other words, feeding butter to cows. That is the absurd situation that has been reached.

On the question of exports, as the honourable member for Murray pointed out, it is extremely important that the Government continue to work on trade negotiations, because this is the one area that offers real hope for expanding our export markets. The Uruguay Round negotiations and the pressure we can put on the EEC should be kept up. Without doing that sort of thing we shall fall further behind in trying to maintain our balance of payments.

The honourable member for Murray also touched on a point on which I wish to expand a little-the question of rational sourcing of fresh milk. It is interesting to note that the United Dairyfarmers of Victoria has produced a very interesting paper on rational sourcing. What gives the paper a lot of weight is the fact that it cites many figures that were produced by the old Bureau of Agricultural Economics, now the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. As has been pointed out in this paper, if there can be an orderly move-the key word is `orderly'-to more rational sourcing, there is a very strong case to be shown, and a very interesting case, that the cost to many New South Wales dairy farmers will be negligible. It is interesting to look at the rationale behind this paper. One sees that because New South Wales dairy farmers who supply to the city milk markets have to supply for 12 months of the year, their costs of production are naturally a lot higher. I seek leave, Mr Deputy Speaker, to incorporate in Hansard two tables of figures which appear in this paper.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The tables demonstrate clearly that by allowing a more efficient use of pastures and by allowing milk production to be tailored in New South Wales areas to the point at which they are at maximum efficiency-in other words, rather than having to produce milk for 12 months of the year, tailoring production to the best seasonal arrangements-the cost of production can be reduced to roughly the same amount as the additional revenue that is gained by supplying that city milk market for 12 months of the year. It is a very interesting concept. It is something at which I hope the Minister will look very closely, because the arguments here are rather persuasive. Obviously, New South Wales dairy farmers feel a little threatened by this and they have shown that despite the fact that there is an agreement between New South Wales and Victoria for Victoria to supply 3 per cent of the whole milk market currently, increasing by one per cent over the next two years to up to 5 per cent, the arrangement has currently reached a position of stalemate, where the agreement is falling apart.

SPEECH.PARA: In table 1 we see the comparison of the cash costs per litre of producing milk in various States. I take Victoria and New South Wales for this example. We find that the cash costs are estimated by the BAE at 12.64c per litre in Victoria, whereas in New South Wales to produce a litre of milk the cash cost is estimated to be 20.44c-an increase of almost 8c per litre, which is a quite significant amount. When one works through those figures and looks at table 2 and the costs of production, one finds that if the New South Wales dairy farmers, on average, were to move to the more efficient usage of pasture and if they had to rely less on supplementary feeding, while receipts would fall because a greater percentage of their milk would go to manufacturing and less would go direct to the whole milk market, the net returns, according to these figures, which are based on BAE surveys and figures, by and large would be the same. It is a very interesting paper, and I hope that it will be the subject of much more discussion. There is no doubt that the figures show clearly that there is a very strong case for a more rational sourcing of whole milk in the eastern States.

It is important to take up the point made by the honourable member for Murray that the pressure is on the industry to come up with some sort of agreement on whole milk rational sourcing. The pressure obviously is coming from the closer economic relationship with New Zealand. The point I really want to make about this is that I expect the Minister has looked very closely at this paper on these arguments. I expect that he has analysed them carefully and that he will be looking to take a statesmanlike role in trying to help the States come to some agreement on how they might move towards this transition. The other side of the coin is that if we can reduce the costs of production in New South Wales there will be an opportunity to reduce the price of dairy products to the consumer, which would always be attractive.

As has been mentioned, the Opposition will not oppose the Bill. We believe it to be a sensible arrangement. Even though it contains an almost total degree of retrospectivity, in this case it is a very sensible retrospectivity and quite clearly will help the Australian Dairy Corporation to run more efficiently the export of small amounts of cheese and butter. The Minister has a very great responsibility to the dairy industry. He has set the industry on a course where it has the opportunity to be competitive with New Zealand. Nonetheless, there are still some teething problems, particularly on the question of the whole milk market, particularly in New South Wales and Queensland. It will require a very skilful bit of statesmanship by the Minister to ensure that the whole milk marketing arrangements as they currently exist do not break down so that we get a wholesale milk war between Victoria and New South Wales.

Through serious negotiation, particularly with the Minister taking the role of arbitrator, there is a very real chance that this matter can be sorted out sensibly and with the minimum disruption to the industry. There is no doubt that if this does not happen there could be some very serious implications that no-one in this House would like to see. There is also a very important role for the Minister to play in continuing to work with the New Zealand dairy industry to ensure that there is not a cut-throat war between our industries. If we can avoid that conflict and maintain a sensible trading relationship between the two countries, there will be a real opportunity for both Australia and New Zealand to work together in developing new export markets throughout South East Asia. In conclusion, the Minister has a very important role to play in the coming years-or for as long as he is there, which may not be that long-in the future of this industry which has already undergone massive restructuring over the last 30 years. The number of people involved in dairy farming is down to less then one-third of what it was in the 1950s. The Minister has a huge responsibility and we would be very disappointed to see him shirk it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill as, indeed, I am always pleased to speak in the chamber on the Australian dairy industry. After listening to the introduction from my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), I wish that my speech had been a little longer. I will not detain the House for very long with my comments because most of the points have already been covered. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro gave a list of members on the Government side who, in his view, had made a contribution to the debate and had supported the dairy industry. Modestly, he omitted his own sterling contribution. Those of us who know him well and have seen him in action know the tremendous support he has always given to the dairy industry. Another person he omitted to mention, I suppose understandably, is the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), who is at the table and who assures me that he has four dairy farmers in his electorate. I believe he represents them very well. Long may he continue to do so and may he get a few more dairy farmers in his area.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been said, the Bill amends some sections of the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act. But this has already been gone into at some length by other speakers so I will not again detail the aspects in this legislation which are of a rather technical nature. I am pleased that the Opposition is welcoming the retrospective aspects of the Bill. Perhaps it could look a little carefully at a few other retrospective aspects of legislation. Nevertheless we welcome its support for this aspect. As both the preceding speakers on the Opposition side have indicated, there is no basic disagreement between the Government and the Opposition on this matter. I have no real argument with what those speakers for the Opposition said. I also make the point that, like the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), I am not happy about the tax on flavoured milk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say that again.

—I am not. I have told my farmers that. I understand why the tax was put there but I am not happy about it. Just because one is on the Government's side does not mean that one has to slavishly agree with everything. I will support the tax, though, because I understand why it is there. As would members opposite, I would also be concerned if the tax were increased. Obviously the tax would be increased only if there were good reason for it to be increased. Nevertheless, I would be opposed to it.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make some general comments about the dairy industry. We have all watched with interest the developments in the industry over recent years and, indeed, sometimes with alarm. Disruptions over the last couple of years and arguments about interstate milk have not helped the industry. In my view, the greatest threat to the industry will come from the New Zealanders. I will go back to that later. I also have no disagreement with what the honourable member for Murray said about the Europeans. As I interjected at that time, his catalogue of sins against the Europeans, to some of us, is rather like the catalogue of sins that we could draw up against some of the Victorian producers.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all in the one country.

—I know we are all in the one country. I wish that some of the milk producers-but not all-in Victoria would realise that. I support the call for a rational approach to dairying and milk production in Europe. In New South Wales we have an efficient industry. Over the years it has been restructured and the number of farmers has decreased, whereas in Victoria the number of farmers has increased. When looking at the New South Wales liquid milk market, I can understand the alarm with which farmers in my electorate see this, because they have built up their industry over the years and theirs is a natural area to supply the Sydney milk market. I will study with great interest the tables produced by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). But I would hardly expect the source of those papers to be exactly sympathetic to the New South Wales case. I think the honourable member would at least concede this point. He would hardly expect those people to put an argument for the New South Wales dairy farmers. We all use the old saying that statistics can be used to prove anything.

SPEECH.PARA: New Zealand looms large on the horizon for the Australian dairy industry. It is the greatest threat to our dairy farmers. I have also found with New Zealanders that in most things they are involved in, they will aggressively market their product. We have to consider this in marketing our own dairy produce. We have to more aggressively market, especially throughout Asia. I remember saying in a speech a couple of months ago that I believe by agreement with Qantas Airways Ltd and other people we could get some of our products, such as short shelf life products, into the markets of Asia. It will take a lot of money because someone will have to go there and provide the refrigeration and, of course, we will have to be able to guarantee a stable supply of these short shelf life products.

TALK.START.PARA: —You need a bit of irradiation.

—No, not necessarily. We could base the sale of our product on the absence of that and the freshness of the product and we could quickly get it onto the markets of Asia. However, my great worry has always been, with the New Zealand threat coming up, that the States have proven that they cannot get their act together. If we cannot get our act together how can we fight the threat coming from New Zealand?

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Murray talked about sharing the burden. Let me assure him that farmers in the Throsby electorate certainly share the burden by paying the levy. They did not like it when it was introduced. They fought against it and argued against it, nevertheless they saw the rationale behind it and for the good of the industry they pay the levy. I believe they share that burden. I do not want to see a price war develop between the States. It has been said many times that no one will win from a price war or a milk war between the States.

My electorate of Throsby includes one of the most productive dairying areas of the Commonwealth. I cannot claim to have as many farmers in my electorate as the honourable member for Murray. He told me he has more farmers in his electorate than the total in New South Wales and Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —More dairy farmers.

—More dairy farmers, yes. Undoubtedly, they all vote for him. I do not know whether the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) would agree with me but I think the dairy farmers in my electorate would vote for me.
—Better quality.

—There are better quality dairy farmers in the Throsby electorate. Producers in the area have geared themselves for year-round production to service the discerning New South Wales liquid milk market. They have done this with distinction for a long time. The Shoalhaven Dairy Co-op Ltd, which the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy had the pleasure of visiting with me recently, is the major co-op in my electorate. It recently invested $8m in a new plant at Bomaderry which is capable of effectively handling the produce of its members into the foreseeable future. Besides handling milk on behalf of the New South Wales Dairy Corporation it manufactures a range of short shelf life products under the `Nowra' brand for distribution throughout the south-east region of the State. I would like to see the co-op distributing it further than the south-east region. It is one of the groups I want to see more aggressively investigate the possibility of getting some of these short shelf life products onto the markets of Asia. As well, this co-op is a processor of condensed milk for the retail and industrial markets. This co-op is a progressive company which, besides processing its members' products, has developed a range of subsidiary operations aimed at serving its members and the wider community. These people and others like them have invested a lot of money in dairying. It is up to us to provide the environment necessary to ensure that the faith of such investors is not misplaced.

SPEECH.PARA: When the honourable member for Wannon was producing his figures from United Dairyfarmers of Victoria, he spoke about the necessity to get the best seasonal return from the dairy farmers. Of course, this is often the crux of the argument between the New South Wales farmers and the Victorian farmers, because New South Wales farmers produce year-round milk. The consumers in New South Wales have a guaranteed year-round supply of high quality milk. The worry of the people in New South Wales is that if the gates were opened and the Victorians were allowed to come in with all their milk, in spring and summer we would have very cheap milk and a very plentiful supply of milk-indeed, we would have an oversupply of milk. But we are not worried about spring and summer; we are worried about autumn and winter, because we fear that with seasonal production whatever milk was available during autumn and winter would be very expensive and we suspect that often milk would not be available. The honourable member for Murray shakes his head. I will have a look at the figures--

TALK.START.PARA: —We produce far more milk in winter than New South Wales does, at a cheaper price.

—The honourable member says that. Nevertheless this is the worry that farmers in my area have and it is a worry I share. We would have a plentiful supply of milk in spring and summer and no milk in winter, and what milk we had would be very expensive. The dairy farmers in New South Wales, at no small cost to themselves, rationalised their industry. They went through a difficult period a few years back and they are not going to stand by idly and see the industry that they have so carefully built up over the years destroyed. Honourable members spoke about an equitable return, and equity within the industry. That is what we want. We want to join with our Victorian cousins but we are not going to lie down and let the Victorians take from us what we have worked so hard to achieve.
—You are getting parochial now.

—There is nothing parochial about my approach to this industry, as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy would confirm. I believe there is a good future for the Australian dairy industry. Of course, there will be changes within the industry. We have to watch the New Zealanders very carefully and get our act together to resist their attempts, because no doubt they will attempt to take over the industry here. We have to market more aggressively our whole range of dairy products, especially those short shelf life products and especially throughout the Asian markets.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude my remarks by congratulating the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy for the excellent job he is doing for the dairy farmers and the rural people of Australia and I commend the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Several honourable members who have spoken have urged that I adopt a statesman-like role. I think the best parameter by which I can judge that statesmanship has been evidenced by the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). Like him, I once had the pleasure of representing dairy farmers in some of the areas he now represents. I am not quite sure of electorate boundaries but I am sure he represents the dairy farmers in Jamberoo, Kiama, Jaspers Brush, Meroo Meadow, Berry, Bomaderry, Kangaroo Valley and Nowra.
—Indeed.

—He represents all those people-and a fine collection of people they are. There is no opposition from the other side of the House to what is basically a technical and administrative matter. I make the point that many honourable members have referred to both the manufacturing and marketing of milk. I say plainly that it would be a tragedy if the Government in New South Wales were to change and the National Party got hold of the New South Wales industry. The fact is that the delicate situation we now have, the fragile compact as I describe it, that has the potential to move the rational sourcing of milk, may evaporate overnight. The National Party policy in New South Wales refers only to market milk. On other products it simply says that it will set up an agency within the Department of Agriculture to dispose of agricultural products.

SPEECH.PARA: The cutting edge of the debate in the industry is the New South Wales versus Victoria matter. The Victorian Government has in place legislation which makes that situation manageable. I believe that there is a large measure of understanding between the two governments. Of course, we understand the reality that dairy industry leaders, representing their industries, at times make things difficult. Here again, I must say that under the leadership of Pat Rowley we have those outbreaks in which people make statements that are not always too helpful quietened. However, the industry is working through the present marketing arrangements and progress is being made.

I will not revisit the whole dairy debate, but there are matters that are self-evident in the structure of this industry. Victoria and Tasmania can produce milk comparatively better than many other parts of the continent. I will not make too many comparisons because there are areas in the various States that also produce efficiently-that is granted. We should comment on the fact that many good things are happening. There is a lot more product diversification; co-operatives are amalgamating; new money is entering the industry at various levels; and people are applying their minds to the fact that we need to be in a lot better situation some years down the track. As honourable members know, the plan we have in place for the industry expires in 1992 and there is a mid-term review of the marketing arrangements now before the Industries Assistance Commission.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), claimed that closer economic relations (CER) will be brought forward to 1990 and that the industry will be under pressure from New Zealand even sooner. When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made that general announcement during his visit to New Zealand he was really referring to whether we could look at all matters-matters such as services, intellectual property and so on-in the 1988 review which had been set down for some time, with a view to bringing forward some of the other dates. When the Cabinet discussed this, the particular circumstances of the sugar, tobacco and dairy industries were taken into account. While the honourable member for Murray makes this point, which is generally true, the fact remains that access will depend on industry to industry negotiations under the memorandum of understanding which is still current. The industries themselves-or the Australian side of them-are in contact with me and I believe that they will have a key role to play.

The honourable member has urged acceleration in negotiations to handle events from 1990-largely, I think that will be from 1992-and I take the point that we want orderly transition. Some of the views coming from Victoria, which the honourable member endorses, are very sensible. He also raised the question of sales tax on flavoured milk. I make the point that, in the review of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of business taxation, none of those matters will come under scrutiny. Basically, the rationalisation of the taxation schedules that took place some time ago means that there are now two schedules of 10 per cent and 20 per cent, with a few luxury items being taxed at 30 per cent. This has resolved what we saw as the relevant anomalies in that area. Of course, other people now claim that we have created other anomalies, but there has been a rationalisation and I believe that these matters are now in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was actually referring to the mini-Budget and fears about a mini-Budget increase.

—Yes, I was referring to that too. I point out that people from the ice-cream manufacturing industry recently came to me saying that they paid a very high price for their input. They claimed that the sales tax of 10 per cent on their product together with the drop from 20 per cent to 10 per cent in the tax on confectionery, had created a particular disadvantage for them. Here was an anomaly, but they in turn were critical of the price they paid for milk on the domestic market. There are always people who have a different axe to grind, as it were, and that is a very good reason why there should be stability in these taxation rates. The Government is trying to get that stability.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) asked what I had in mind for the review of the industries. That will be known some time down the track. The review is about development and about trying to target our directions. We have identified several directions since we have been in government-more emphasis on marketing and research. I believe that we need to give more attention to human resources in agriculture in order to try to equip people better for handling some of the difficult financial and management decisions they have to face. We know from the problems that have been encountered, particularly among specialist cereal growers, that there is a need in many areas for farmers to be better equipped. We are not looking just at that; we are looking at the whole range of industries across my portfolio and deciding the direction in which we should go. That is the whole rationale for the mega-Ministries, the super-Ministries, and for the structural adjustment committee of the Cabinet to look ahead rather than be obsessed with day-to-day administration of Acts and Bills.

The honourable member for Wannon also asked whether I was urging my Cabinet colleagues to do the same in other industries. The simple answer is yes. It will be well known, with the Press speculation, that we are looking at the question of secondary industry protection across the board. The honourable member for Wannon, the honourable member for Throsby and others said that the Australian and New Zealand industries should work together on the whole question of CER, and I can only concur in that view. The New Zealanders have put it to us that if there were to be cross-ownership between dairy companies across the Tasman it would be one way of taking a lot of the tension out of the industry. We cannot stop commercial forces; anything that happens in that light must happen in the context of the memorandum of understanding and what is negotiated between the relevant industries. It has also been suggested that I take a leading role in CER negotiations. Regardless of who goes to New Zealand, I will ensure that I am well and truly involved. Probably the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) will go because he handles most of the generic areas in the trade role. I will be well and truly involved in the area of specialist commodities. I thank all honourable members who took part in the debate. They have urged me to take a statesmanlike role; I will think about that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (URANIUM CONCENTRATE EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 February, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have only a few minutes before we break for dinner, so this debate on the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill will be resumed after dinner and therefore the majority of my remarks will be made then. This Bill amends the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Act of 1980 to incorporate a tariff proposal tabled in the 1987-88 Budget. The amendment increases the duty on exported uranium concentrate mined in the Alligator Rivers region from 80c to $1.02 per kilogram as from September 1987. So the duty has been in place for some months already. The duty was first proposed in 1980 to support the supervisory, co-ordination and research roles of the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS). I will talk about that in some detail later.

SPEECH.PARA: The increase in the rate of duty is in line with the Government's decision in the 1987-88 budgetary context to recover a greater proportion of the cost of the OSS. The increased duty is expected to raise an additional $0.6m in that part of the 1987-88 financial year to which it applies and an additional $0.9m in a full year. The total uranium export levy is expected to raise $3.7m in the 1987-88 financial year and $4m in a full year. This increase in duty is thus expected to recover approximately 75 per cent of the annual cost of the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers region. The coalition will not oppose the Bill as it results from a decision made in the Budget context. As the facts that I have just outlined indicate, the OSS was set up under the Fraser Government. However, the Opposition has an in-principle second reading amendment. I formally move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Hawke Government should be condemned:

(1) for its failure to limit the role, the duties and the accountability of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in the light of 10 years' experience in its monitoring of the Alligator Rivers region, the grant of self-government to the Northern Territory and the establishment of the University College of the Northern Territory; and
(2) for the imposition of this additional levy on uranium at a time when Australian uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive on world markets.

In making those remarks about the Office of the Supervising Scientist, it should be understood at the outset that the reason for moving the amendment is not in any way to diminish the role of the scientists in the very important work they do. The OSS was set up as a result of a very lengthy inquiry. I believe it was instituted originally by Prime Minister Whitlam. The Office started under Mr Justice Fox of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry and ultimately we ended up with the Office of the Supervising Scientist which was set up when Mr Fraser was Prime Minister. So there is strong support for the office. It is the nature of the Office that I want to explore this evening. In our amendment we express concern that perhaps the role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist has, after 10 years-it has been going for 10 years-extended beyond what was envisaged originally and perhaps it is time to have a much closer look at its role and functions and to see whether or not some elements of the Office might be better placed somewhere else. I will make a suggestion about that later.

The second part of our amendment relates to the levy. The levy has risen over some considerable time and is now $1.02 a kilogram. Our amendment says that the imposition of a levy on uranium mining, and on any type of mining, is a fetter on the opportunities to compete in international markets. We are not saying, by way of this amendment, that there ought not to be the funding of some form of a supervising scientist for the very delicate environmental matters that have to be watched over very carefully by the Commonwealth in uranium mining. It is a matter of determining whether or not a levy is the best way of funding it. We believe that a levy is not the best way. Indeed, the proposals that I will put forward later this evening would be responded to quite positively by industry, which would see its way clear to continue funding very vital research-research that is recognised Australia-wide and worldwide for its excellence. It is basic research; it is essential research; and it is research that ought to be continued. The question is where that ought to happen.

The Alligator Rivers region is some 200 kilometres east of Darwin and is probably the richest uranium province in the world. The uranium deposits are located at Ranger, Jabiluka and Koongarra. Further east in Arnhem Land is Nabarlek, which is now fully mined. Those resources are located in a region which is in many ways remarkable. They are largely undeveloped, have an Aboriginal population maintaining elements of its traditional way of life and contain many of the best surviving examples of Aboriginal rock art, abundant wildlife, diverse vegetation and spectacular scenery. All Australians would appreciate what is there if they had an opportunity to see it. It is well worth preserving it and making sure that whilst we mine the area we watch over it carefully and have independent people, such as the Supervising Scientist, to ensure that all those matters are taken account of. I gave some details about the Fox inquiry and how the Office of the Supervising Scientist came about. I think that is probably well known to honourable members.

A very high degree of co-ordination is necessary to avoid duplication of effort and to ensure that all agencies are able to contribute in a productive way to a thoroughly integrated research, monitoring and environmental protection program. That necessitated, at the time the Office was set up, the establishment of a co-ordinating committee. On that co-ordinating committee, which determines what research shall be undertaken, sit all the players involved in uranium mining in the Northern Territory: the Northern Land Council, various companies, the Office of the Supervising Scientist, Professor Ovington of the National Parks and Wildlife Service, representatives from Federal departments and the Northern Territory Government. That is the body that determines the research that shall be undertaken. Therefore, one can surmise that the research that is undertaken enjoys the full support of all those who have interests in Northern Territory uranium areas.

It is important to note that its brief to co-ordinate the formulation of environmental control measures observed by Ranger constitutes only a fraction of the OSS's responsibility. Supervision, monitoring and research must occur throughout the region in order to provide a database by which to assess possible future changes to the environment. It is important to note that the specific role of the OSS is not to regulate; it is to supervise.

TALK.START.PARA: —And inform.

—And inform, which it does. Its role is to supervise. In a sense, it watches the regulators in the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy. The OSS's role is to supervise; it is not a regulatory body. It is a body that reports, informs and carries out research. I now wish to put into perspective the range of activities that the OSS undertakes. It does a lot of complementary and collaborative research with bodies such as the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO), which is based in Sydney. It is looking at things such as freshwater mussels and turtles and atmospheric testings to determine levels of radon. With ANSTO, which provides the pure laboratory work, there is a very strong collaborative function. ANSTO, as honourable members would know, is the premier repository of nuclear knowledge-for want of a better way of describing its function-in this country. So there is a complementary role there.

SPEECH.PARA: Interestingly, the OSS-I will make further remarks about that-has its head office in Sydney. That has been a point of contention and criticism for some time. Our amendment points out that perhaps after 10 years we ought to be looking at that very specific question. I will address that issue after dinner. It has a collaborative function with ANSTO and individuals. It has collaborative programs with those who work in the University of Sydney and the bodies of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation that operate in northern Australia and throughout the country. It has a wide brief and a great range of collaborative activities going on, primarily with ANSTO.

When one looks at the costs of running the OSS it is interesting to take some comparative figures. For 1983-84 the cost was $4.5m; for 1984-85, $4.7m; for 1985-86, $5.5m; and 1986-87, $6.1m. The second part of our amendment relates to the proposed recovery of 75 per cent of the cost of the Office by way of a levy. What we are saying is that, whilst we believe there should be a role for the Office of Supervising Scientist, taking money from the industry by way of a levy might not be the best way to fund it, given that a levy establishes a principle and puts a burden on an industry whose export potential we want to maximise.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will allow this Bill to pass because it is a Budget Bill. We have moved an amendment condemning the Government for not looking more closely at the Office of the Supervising Scientist, which is the office that oversees the operations of uranium mining in the Northern Territory; and for imposing a levy. I have explained in some detail the reason why we have put forward that amendment. I said that two matters stand out with regard to the OSS reinforcing its independent supervisory role. Those matters are, firstly, the declaration of stages 1, 2, and 3 of Kakadu National Park. The inclusion of stage 1 on the World Heritage List and the proposed nomination of stage 2 for the World Heritage List are also matters that need to be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: The nomination of stage 2, covering nearly 7,000 square kilometres, has now been withdrawn from the World Heritage nomination, after strong opposition from the Northern Territory Government. If stage 3 were to be nominated, that would add another 6,000 square kilometres, and embrace almost all of the catchment area of South Alligator River. Indeed, two pastoral leases have been included in stage 3, over which the OSS will now have some role. An additional five staff have been appointed to the office, one of which is in Sydney to cater for that particular area. There is no uranium mining in that area. However, there is some gold mining, and one would wonder whether, if the present levy system is to continue, there may well be at some future time a levy imposed by the Government to continue to fund that aspect of the OSS's role over that particular area. It remains for the Government, perhaps, to give some more detail to this House about what is proposed.

The other matter that needs to be considered is the further exploration and mining development. Since 1981 the Northern Territory Government has offered 153 exploration licences to at least 30 companies, subject to agreement being reached with the Northern Land Council representing Aboriginal communities. The first agreement was reached in 1986. Therefore the OSS has to perform its functions within a complex and interlocking network of legislation and agreements, and a great number of conflicting interest groups. They include national parks and wildlife conservation groups and authorities; the Aboriginal land rights issues; the provisions of the Atomic Energy Act and all the debates that surround nuclear issues in this country; environmental protection considerations both of a Federal and State nature; the Australian Heritage Act; and, of course, the Northern Territory and its various Acts covering such matters as mines, control of water, soil conservation and land use.

It is not coincidence that the OSS draws adverse comments from a whole variety of different groups within the community, including the mining and the conservation lobby. If any conclusion could be drawn, it is that the Office is independent. Because the source of criticism aimed at it comes from all sides, perhaps one can safely draw the conclusion that the Office is fulfilling the function that we originally wanted it to do; to independently supervise that area.

When talking of functions, it is well to remember what those functions specifically are. Under the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act the OSS has, as I said, a supervisory, co-ordination, and research role in protecting the environment in the Alligator Rivers region of the Northern Territory from the effects of uranium mining operations in the region. Therein lies the nub of the reason for the Opposition's amendment. We are talking about the role of the OSS, and whether that role ought to be limited; whether, after 10 years of operation we ought not to be looking a little more carefully at that role. Things have happened. There has been, of course, the grant of self-government to the Northern Territory, and the establishment of the University College of the Northern Territory. The supervisory role that was originally envisaged for the OSS has been expanded because initially the OSS had to develop a whole basic science understanding by way of research. During the past 10 years the Supervising Scientist has done that well, as have his officers. However, one wonders whether the need for continued research within the OSS ought to continue. Perhaps the research function ought to be placed somewhere else. That will lead to some remarks that I shall make shortly.

Research costs within the OSS account for about 75 per cent of the Office's resources. As reported in the most recent annual report of the OSS, the amount of research needed to ensure that the highest level of environmental protection is being achieved is a matter of judgment. That judgment is one which this House leaves for the Supervising Scientist to determine. The Opposition suggests, by way of amendment, that perhaps that function should be reviewed. Perhaps this House should say that the function of the OSS should now be more supervisory and less research-with the research role being transferred elsewhere.

The Government at that time, the Fraser Government, accepted the size of the organisation in view of the high level of environmental protection of the region that was demanded by the community in general, and by the traditional Aboriginal owners in particular. That program has been critically reviewed and endorsed by wide sections of the relevant Australian scientific community, including the Australian Science and Technology Committee.

It is well worth noting at this time that the role of the OSS is that of science. Unfortunately the Government seems to be according science less importance. Indeed, it is a pity that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) now spends much of his time dealing with day to day matters of custom. That does not mean to say that the Minister does not have a commitment to science. All honourable members in this House would agree that the Minister, more than any other member of this Parliament, has a commitment to science and has been very vocal in support of it.

However, politics is about delivering results and, as I said recently, it is a tragedy that we no longer have a formal science department within the Federal bureaucracy. After 15 years that department has been disbanded. That is a tragedy for science. Science is a long-term issue about which we need to be thinking all the time. If it falls off the agenda, some important aspects of human endeavour may not receive the attention from the Government that they ought. At some future time I hope that that department will be re-established.

Most of the scientific study and technical analysis undertaken by the OSS relates either to water management or tailings disposal. That is because the on-site risks during the operational phase of mining are readily controllable and small. The dominant environmental risk in both the short and long terms are considered to be off-site. Revegetation and water disposal will become important as the Nabarlek de-commissioning gets under way. It will be interesting to see the research that flow from that. As I said earlier, there is a real need to establish base line conditions in order to monitor the environmental impact of mining-or any other human activity, for that matter. Owing to the very limited knowledge of the environment, the amount of work required is considerable. That has been undertaken. However, that has been going on for 10 years and one wonders now whether it might not be time for a review. The base line conditions that the OSS has had to monitor from ought now to be established. Though I am not a scientist and cannot speak with authority on that particular point, that is the view that has been expressed by others.

I now turn to staffing issues. At the end of the last financial year, 1986-87, the OSS employed a total of 69 staff: 42 based at Jabiru, 26 in Sydney, and one in Darwin. So, two-thirds of the staff are located in the Northern Territory, and one-third in Sydney. As I said, that has been a point of criticism. A decision was made to base the Supervising Scientist, the Policy and Administration Division, the Supervisory and Assessment Branch, the Policy Co-ordination Branch, and the Management Services Branch of the OSS at its Sydney establishment. There were reasons for that. At the time it drew from the Federal department of the environment its support functions, but it has stayed there for ten years.

It may now be argued that the initial reasons for the Sydney location-for example, that the Northern Territory lacked tertiary institutions or that Mr Fry, the Supervising Scientist, wished to remain in Sydney-are no longer valid, and that the operating costs could be reduced by a Darwin location. I say `could be' because no one knows because it has not been tested. Obviously, if we moved every scientist out to Jabiru, it would cost a great deal in housing and that would militate against any such move because the benefits may not be there.

To establish it in Darwin is another proposition and one that ought to be considered far more closely. That is really one of the thrusts of our amendment in pointing out that perhaps the initial role of the scientist in establishing that head office in Sydney would provide the opportunity to cut back costs. That remains to be tested. But I do not think the argument can be dismissed any more with a mere wave of the hand, as it has been in the past. The 1986-87 annual report indicates the need for Sydney staff to liaise regularly with the Northern Territory supervising authority on matters relating to the formulation of authorisations, industrial health and safety and environmental protection measures, and with the Northern Land Council.

There has been criticism that there has been a breakdown in communication. The lines of communication are long. As any good general would know, one does not win a war if one's lines of communication are long. We are not conducting a war up there; we are conducting an operation that we want to be operated efficiently and effectively. Having long lines of communication militates against a successful operation. If one were to centralise the administration of the activity in Darwin, one might get the benefits not only of economy but also of enhancing the communication level with the Northern Territory Government, which is the regulatory authority, and the Supervising Scientist would then act in a complementary fashion.

As I have said, in addition the Sydney based staff visit Darwin and the region on approximately a monthly basis, arranged to coincide with meetings of one or other of the number of standing or ad hoc committees or working groups that meet regularly in the Northern Territory. It could be argued that the administration should now be Darwin based if it could be shown that this would result in substantial savings in travel, administration and other costs.

The Northern Territory law regulates mining operations in the Alligator Rivers region and the Supervising Scientist exercises supervisory, co-ordinating, research, standards development and reporting roles under Commonwealth law. As I have said, it could be argued that the role of the latter should have diminished over the years as the unknowns have become known. The establishment of base line information has been going on for 10 years so the unknown has now become known, or at least it ought to have done, and to a large degree I believe it has. As standards developments have been firmly established much of its function has become routine, such as taking water samples.

There is some duplication-only a small amount-between the functions of the regulator, the Northern Territory Government, and the Office of the Supervising Scientist, such as taking water samples. Perhaps there would be an opportunity for the Government to look more closely to make sure that there are not other areas of duplication. By collecting a levy from the industry and funding also from Consolidated Revenue-taxpayers' funds-we do not want to see one group of taxpayers' funds being utilised for exactly the same thing as another group of taxpayers' funds, namely the Northern Territory Government.

The question is whether the research function of the OSS should rest with that Office-that is the threshold question of my amendment-or with the Australian Research Council, the national body responsible for overall national research priorities. If after 10 years the base line conditions have been established, and if the research as good as it is, is to be ongoing one wonders whether or not it is necessary for it to remain within that Office and then one looks at the possible alternative. The alternative that I think it is now time to consider is the possibility of setting up in Darwin some national wetlands research institute taking the Alligator Rivers Research Institute, which is part of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, and combining it with elements of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation that operate in the north of Australia. It would include, of course, all of those research elements of the OSS, and look more closely at what the North Australian Research Unit does, which is part of the Darwin Institute of Technology, and at what is happening at the new University of the Northern Territory. I understand there will be about 500 students at that university this current academic year. It would take research out of the OSS and put it within a broader wetlands research institute which perhaps could have not just a national focus but an international focus.

Darwin is on the doorstep of what we are told is one of the fastest growing areas, the Pacific Rim. Excellence in research is already there which could be combined with the other elements there. It would make a lot of sense and give some prestige. There would not necessarily be a great saving to industry because I believe it is in industry's interest to fund this research and I believe that industry would continue to do so, but it would not be funded by way of a levy.

That comes back to the second part of my amendment. We oppose not the role of research into the environment of uranium mining; indeed, we support it very strongly; we established it. But what we are saying is that, if we put levies on mining operations, such as coal levies, uranium levies and oil levies, they are in the form of a secondary tax and they militate against the export industries that we want to be more and more competitive in placing their product on the international market. If the companies could see their way clear-I am sure it would be in their interests to do so-to fund directly by some mechanism suitable to the government of the day, whether it be a coalition government or a Labor government, we might find that that would be a far more effective way of doing it and therefore the role of the Supervising Scientist, whilst it would continue, would be diminished. It would be doing its primary role of supervising rather than becoming, as I suspect it may, a growing research institute-of some excellence no doubt but continually drawing on funds. We put in place that early mechanism of drawing funds from the industry and the industry does not have the opportunity to look more closely at it although, as I said-and industry must look more closely at this-it is represented on the co-ordinating committee which sets the research guidelines and directions of the Alligator Rivers Research Institute.

At a time when Australia is looking for exports, education exports is an area at which it ought to be looking more closely. We ought to be pursuing it more aggressively. The development within the Northern Territory of a university is a positive step which everyone in this place welcomes. One way of enhancing its role and providing it with a centre of excellence, a centre of expertise, may well be the development of a wetlands research institute which could be made up of those primary elements of research that are now within the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Perhaps the Minister will comment on that proposal later. As I have said, we are on the doorstep of Asia and we could be playing a far more positive role.

To recap quickly, we support this legislation because it is part of the budgetary process; we do not oppose Budget Bills. We have moved an amendment criticising the levy which has gone up again from 80c to $1.02 per kilogram. Obviously, the industry does not like it. We think it sets a particularly bad precedent to place a levy on export industries, particularly uranium. We had a lot to say earlier this week and last week about uranium. Of course, uranium mining is rather an emotional matter about which many of us on both sides of the House can get quite excited. But uranium is a potential export in this country, the surface of which is only just being scratched. Much more money could be made. Many more jobs could flow from it. We must do it in an environmentally sensitive and sensible way; we certainly support that.

The Office of the Supervising Scientist has a role to play. But money can be saved in its operations. It has been going for 10 years and it is now time for a more detailed study to look at some of the alternatives to its operation. If the Northern Territory-the latest independent area; its no longer being a territory-can benefit from some changes to enhance its educational facilities and its future educational potential in that part of the world where Australia will need in the future to play a much bigger role, that will be timely and I commend that proposal to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?
—Yes, I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill proposes to increase the duty on exported uranium concentrate mined in the Alligator Rivers Region from 80c per kilogram to $1.02 per kilogram. The Bill is straightforward and I have great pleasure in supporting it. It has been put forward by one of the Ministers I admire the most in the House, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones).

SPEECH.PARA: The duty which has been imposed was introduced in 1980 by the Fraser Government and is in recognition of the special costs of environmental monitoring and research activities related to uranium mining in the Alligator Rivers region. The increased rate of duty reflects the Government's decision-and a correct one-made within the 1987 budgetary context to move closer to the recovery of the cost of this monitoring and research. Clause 4 provides an exemption from the increased levy for Alligator Rivers region uranium concentrate which was loaded onto a vessel for export before the 15 September commencement date, or which forms a part of a consignment of uranium concentrate which commenced to be loaded onto a vessel for export before the commencement date.

The proposal gives effect to the Government's Budget decision announced on 15 September 1987 and is effective from 8 p.m. on that date. The proposed increased duty is expected to raise an additional $0.6m during that part of the 1987-88 financial year to which it applies, and an additional $0.9m in a full year. At the proposed new rate, the total uranium export levy is expected to raise $3.7m in the 1987-88 financial year and $4m in a full year. The proposed levy will now recover approximately 75 per cent of the annual cost of the uranium related monitoring and research activities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers region. I think that is correct and proper. The Government is determined to ensure that the unique habitat of the Kakadu National Park is maintained for the future enjoyment of all Australians. It is good to see in the House tonight the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon).

The Office of the Supervising Scientist is a key element in the environmental protection arrangements put in place by the Government. To that end the Office has engaged in significant research into the management of uranium tailings to provide information necessary to ensure that tailings can be contained and isolated from the environment for thousands of years. Miners are monitored also for exposure to radiation in the extraction of the uranium. It is also necessary to develop strategies for revegetation, which is extremely vital in such a fragile area.
