The Office has also conducted baseline studies at the proposed gold mining site at Coronation Hill in the proposed stage 3 of the Kakadu National Park to determine what are the unique natural qualities of the area and to assess what permanent damage to the environment could occur should any mining take place in that region.

The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) mentioned staffing of the Office. Over two-thirds of the staff of the Office of the Supervising Scientist are located at Jabiru in the Northern Territory. However, staff who perform tasks such as administrative support that can be conducted efficiently elsewhere are based in Sydney. The honourable member for Bass recommended that the staff shift to the Northern Territory. He made the statement that `it could improve accounting'. I do not think that is a good enough reason to shift staff or change strategies. That demonstrates the difference of opinions on both sides of the House on all economic matters. The cost of paying the Northern Territory allowance to staff, the cost of providing adequate housing and the increased costs of goods and services in the Northern Territory as opposed to Sydney make it more cost efficient to base particular staff in Sydney rather than in Jabiru.

One may well ask what justification there is for increasing the levy on exported uranium concentrate by 22c per kilogram at a time when export earnings are so badly needed. In 1978 the Fraser Government decided that in view of the environmental significance of the Alligator Rivers region uranium mining operations should be subject to oversight by the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers region. Subsequently, by legislation passed in 1980, a levy of 11c per kilogram was imposed on uranium exports in recognition of the special costs of environmental monitoring and research activities related to uranium mining in the region. This levy, however, recovered only a small fraction of the costs of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. It is only fair to say that if we are going to export uranium the monitoring of such fragile areas should be maintained and the economy of Australia should not pay for it.

It is an accepted principle that costs of providing necessary regulatory services should be recovered. That makes commonsense. Accordingly, in the 1986-87 Budget the Government increased the levy on uranium oxide mined in the Alligator Rivers region from 11c to 80c per kilogram. The levy raised $3.1m in 1986-87 and offset 50 per cent of the cost of operating the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The Opposition always points out that we should show economies; this is another example of doing just that. In the 1987-88 Budget, the Government increased the levy to $1.02 per kilogram. The rate has been increased so as to offset 75 per cent of the cost of operating the Office of the Supervising Scientist. It is expected to raise $3.7m in 1987-88. The levy is paid by Ranger Uranium Mines Pty Ltd and Queensland Mines Ltd. It is not expected that the increase in the export levy will significantly affect export earnings from uranium mining in the Alligator Rivers region, as only an additional $0.6m will be raised this financial year. However, this revenue contributes to safeguarding the region and ensuring that the environment retains its natural beauty. As tourism is becoming a massive industry, that is extremely sensible. This generation as well as future generations should be able to enjoy our unique heritage.

One of the complex problems that will affect the nuclear industry in the near future-and I digress here for a moment-is the decommissioning of nuclear power plants, which is proving to be much more costly than expected. This raises the question of who will pay in the future for this decommissioning. It is a problem that will have to be faced in the very near future by many of the large nations that have ageing power stations.

I would like to compliment the Minister on his initiatives in regard to superconductivity. It would appear to me that in the long term this will help to pave the way for more efficient and less costly energy use. This will come about simply by the use of a lesser amount of coal, water power or uranium to produce a higher proportion of usable energy. As the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business pointed out, the greenhouse effect is a serious issue that has to be addressed for the future of our planet. We should not be frightened by technology but should be attempting to explore ways in which we can live in peace and in a way that is conducive to maintaining our natural environment within the realms of feasibility and commonsense. I support the statement made by the honourable member for Bass about the importance of science and its necessity if we are to survive as a nation and reach the year 2000 in a progressive manner.

Obviously, for Australia to improve its economic position it is necessary to support value added industries and at the same time attempt to conserve and nurture the environment. With the increase in the levy to offset the costs of the Office of the Supervising Scientist we are ensuring that environmental monitoring and visual activities can be taken out in an affordable way. It is on that premise that I support and commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House has heard a thoughtful and moderate speech from the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice). I believe that this would not have been the case had we been hearing from some of his colleagues such as the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent), the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) or even perhaps the recent ministerial appointment in the other place, Senator Bolkus.
—They have been gagged.

—As my colleague points out, they have been gagged. The purpose of the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1988, as was just made plain, is to incorporate into the Act the 1987-88 Budget proposal that the export duty on uranium concentrate produced in the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory be increased from 80c to $1.02 per kilogram. As has also been pointed out, this increase will help contribute to the cost of the activities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. This is indeed a worthy objective but it is in conflict with the overriding priority of this country to expand exports, a matter which is referred to in the second part of the amendment moved by the Opposition. As was made clear in the speech of the honourable member for Hinkler, export duties have a habit of creeping upwards. The export duty in this case began at about 0.1 of 1 per cent. At 80c it was roughly 0.8 per cent of the value in question. The charge of $1.02 puts the duty up near 1 per cent. The tendency to increases of this sort are just the problem with export duties. In the situation in which this country finds itself, with such an enormous priority on exports, such a duty on exports is undesirable.

SPEECH.PARA: The Office of the Supervising Scientist was, of course, an essential element of the complex regime of environmental protection measures to control potential environmental impacts from the development of the uranium resources of the Alligator Rivers region. The region embraces the Kakadu National Park. In a word, the overall objective is to protect the environment in the Alligator Rivers region from the effects of mining operations. The annual cost of the Office of the Supervising Scientist is of the order of $6m.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lot of money.
—It is a significant sum, as my colleague mentions.
—Very well spent.
—Yes, I will come back to that. This amount is made up of research at about $4.677m, with the cost of supervising and assessment and co-ordination and corporate support making up the balance.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is recognised that the Office of the Supervising Scientist is not a regulatory agency. Its primary charter is to oversee the regulators, and to assist in the development of environment protection arrangements and regulatory regimes and to advise the Government on their adequacy. As I pointed out, it has a prime responsibility to ensure, in the day to day licensing and regulation of uranium mining operations in the region, that the Commonwealth's environmental requirements are implemented. The Office is further charged with the duty of carrying out specific mission-oriented research. Research is necessary not only to ensure that the highest level of environmental protection is able to be maintained in the region, but also to give credibility to assurances that this high level of protection is in fact being achieved. In the event we find-and I have just been given the figures-that research accounts for 75 per cent of the Office's resources.

My colleague the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), the shadow Minister for Science, has raised questions about the scope, size and appropriate location of that research effort. In the annual report of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, for 1986-87, we are assured that the research program was critically reviewed from the start and endorsed by a wide section of the relevant Australian scientific community, and it has been independently endorsed by the Australian Science and Technology Council since. The co-ordinating committee for the protection of the environment in the region would no doubt keep a close eye on the relevance and practicality of the research to the task at hand.

However, after some 10 years of establishing the fundamentals of the framework of the scientific research necessary to carry out this task, it could well be time, as the shadow Minister suggested, for taking another look at the charter and procedures of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. In particular, we could look at the question of whether basic research in particular might be done elsewhere. My colleague has made the imaginative suggestion of establishing a national wetlands research institute in the Northern Territory, embracing perhaps some elements of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in association with the University College of the Northern Territory. This could be a potential sphere of excellence in research and activity for that institution. I commend this suggestion to the House.

Although the monitoring activities which the Office of the Supervising Scientist carries out may, in terms of the amendment, be overdue for some revamping in the light of experience and changed circumstances, the work that is done by the Office is testimony to the careful and extremely responsible approach which the Fraser Government took in approving the development of uranium mining in the region. That decision was taken on the basis of the most stringent arrangements and controls concerning the environment and Aboriginal welfare in the region, with exports subject to strict safeguards agreements in the context of the non-proliferation regime and the supervision of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it time to approve more mines?

—It is certainly time that more than the three mines were approved. In tense terms, the Opposition recognises the importance of the work of this Office of the Supervising Scientist. There is no question that the expenditure of an appropriate sum of money is importantly justified by the tremendous prospects-then, and even more so now, for uranium mining and export by this country. There is an overwhelming body of world opinion in support of nuclear power for the generation of electricity. While it is true that attitudes to the nuclear power industry can never be quite the same after Chernobyl-I concede that-the fact is that nuclear power now accounts for over 15 per cent of world electricity production, ranging from a very small proportion of electricity production in Brazil, Pakistan, India and Italy to 10 per cent in the Soviet Union, 25 per cent in Japan, nearly 30 per cent in the Federal Republic of Germany, just over 50 per cent in Sweden, and 70 per cent in France.
—It is safer and cleaner than the alternatives.

—I note what my colleague says. There is no doubt that the nuclear industry is here to stay. There are nearly 400 nuclear power reactors in operation connected to electricity grids and a further 250 are planned and/or are under construction. The demand for uranium to fuel them continues to grow and is likely to double by the end of the century. Indeed, on the way, demand is likely to run ahead of projected supply based on the capability of existing mines and mills.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a tremendous opportunity for this country. Yet, the left wing of the Australian Labor Party, as distinct from the position taken by the honourable member for Hinkler, continues to flout this prevailing world opinion in favour of the nuclear generation of electricity and turns its back on this strong trend in demand. Of course, the left wing in the Hawke Government calls the shots in this respect. The most recent ministerial appointment, to whom I referred a while ago, Senator Bolkus, is in the vanguard of the opposition to uranium mining. It was he who not so long ago introduced into the Senate a motion that sought to oppose the development of Roxby Downs, and only very recently he was criticising the Ministry of which he is now a member for approving the most recent shipment of export uranium from Energy Resources of Australia Ltd. He said that that decision flouted Party policy and disregarded all the forms and mechanisms of the Party, and he questioned whether the Minister had the authority to so act, and so on. One could go on in that vein. How perverse and, indeed, how out of touch with the sentiment of the majority of the Australian people can one be.

I do not wish to stress only the economic aspect of this matter, although that aspect is very important. Australia has a vast deficit in its balance of international payments. Our receipts from exports fell short of our spending on imports and last year the payment of interest on our crippling overseas debt increased to the extent on average of the order of $30m every day. The situation was such that the country was going into hock an extra $30m every day. I concede that we achieved some relief from that situation in the month of January. In this way we are adding relentlessly, day by day, to our vast overseas debt. Yet this Government would turn its back on Australia's great potential for increased exports of uranium concentrate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madness.

—It is madness. When Australians generally are having to accept and adjust to lower standards of living, the perverse ideology of the Labor Left makes the fall in living standards greater than it need be. The value of lost uranium exports over the past 10 years has been estimated at of the order of $4.5 billion. Over the next 10 years it could be of the order of $10 billion. What will be achieved? As the visiting French Minister for Defence, Mr Giraud, said, `There are plenty of other countries around to supply uranium. If Australia does not supply it, you hand the sale over to some other country where the safeguards are much less stringent'. In the next few years in particular Australia will have a great opportunity to supply Japan and Korea, which is where much of the future big growth lies.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I do not wish to stress just the economic aspect of this matter. The attitude of the Labor Left is so perverse that it turns the morality of this issue on its head. It simply does not acknowledge the moral obligation that we in this country have towards meeting the current and future energy needs of the world and, in particular, those of the more than two-thirds of the world's population in the poor and developing countries-some billions of people, many hungry and most living in poverty on a scale which most Australians have very little understanding of and care even less about. We in this country are extremely rich by comparative world standards, although we are falling in our relative position under the administration of this Government. We make up a minuscule 0.3 per cent of the world's population, while we are blessed with almost 30 per cent of the world's high grade, potentially low cost, uranium. We have a responsibility to mine it and sell it. But the Labor Left would have us sit on it and leave it in the ground, while so large a proportion of the world could go begging for their energy needs. Meanwhile this measure before the House seeks to increase the export levy, which will itself inhibit the prospects for production and sale.

Linked to what I have just been saying is the fact that this country also could contribute further to the success of the non-proliferation regime. We are a signatory, of course, to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. There is a high obligation on us to work in that context by way of good example and the maintenance of high standards, and to exert the leverage that could be ours by the ability to supply uranium reliably in large quantities and at low cost, thereby encouraging other nations to participate more meaningfully in the nuclear non-proliferation regime. This Government, by its Left dominated, ideologically short-sighted policy, reflected in its three-mine policy-which is wrong and illogical as Mr Parker in Western Australia and even Senator Button and others concede-and its opposition to other phases of the nuclear cycle deprive Australia not only of major economic benefits in a time of great difficulty for our economy, but also of further opportunities, as I was just saying, for this country to contribute significantly and in a practical way to the success of the non-proliferation regime, and thus to world peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill which is before the House tonight is a straightforward and simple matter concerning the raising from 80c to $1.02 the export duty per kilogram on uranium concentrate shipped from the Alligator Rivers region of the Northern Territory. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) has moved an amendment that the Government should be condemned `for its failure to limit the role . . . of the Office of the Supervising Scientist' and `for the imposition of this additional levy'. Despite the amendment, the Opposition is not opposing the Bill. Although the Bill is simple, the consequences of the measures are very significant. The money collected from the levy is used to fund at least 75 per cent of the cost of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in its vital task of supervising the activities of the Ranger uranium mine.

SPEECH.PARA: It is, of course, trite to say that the mining of uranium is an issue which causes great passion amongst both the proponents and opponents of mining. I do not believe there is any real purpose in my canvassing those arguments tonight, except to state that we are dealing with a Bill which recognises the existence of a current operating mine and, as such, our attention should be on ensuring that the mine is operated in such a way as to minimise its effect on the environment and also ensure that the safety considerations of the workers are carefully considered.

As honourable members would be aware, the Office of the Supervising Scientist was established following the recommendations of the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry. Its principal aim is to protect the environment surrounding the mine, especially in relation to the maintenance of tailings dams and the disposal of waste products. Beyond that, it has a very important role in conducting research into the effects of the mining operations on the areas around the Alligator Rivers region. This region is adjacent to part of the Kakadu National Park. We are not, I suppose, talking about a clapped-out or insignificant area of Australia; we are talking about an area which is of international significance. It has been recognised as such by this Government and I do not believe that anyone in the House would argue that proposition. The situation is that we have a mine operating in an area of immense environmental importance. Obviously that led to the creation of the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

The Opposition amendment goes to the fact that this particular Office has been in operation for 10 years and perhaps now is the time to look at it to see whether it is fulfilling its role, whether its functions could be hived off or given to some other authority or whether it has kept pace with changing circumstances. It is refreshing to note that at least the Opposition is acting in a constructive way. I have read through some of the debate that took place when the last increase of levy was debated in this House. To say the least, at that stage Opposition contributions to that debate were extremely trite and not at all constructive. On this occasion at least Opposition members are saying that the Office has a vital role and that we should look at whether we can improve its operation.

The honourable member for Bass mentioned some of the changing circumstances. For instance, the Northern Territory now has self-government and newly established in Darwin is a university which will have the ability to operate research facilities which did not exist some time ago. But that of itself does not mean that the Office of the Supervising Scientist has lost its effectiveness or is no longer playing a constructive role. Inbuilt in the structure itself is a consultative committee whereby all interested and relevant parties have the opportunity to have their say in the operations of the Office. Therefore, the Northern Territory Government, the mining companies, Commonwealth agencies such as the National Parks and Wildlife Service and, very importantly, the traditional owners of the area-the local Aboriginal community-are involved in the decision making process of the Office. Built into the structure of the Office is the mechanism to ensure that it does not automatically date through the effluxion of time. Something a little more substantial must be put forward by the Opposition before it can establish any sort of case for the functions of the Office to be hived off or for its role to be reduced.

In that regard I submit that the honourable member for Bass seriously failed. He raised some questions, but I do not recall his pointing to a particular problem to explain how the Office is not fulfilling a useful role at present. Where is the Office falling down? In what aspect can its functions be handled more effectively? We did not hear any specifics. All we heard was, `It is 10 years now; let us look at the Office'. There is nothing wrong with that, but it is no ground on which to condemn the Government, or as a basis for making bland statements that the Government has failed to limit the role of the Office. The Opposition needs some argument as to why there is a need to limit its role, and it has not been forthcoming.

The Opposition then advanced the common arguments which are always run up the flagpole each time the House discusses this measure, about the staff of the Office of the Supervising Scientist being based mainly at Jabiru but with some of the staff being based in Sydney. The question is always asked as to why two offices are necessary, and whether it would not make marvellous sense to have the whole staff in one location. I suppose in an ideal world that may be the case. It may well be preferable for all the functions of the Office to be in one location, but the Government has to operate in the real world. The real world dictates that the cost of maintaining staff facilities at Jabiru in the Northern Territory is infinitely more than operating a similar facility in Sydney. If we are concerned about the cost of the Office escalating, what would be the cost of replicating the laboratory and computer facilities that exist in Sydney and putting them up in the Northern Territory? If we are worried about costs of that nature, we are not going to contend seriously that the Office in Sydney be closed and everyone shipped to the Northern Territory.

The honourable member for Bass said we have long lines of communication and every general knows that long lines of communication lead to breakdown. Sure, there is an awful distance between Sydney and Jabiru, but he pointed out there are regular visits from the staff based in Sydney to the base at Jabiru.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they expensive?

—Of course they are expensive, but they are not nearly as expensive as moving the whole shop up there. One must look at the overall picture. Obviously, there are good lines of communication. I understand that communications between the Northern Territory and Sydney are in reasonable shape. We have such things as telephones and facsimile machines and what have you. Distance of itself is no great argument for saying that the lines of communication are overstretched. I do not think that argument stands up.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member went on to outline a few alternatives he thought should be looked at. He suggested there may be some grounds to establish a northern institute for wetlands based at the university in Darwin. This institute could take over some of the functions of the Office, together with some research functions already at the university. I suppose that is a proposal the Government could look at, provided there were some tangible benefits.

I return to the point that already there are consultative mechanisms that allow all interested parties to have a role in the decision-making process. The honourable member for Bass must have some specific reasons why there would be an advantage in these functions being incorporated in some new institute. If we are genuinely concerned about costs, the last thing we should look at is setting up new separate institutes. That would be a fairly expensive exercise even if there were a great deal to be gained.

Let us look at what the office currently does and see whether it still plays a worthwhile role. That is a good starting point, and I think the honourable member for Bass will agree with that. Firstly, the office provides independent and credible scientific advice on the operation of the mine and the environmental protection arrangements set down by this Government. So we have an independent body to provide advice on how the mine is going and what measures should be introduced. The honourable member mentioned also that the Office comes in for a fair bit of criticism from all sides of the uranium mining argument. I suggest, as he did, that that shows it is in fact playing that role-obviously it is offering independent advice. It is not a prisoner of any one particular point of view. It has played that worthwhile role for the past 10 years and is continuing to play it.

Secondly, the Office carries out the legislative functions determined by Parliament as the minimum to satisfy the public demand for high environmental standards. As I pointed out, we are talking about an area of immense environmental significance. More than that, we are talking about an area of immense significance to the local Aboriginal community. The environmental and pollution standards Western culture may accept are probably quite different to those of the Aboriginal community. To have a separate body which has direct input to that community continues to be extremely worthwhile. I do not think we are falling down on those counts. I believe the critical problem concerns the control of the water management system and replaced water products and the need to keep them separate from the Alligator Rivers and the catchment area. For that reason there need to be very strict environmental controls. The Office is playing a worthwhile role in that regard.

I would like also to speak just briefly about the question of the local Aboriginal community. I have no doubt that other honourable members will probably take up this point as well. I had the pleasure just recently to hear very interesting views being expressed on this subject by Senator Bob Collins from the Northern Territory. He certainly gave what I would call an eye opening account of the views of the Aboriginal community generally in the Northern Territory on the question of uranium mining. It is clear that there has been some sort of transformation, if Senator Collins's views are correct, in the Aboriginal community on this particular subject, and I will listen with interest to the honourable member for the Northern Territory a bit later in this debate giving his particular views on this subject.

For my part, I would just like to reiterate that I think there is a very real additional responsibility on the Commonwealth, given that we are dealing with a traditional Aboriginal community whose links with that land have extended for far longer than any of our links, or European links, to ensure that the environment is protected over and above that protection which the area deserves simply by its own world-class environmental significance. For that point alone I think it is important that this Government keep a very active role through the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

As for the financial part of this Bill, the Commonwealth will gain this financial year an additional $600,000, which in a full year will increase to $900,000. This means that annually the Commonwealth will collect some $4m through this levy. It has been suggested that that will be a great imposition on the uranium miners and that, at a time when Australia needs great export earnings, we should not be putting this sort of levy on uranium mining. I suppose the basic retort to that is that the companies are extracting a benefit from that area and they have a responsibility to ensure that they safeguard their operations and what they are doing there. I do not think it is so unreasonable to expect the company to pay in the form of a levy the cost of those maintenance provisions.

The other argument put forward is that Australia should be exporting uranium, that we have huge balance of payments problems, and what have you. Without canvassing the argument too much, the uranium will not evaporate; it will not disappear overnight; it will continue to sit there. It is like money in the bank. I am by no means convinced that the economics being put forward at the moment justify wholesale mining on the sole ground, forgetting the other arguments to be put forward, that a worldwide market exists. But if in the future the growth of the industry continues and we can be satisfied as to matters of safeguard and the interrelation of the industry with nuclear weapons, the uranium will continue to be an asset that we have managed to conserve.

I do not really believe the great tales of woe and doom that, if we do not dig up every ounce we can at the moment, we will sink and our standard of living will go down the gurgler. That simply does not stand up to any close scrutiny. On the whole, I believe there is a worthwhile role for the Office of the Supervising Scientist. I believe it is reasonable to fund that role through the collection of a levy. I do not dismiss out of hand the comments made by the honourable member for Bass, but I certainly dismiss out of hand as simply nonsense that the Government's actions in this regard are reasons for it to be condemned. So I ask the House to reject the amendment and to support the original proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill, which increases the export duty on uranium from 80c to $1.02 for every kilogram exported. It is worth reflecting on these figures because that is a 25 per cent increase. Only about one year ago, almost to the day, we were debating similar legislation when we were increasing the export duty from 11c to 80c-a 7 1/4 fold increase. I wonder what the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), the so-called guru of the price watch committee, would have thought of that. Here is a government charge going up by massive amounts on two occasions, well above the consumer price index, in a matter of 12 months. This is an excellent example of government taxes and charges forcing prices up.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that the Bill is designed to recover 75 per cent of the cost of the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS) which runs into just over $6m a year. I will come to the OSS later. In total, the levy will collect about $4m a year, but I note with some interest that this levy will be paid into general revenue; it will not go directly into any environmental or research body but straight into general revenue. That alone tells us that the Government is using this levy as a tax to raise more money.

The Ranger mine, the main mine in the Kakadu National Park and Alligator Rivers area, is already paying more than its fair share of taxes. In the few short years it has been in operation it has earned more than $1,000m for Australia in export income. It has produced government tax payments of well over $400m and it has paid about $60m in royalties to the Northern Territory Aborigines. So it has done its bit and is paying its way. There is a smaller mine there milling uranium-the Nabarlek mine-which has also paid its taxes and grants to the Aborigines. It has paid more than $11m in royalties to Aborigines in the time it has been in operation. I believe that the Government is milking these mines with extra taxes, and this legislation, in effect, is ordering the golden goose to lay one more egg for the Government in order to prop up its profligate spending.

As I have said, there are two mines in the Kakadu National Park area, the main one of which is Ranger, operated by Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA). It is situated near Jabiru and has been a very safe mine for the workers and for the environment around it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the spillages?

—Spillages have caused no damage at all that the OSS can detect. I have read the reports carefully. ERA sells in excess of 3,000 tonnes of high concentrate uranium oxide overseas and it is proposed in future years that that amount will double. This is good for Australia's balance of payments. ERA announced last month that it had made its first sale for some time to France which generates more than 70 per cent of its electricity from nuclear power because it is so clean, safe and relatively cheap, compared with alternative sources. An associate of Electricite de France, Cogema Australia, has purchased a 1 1/4 per cent stake in ERA, which is very good for customer relationships and the stability of the market.
—The Government will even support that.
—The Government does support that, as the honourable member for Mallee says, though I believe it has had quite a deal of agonising about it and will continue to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The No. 1 ore body at the Ranger mine is about 52 hectares in area and about 175 metres deep. It has been operating since 1980 and is a spiral road, open cut mine with a mean ore grade of about 0.3 per cent, which eventually will yield about 53,000 tonnes of uranium oxide. There is a No. 3 ore body there, which is due to begin operations in about 1992, that will produce 72,000 tonnes of uranium oxide. The ore is crushed and leached with sulphuric acid and the uranium is extracted from the leached mixture with solvents to form a concentrate of about 95 per cent uranium oxide. The tailings that are left over are neutralised by lime and put into a tailings dam.

This whole operation, especially how the Ranger mine gets rid of its waste, is watched over by a body with the rather quaint title of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. It has a supervisory and research role concerned with the environmental protection of the Alligator Rivers region. For those listening in who do not know where that is, it lies about 220 kilometres east of Darwin. The annual rainfall in that area is about 1,500 millimetres, or about 60 inches on the old scale, which I understand a lot better, and it mainly falls between December and April, in the wet season. The Office of the Supervising Scientist was established 10 years ago, in 1978, mainly as a sop to the greenies so that we could get uranium mining finally under way in that area.

Its accounts show that it spent $6,144,557 last year. I was interested to see that amongst its accounts was an expenditure of $21,000 in fringe benefits tax. In other words, here is a sort of Government set up company paying fringe benefits tax back to the Government. It is a bit like a vampire bat drinking its own blood. I cannot see much sense in that, but that has been the history of the fringe benefits tax in this country. Three-quarters of the Office's total expenditure goes on research, as previous speakers have said. I see that the Government has looked fairly hard at the OSS and trimmed the staff level from 76 to 67. I see that one of the staff is based in Darwin, most in Jabiru and about one-third in Sydney. I do not know what the number is, but last year the Office had about 27 of its staff on level 24 of the Triple M tower in Bondi. I spoke on that matter last year so I will not go into it at this time.

In the 10 years of the Office's existence it has found little wrong with the way in which Ranger and Nabarlek are managed. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) so rightly raised the question: Is the Office needed now with its present staffing level? Can we afford it? I guess the answer is that we have it only because originally it was set up as a sop to the greenies. We can afford to put the levies on these mines because they are so profitable. We could not afford it on other mines around Australia: we would have almost no mining in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing to do with Justice Fox.

—The left wing, which is interjecting now, would like to shut the country down. We would be living under a piece of bark leant against a tree trunk if we listened to some of the rabble opposite. Ranger and Nabarlek are already very tightly restricted with legislation. One can hardly go to the toilet in the area for red tape. There are 13 pieces of Commonwealth legislation, 34 pieces of Northern Territory legislation and four new Northern Territory regulations covering the area. In the 12 months between July 1986 and July 1987 there were 17 changes to Commonwealth and Northern Territory legislation which sets the rules for the mining there. To give just one example, one of those pieces of legislation, the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act, has 14 agreements concerned with it alone. I think we have to keep the matter in perspective. The Arnhem Highway that was put in the area, I am told, has created five times more environmental damage than all the mines in the Northern Territory put together.

SPEECH.PARA: The proper protection of the environment concerns us all, but the weirdo, extremist environmentalists in society are hell-bent on forcing all these extra costs and restrictions on us and shutting down any reasonable development or mining, especially of uranium. Coal can belch out its acid rain, producing pollution which poisons lakes and does not do forests any good. It even punches out more radioactivity than a nuclear power plant, for heaven's sake! It also puts out carbon dioxide, which contributes very much to the greenhouse effect. But that is okay with the left wing, which does not seem to consider the alternatives if we are going to continue to produce energy in this world. It seems to think it is somehow evil for Australia even to export uranium. I notice that some of these people who travel to visit some of those sites to demonstrate do so in planes which use up oil. They drive vehicles made out of iron and aluminium, which are mined from the ground, and they even use the roads, the construction of which, I suppose one could say, has damaged the environment in some way. Even though they are against chopping down trees they live in houses in which timber is used. They even use toilet paper which comes from trees that have been chopped down. They are totally inconsistent in the principles they espouse and the way they conduct their lives.

It is well known in the Alligator Rivers region that waste water can be discharged safely without harm to either man or the environment. No harmful short-or long-term effects have been found, particularly from radiation. The main worry-if there is any from discharge-is with the heavy metal component. At Rum Jungle we saw that the toxicity was from heavy metal damage rather than radioactivity. Ranger knows it, and the Office of the Supervising Scientist knows it. It is in its last annual report. The Government has been informed of it, but it is too scared to act. It has directed Ranger to enlarge its pond, although I am pleased to say that it has rejected the more environmentally damaging alternative of putting in a new dam which would probably cover another 30 to 40 hectares. Probably the best environmental option is to allow the release of the water because that will cause least damage to the environment and will be the least costly. The release would go into Magela Creek. It should be done in the wet season when it is flowing strongly so there is sufficient dilution. It should be done early in the season when there is still the expectation of further floods later on-certainly no more than four to six weeks before the end of the wet season.

It was interesting to flick through the back pages of the annual report of the Office of the Supervising Scientist and look at its research projects which have been mentioned tonight. No doubt some are quite pertinent to what the Office has to do up there, but some of them seem to be a little esoteric. One project looks at sexual differences in morphology and niche utilisation in an aquatic snake. Another looks at food habits, habitats and reproductive biology of four sympatric species of varanid lizards in tropical Australia. And so on. When the honourable member for Bass said that perhaps we could look at some of the Office's functions, maybe those are some of the areas that he had in mind.

The future of the Office of the Supervising Scientist could well grow, particularly under this Government, instead of being wound back. This could happen despite Nabarlek closing down later this year, leaving only one mine operating there. Exploration is really starting to crank up at Coronation Hill. The interest there is not so much in uranium; it is more in gold, platinum and the palladium metals. Coronation Hill will take a very much higher prominence as the operations get further under way. I wonder if there is an export tax on uranium, what tax the Government will try to collect to have the Office of the Supervising Scientist overseeing what is going on at Coronation Hill.

We are starting to see exploration programs being looked at at Myra Falls, which is within Arnhem Land, some 40 kilometres south of Nabarlek. We have a wait and see, or care and maintenance program going on at two deposits there-the Koongarra uranium deposit, which is operated by Denison Australia Pty Ltd, and the Jabiluka deposit, which is operated by Pancontinental Mining Ltd-just north of Ranger. The latter deposit is a very rich one. I think it has been a wicked waste that we have not been able to mine that uranium under the so called three mines policy. It is illogical that we can mine uranium in one area of Australia but not in another. The Government should not decide that; business people should be making the proper decisions in that area.

Australia has close to 30 per cent of the free world's uranium sources, yet we export only 10 per cent. Countries such as Canada and South Africa have jumped in and have our markets. It will be very hard for us to get back into those markets, particularly in the short term. It is almost economic treason. In one sense we have lost those sales forever. One day we are going to move into fusion power and people will not want uranium. They will be abandoning it in the next decade or two.

World uranium production is soon to fall if no more new mines come on stream. At the same time as production is falling the requirement for uranium will be increasing through the next decade. There will be something like a 30,000 tonne shortfall by the year 2000, which is only 12 years away. Australia, with sensible policies, will be the best placed country in the world, with its low cost reserves, to fill that shortfall and to earn some export income for this country. The spot price of uranium at this stage is $US18 a kilogram, which is about $A25 a kilogram, but the long term market price is closer to $US31 a kilogram. As our uranium markets, small as they are, are based mainly on long-term markets which pay a premium for a more stable source of supply, that will give honourable members some idea of the many hundreds of millions, if not thousands of millions, of dollars, we could be earning for this country.

The future for exports in this area is quite exciting. If we let it slip through our fingers again, as we have done in the past, countries like Canada with their Cigar Lake supplies in Saskatchewan will supply those markets and we will miss out. That will be money that we will never see. We should move in the direction I have described. In doing so, we should be careful not to tax excessively our profitable mines because that will only stifle exploration and the development of new mines and so condemn us all to a lower standard of living than we would otherwise enjoy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in support of the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill and against the amendment. I thank the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) and the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) for their great contributions to this debate. The honourable member for Fisher analysed the contributions of both the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) and the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) in an extremely fine fashion. Before I begin my remarks about the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS) I will make some comments on the contributions of those honourable members and that of the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb). It is interesting to note that the honourable member for Bass, whilst recognising the need for baseline date and acknowledging that he is not a scientist, now desires to limit the ability of the OSS to do its job. That is rather strange, considering that he is clearly not in the position of being able to analyse whether the OSS is doing its job efficiently or effectively. I suggest that he knows next to nothing about the processes the Office is involved in.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member also asserted that the functions of the Office of the Supervising Scientist are now routine. I will address those remarks in some detail during my address to the chamber, but clearly that is not the case. I can only suggest to the honourable member for Berowra that his arguments about the economics of uranium mining were, at the very best, fatuous. I suggest that he examine the great contribution to research in the field that is being done by Dr Ciaran O'Faircheallaigh from the North Australian Research Unit. The honourable member would do well to read the papers produced by Dr O'Faircheallaigh. They will demonstrate to him that uranium mining is not the panacea which members of the Opposition make it out to be. Indeed, there is a very good argument for suggesting that mining has minimal effect on the Northern Territory economy. In fact, the only real contribution to the Northern Territory economy which results from uranium mining is derived from the royalties which are paid to Aboriginal people. I suggest to the honourable member for Berowra that he contact the North Australian Research Unit and get hold of the research so that next time he speaks in a debate on this matter he can speak from an informed position.

What can one say about the contribution of the honourable member for Parkes? He is clearly one of those people who, as the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) will later say, would suggest that if it is alive, shoot it; if it is a tree, cut it down; and if it is not, dig it. I am afraid that I am not one of those people. I have grave reservations-which are well known not only in this House but also elsewhere in Australia-about uranium mining. One of my great interests has been the progress of uranium mining in the Northern Territory. I have a deep and abiding concern that has not been eased by the sorts of comments made by the Opposition. Indeed, I think that the Opposition knows, and ought to acknowledge, that the interests of the Australian community will be fostered only by genuine and informed debate about the question of uranium mining-not by the sorts of fatuous claims made by the Opposition.

The honourable member for Bass said that the University College of the Northern Territory might be an appropriate institute to take over the research role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Unfortunately, whilst I think there is a great deal of merit in the argument for a research institute of the type about which the honourable member spoke, a national wetlands institute, I do not think that now is the time. The honourable member should understand, if he does not already, that the University College of the Northern Territory is a neophyte institution which does not have the capacity to do the work that he would like it to do.

At the moment the major contributing bodies to the sort of research to which the honourable member is alluding are the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Northern Australian Research Institute, which itself is an arm of the Australian National University. I suggest that the honourable member should inform himself about the research that those bodies are undertaking, not only in terms of the wetlands area but also in terms of northern Australia generally. Then he would realise that his comments are misplaced.

In the longer term it would be appropriate if a tertiary institute in the Northern Territory carried out the type of research that the honourable member advocates. He should contact the Northern Territory Government and suggest to it that the best way it could achieve that objective would be to rationalise the tertiary institutes-combine the Darwin Institute of Technology and the University College of the Northern Territory, and then work out a way by which they could attract the sorts of funds required to carry out the very considerable task that he would like them to perform.

I should like to address some remarks to the substance of the debate and canvass a number of points. I shall not traverse the functions of the OSS, as that aspect has been sufficiently discussed by previous contributors to the debate. However, I shall point out a couple of matters that need to be understood. I am sure that the general community would like to be aware of why the OSS is so important to the Alligator Rivers region and why there is so much concern about the environmental impact of not only the physical but also the social impact of uranium mining.

Honourable members opposite should be aware that in the early days of uranium mining environmental problems received little attention. Tailings dumps were not even considered hazardous. For example, in the United States of America some 24 tailings sites now have to be rehabilitated, at a cost of somewhere in the vicinity of $US500m. At Grand Junction, Colorado, tailings were used as fill material, and now 1,000 buildings are contaminated and will have to be rehabilitated. I am sure that the honourable member for Parkes would consider that appropriate, given his statements about those people who have concerns about uranium mining, and environmental concerns in particular.

There has been serious pollution of waterways-of course that would not concern him-at Elliot Lake in Canada and at Rum Jungle in the Northern Territory. I wonder whether the honourable member for Parkes has ever bothered to visit the Northern Territory and, indeed, Rum Jungle to examine what has happened in terms of the uranium mining which took place in the mid-1950s. Has he seen the results of the environmental impact after the mine closed? In the case of Rum Jungle, the heavy metals, acids and sulphates leaching into the East Finniss River were the major source of pollution. The rehabilitation of Rum Jungle was commenced in June 1982 and was completed four years later. It cost the Australian taxpayer $16.2m, but of course the honourable member for Parkes is not interested in that.

What was once described as a stark lunar landscape has been, as a result of that rehabilitation effort, transformed into a lush tropical oasis of lakes and ponds, wetlands, marshes, well treed bushland and grassy hillocks. I note, as the honourable member for Bass leaves the House, that that was not the way it was left when the mine closed. To give an example of the extent of the pollution of the Finniss River, the pollution load carried by that river had to be reduced, in the instance of copper, by 70 per cent, manganese by 56 per cent and zinc by 70 per cent.

The Alligator Rivers region uranium industry of course requires the sort of care and maintenance that the Office of the Supervising Scientist ensures it receives. The Alligator Rivers region lies some 220 kilometres east of Darwin and covers an area of about 28,000 square kilometres. It is broadly defined by the catchment of the West, South and East Alligator Rivers.

I commend this region to all honourable members as it is extremely attractive and important, not only in terms of Australia but in terms of the world. This has been acknowledged by its inclusion on the World Heritage List. Much of the region is Aboriginal land. Rich Aboriginal cultural heritage sites of significance to the Aboriginal people are abundant. It is extremely important that I note that no-one in the Opposition has addressed the question of the Aboriginal interest in the land and the Aboriginal interest in the environment in the vicinity of the Ranger uranium mine or in the Alligator Rivers region generally.

The area includes Kakadu National Park stages 1 and 2 which are now on the World Heritage List. I remind the House and the Opposition in particular why stages 1 and 2 of the Kakadu National Park have been made part of the World Heritage List. It was recommended for these reasons: as a cultural property the park is of outstanding universal value because the art sites of Kakadu represent one of the most major and spectacular concentrations of Aboriginal art in Australia. When the whole park has been surveyed it is expected that there will be in excess of 1,000 discrete art sites recorded. Although damage and deterioration have occurred at some sites, most paintings are well preserved. The rock art provides an indication of the composition of previous species in the area and it can be used in conjunction with archaeological records to provide information about the past Aboriginal prehistoric economy and subsistence behaviour. It contains a large number of archaeological sites, most of which are yet to be excavated. Rich midden deposits are present because the sites were in close proximity to widely differing ecological zones and conditions favourable to the preservation of a wide variety of organic remains have occurred. Excavation of the archaeological sites could prove of great value to future researchers in climatology, geomorphology and to biological science in addition to prehistory.

In terms of the physical interests and the justification for the World Heritage listing, I ask the Opposition to listen to the reasons for this. I suggest that honourable members opposite ought to have great cognisance of these reasons in their consideration of the questions concerning the Office of the Supervising Scientist. In terms of the natural property, the Kakadu National Park was recommended for listing for the following reasons: it contains representative samples of a wide range of ecosystems, including those of the tidal flats, floodplains, lowlands and plateaux. It is the only conservation area in the Top End of the Northern Territory to conserve such a range of habitats and species. It is a large area, ensuring that the integrity of most of the ecosystems is maintained. The vegetation, particularly the aquatic component, is rich in terms of floristics and endemisms. The other fauna is rich and varied comprising an estimated one-third of Australian bird species. There is a remarkable diversity of fresh water fish species with approximately one-quarter of all recorded Australian freshwater fish occurring in the park. There is also a wide diversity of mammals, reptiles, amphibians and invertebrates. It provides suitable habitats for some of Australia's endangered species, for example the estuarine crocodiles. It provides a habitat for a wide range of rare and regionally endemic species of flora and fauna. The escarpment is scenically spectacular and features some outstanding waterfalls, and the wetlands of the regions, the subject of research by the Office of the Supervising Scientist, including the park, constitute one of Australia's major wetland regions and are frequented by very large numbers of a wide variety of waterbirds. At certain times the wetlands are an important wintering habitat for non-breeding Asiatic waders and as a dry season refuge for many local species. The flora and fauna have interesting scientifically important affinities with South East Asia and Papua New Guinea, and in addition to scientific research and educational opportunities, the natural heritage of Kakadu National Park provides an internationally outstanding basis for a wide range of passive and active visitor use.

On that point I point out to honourable members opposite that, while they wax lyrical about the economic benefits of uranium mining, which I suggest are questionable, they ought to be cognisant of the fact that last year 200,000 visitors went as tourists to Kakadu National Park and this year it is estimated the number will climb to a quarter of a million. That is very important because it has important spin-off effects not only in terms of the immediate vicinity of Kakadu but in the Northern Territory economy generally. I add that a lot of that tourism comes from visitors from overseas, particularly Japan and the United States of America. It is important, therefore, that we recognise that the Office of the Supervising Scientist is crucial to the protection of this crown jewel of Australian tourism and natural heritage-not only natural heritage but also, as I suggested earlier, the heritage of Aboriginal Australians.

It is important that people understand the way in which Aboriginal Australians, particularly the people of this region, relate to the area and to the region. When those opposite talk in rather crass terms about the economy of uranium mining, they should take cognisance of and try to understand the role of Aboriginal people in that environment. As the honourable member for Fisher suggested earlier, the Aboriginal people have a unique perspective not only about their environment but also about their role in the uranium industry. I commend to the Opposition the discussions that have taken place and are continuing to take place between Aboriginal people and various exploration companies, and indeed the Government, and to be aware of the role that they are playing.

The honourable member for Parkes suggested that the Office of the Supervising Scientist resulted from some massive greenie plot. But in fact he knows, as do other Oppositions members, that the Office of the Supervising Scientist was established following the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry. The Fraser Government enacted the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act of 1978. Does the honourable member for Parkes have the temerity to stand up and tell me and the House that the greenies caused that to happen? I dare say that was not the case, and the Opposition knows that.

The Office of the Supervising Scientist is responsible for the development and implementation of standards and procedures for protecting the environment of the area, public and worker health safety-which I know has not been discussed by members of the Opposition-and the conduct of supporting research. Through the tabling of the Supervising Scientist's annual reports in this place, the public is kept informed of whether environmental standards are being met and what is being taken to prevent infringements of the environmental regulations. Without the tabling of these reports and the constant monitoring in this place, we may not, for instance, have been made aware that in 1982 and 1983 significant incidents involving exposure of two workers to radioactive dust occurred or of the actions taken to investigate the incidents and implement remedial action.

Before closing, I want to address a matter which was raised by the first two Opposition speakers in this debate, the honourable member for Bass and the honourable member for Berowra, in which they talked about the sort of research that is undertaken by the Office of the Supervising Scientist. From what I could understand, they complained that the research was rather academic and not of a great deal of use to uranium mining or to analyse the effects of uranium mining in a region.

I suggest to members of the Opposition that they listen to what I have to say because the research program of OSS is tactical and problem oriented. All projects are directly related to the practice of environmental protection-assessment, control and monitoring-and to the provision to the community of technically sound advice on the state of protection being achieved in the region. I will give just a couple of examples. Ecosystem maintenance is a major goal of environment protection in the region. Work on the biology of aquatic animals and plants living in the region-the fish, frogs, lizards and aquatic reptiles, macroinvertebrates, microcrustacea and algae, for example-provides essential baseline data on the presence, identity, abundance and distribution of organisms within the aquatic ecosystem. Without this information the impact of mining operations on the aquatic environment could not be detected or even recognised.

Studies of the acidity of rain, surface and ground waters are important in understanding the source of chemicals in the waters of the region, the relevance of acidity to fish kills, which are frequent in the region, and the potential for rain to leach contaminants from ore and waste rock piles. The study of Aboriginal diets and of the way in which radioactive materials released from the mining operations can find their way into bush foods is clearly essential to the formulation of standards for the control of release of radioactive substances from the mine site. I suggest that honourable members opposite read what the Office of the Supervising Scientist does so that they will understand the relevance of its research.

In conclusion, I would like to quote the words of a very important and prominent Aboriginal person, Mr Big Bill Neidjie, who is a senior traditional owner of the Bunitj lands in Kakadu National Park. He is a very significant Australian-someone who, I believe, has a message for all of us. In terms of the Aboriginal perspective of the land, the need to nurture and care for it and the need for us to care about the impact not only of uranium mining in certain areas but of mining elsewhere in Australia, I commend his words to honourable members. I would like them to understand that Big Bill Neidjie is a very important traditional owner of the region. He said:
Our story is in the land . . .
it is written in those sacred places.
My children will look after those places,
That's the law.
Dreaming place . . .
you can't change it, no matter who you are.
No matter you rich man, no matter you king.
You can't change it.
In talking about the value and importance of land to Aboriginals, he wrote:
Should be written way Aborigine was live.
That floodplain . . .
my father, my mother, my grandfather
all used to hunt there,
use ironwood spear.
no clothes then.
This earth . . .
I never damage,
I look after,
Fire is nothing,
just clean up.
When you burn,
New grass coming up.
That mean good animal soon . . .
might be goose, long-neck turtle, goanna, possum.
Burn him off . . .
new grass coming up,
new life all over.
I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This designation of the Office of the Supervising Scientist has a special ring to it. It reminds me of The Inspector-General. Perhaps we could incorporate it in a musical at some stage in the future. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table this evening, with his erudite approach to these matters, would make a good supervising scientist. If he, like so many of his colleagues, should have to leave-or leave by design-the front bench, he might look in that direction. In any event, there is no doubt that there is a general consensus among those who have spoken tonight that we need the Office of the Supervising Scientist and that we need the care and dedication that that Office has given to the safeguarding of the environment in the Kakadu area. There can be no doubt about that. Those of us who have visited that area-I guess that would be most of us by now-are aware of the enormous value that it has for future generations as well as our own. We would all like the area to retain that value to ensure its continuation not simply as a tourist destination but as a place for all Australians to visit, to wonder at their land and the value of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, of course, I was somewhat dismayed to hear the last speaker, the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), and his description of the problem of Ranger and the mines in Kakadu. One would imagine from his description that it is, or could be, the worst area in Australia, and that one should place greater emphasis on those areas than perhaps on others. I ask the last speaker: What does the expansion of cities do? Think of the despoliation of the environment that goes on continually as our cities spread into the plains and the hills and despoil the vegetation and the vistas weekly, monthly and yearly, as we extend our habitation in Australia. If he wants to see real despoliation of the environment, he should visit a place such as Leigh Creek and gaze at the channels which are hundreds of feet deep and kilometres upon kilometres in length. He should visit the dry areas of Coober Pedy or Andamooka and see wastelands that would do credit to the surface of the moon.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you wanted to flood the Murray.

—There speaks the honourable member for Makin, who had a deep involvement in the uranium question in South Australia. In fact, I will refer to some of the remarks he made a little later. He speaks for himself now and illustrates his continued involvement in the uranium question.

SPEECH.PARA: The protection of the environment must be taken on the widest level and in a sensible way. Tourists at Kakadu are probably of greater danger to the environment, if they are uncontrolled and not channelled into the areas which can accept them, than the mine itself. We know that tourism is a subject that has to be very vigorously attended to as far as the environment is concerned.

The question of uranium is one which cuts right across the many groups in the community. Most Australians, most thinking people, would be concerned at the dangers of the misuse of uranium, certainly in weaponry and in the ill conceived energy use. However, it is an emotional question which is subjected to strange tests at times. Australian Labor Party policy is to develop and encourage the use of other than nuclear fuels in developing countries. What would be the load on the earth's atmosphere if all the peoples of the world enjoyed our living standards and used our quantities of electrical energy? It would be an impossible scene. The world could not sustain the burning of fossil fuels in that quantity, and no-one here can say that it could. No-one would expect the earth's atmosphere to sustain our living standards and to support the populations of the world if that quantity of fossil fuels were burnt. That would cause such enormous calamities in this country that it probably would dwarf the consideration of any proper use of uranium, its products and derivatives in power generation. It is those sorts of considerations which are so blithely ignored by the left wing of our friends who sit opposite.

I draw attention to the activities of the factions of the Australian Labor Party and what they have done and what they threaten to do to our uranium industry. Surely, Australians must think that it is one of the most contradictory and stupid scenes that the Labor Party has written into its policy-by the faceless men, those who operate and make that policy outside of the parliamentary party-the individual mines that can be operated in Australia. Can there be anything more nonsensical than that the management of this country in relation to uranium is not taken by this Party as a general policy, but individual mines are selected and placed in the policy, which is to be gone over and harrowed and turned upside down in June? Where will those mines that are already in that policy stand in July?

The honourable member for Makin should be ashamed of his attitude to the development of the uranium industry in South Australia. That development was one of the most disgraceful episodes of the Labor Party ever to be seen in my State. The hypocrisy of it is demonstrated by the Premier of that State now adopting the Olympic Dam mining project almost as his own. He is running around the world promoting it as an enormous billion dollar development. He is lauding the firms which supply the enormous quantities of material and machinery that Roxby requires. But where did he stand, where did the honourable member for Makin stand when the life or death of Roxby was discussed as a project in the South Australian Parliament? The honourable member for Makin did his damndest to refuse and destroy the indenture legislation. It is interesting how the Labor Party in South Australia treated the one person in its ranks who put his State before his Party-the then Mr Norm Foster, a man with immense courage, a great Australian and a great South Australian, as is so ably demonstrated in the Legislative Council. I remember-I have the quotes here-when he was voicing his concern about not having Roxby and the effects that that would have on his State. When he was expressing those concerns the Labor Party repudiated him. In a personal explanation, which is recorded in the State Hansard, he stated about one instance:
I approached my Leader-
the now Premier, Mr Bannon-

in the corridor last night regarding this matter. He told me that he did not want to speak to me. He told me that he had not said that I was not wanted in Caucus. However, I have seen press reports and been told by all sorts of people that that was, in fact, so.

The vote shows that the Roxby indenture in the Legislative Council, where the Tonkin Government did not have a majority, passed by one vote. That vote was Norm Foster's-the man who then resigned from the Labor Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he never resigned.
—Well, he said he did.
—No, the rules precluded him.

—The honourable member for Makin is being finicky now. He is using the same sorts of tactics on Norm Foster now as were used on him then. It was a battle royal in South Australia and the honourable member for Makin and his colleagues in the State Parliament did their level best to stop one of the great developments in Australia and certainly a most valuable development for my State.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians, knowing that we have a large industry worth over $1 billion in exports each year, now face a disruption in this industry because the Labor Party is returning to its grass roots. Many honourable members opposite are sick of their Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) cavorting with his rich friends in Australia and overseas. They are tired of altering legislation to benefit those rich friends. Let them speak and say they are not tired of it. What are they doing? They demand a return to the grass roots of Labor. That means that they will return to a uranium policy which will set out to destroy the industry we have now.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with uranium?

—The honourable member asks what it has to do with uranium. Why is it reported almost every day in the newspapers that the various factions have different views on the uranium industry? Why has the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) run for cover and put everything off till June, knowing that he is facing a fight for his very existence on that policy? If he cannot carry it I do not expect him to be Prime Minister at the end of the year. That is how serious the uranium question is for the Labor Party and the people of Australia. There are enormous implications in this change of direction in the Labor Party. I believe that they are very bad implications for Australia. There is a return to those views held by the honourable member for Makin, when his was the majority view, in the South Australian Parliament. Australia will be very much the loser if it listens to the people opposite and if they can guide their Party back to this scene of an anti-Australian view in relation to one of our greatest mining industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking in support of the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill and against the amendment. I would like to make a few comments about some of the matters raised by honourable members on the opposite side of this House. First of all, I had better correct a few points. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) made a few comments. He incorporated a table in Hansard last week when he was speaking on the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill. It was a table on the world survey of nuclear power reactors in operation, under construction and planned at the end of 1986. He submitted this table to try to justify the wild claim of Opposition members that the demand for uranium will far exceed supply. They are almost saying that it does now. They do not go quite as far as that, but they are saying that demand is going to exceed supply by a considerable amount by the end of this decade and, therefore, we should open up new mines. This is quite definitely nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to see that, although four of the most developed countries in the world-Canada, France, the United Kingdom and the United States of America-listed in the document tabled by the honourable member for Bass have a number of reactors, they collectively have plans for only two new reactors. Those countries have quite a number of reactors under construction, but it will be interesting to see how many of them will be completed. Now that the Chernobyl and Three Mile Island reactors have had destructive accidents, I think we will find that many of those reactors will not be completed. Notwithstanding this, we have been subject to a constant distortion of facts. Today's Australian Financial Review contains an article headed `New ALP uranium row'. The article states:
and is talking about the production of uranium-
production fell 4 per cent below demand for the first time since the nuclear fuelled electricity generation industry was developed.
A 1986 OECD report estimated that nuclear electricity generation is growing at 5 per cent a year and that significant opportunities were available for producers.

That is quite untrue. I have circulated a report which contains two tables. One of those tables is headed `The Projected Annual Uranium Requirements of the non-communist world'. That table shows that between 1973 and 1986 the nuclear fuel industry had to revise its estimates downwards by 78 1/2 per cent. If one looks at those figures in table 1 and compares them with the other table that I have put in the report, which is headed `Estimated Production in the non-communist world', one can see what the actual position is. In my report I said:
These figures, when compared with Table 1, show that uranium production will continue to outstrip non military demand until at least 1995.

These estimates are taken from Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and International Atomic Energy Agency figures. They are authentic figures. Why does the Opposition continue to come into this House and talk about the need to open up new uranium mines?

Let me also deal with the fact that the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) and the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) do not understand Australian Labor Party policy. They talk about a three-mine policy. At least I think the honourable member for Boothby understands that it is just not a three-mine policy. It is a three named mines policy. All of us in the Labor Party have accepted that. It is part of our policy-that is, that Nabarlek, Ranger and Roxby Downs are the three mines. Nabarlek is now mined out. When that mine is finished selling its stockpile, there will be only Ranger and Roxby Downs left. If members of the Opposition are not prepared to accept that Ranger and Roxby Downs can supply the uranium demand around the world, they need not listen to me; they should listen to Peter Bradfield, the Chief Executive of Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA). This is what he said:

At the moment there simply isn't enough world-wide demand to justify bringing on stream mines like Yeelirrie, the CRA Rudall River project in Western Australia, in addition to the huge Roxby Downs project and the huge Ranger project, and the Queensland Mines project (Nabarlek) which is a terminal project but is nevertheless very important. There's plenty of scope for Ranger and Roxby Downs to supply worldwide demand from Australia in the next 15 years and I don't think it's wise to see another coal industry developed in this country where, for example, we have roughly forty mines and ten are profitable . . . It frustrates me that we can't sell any more (uranium), but here again . . . it's a buyer market . . . that's the reason why a three mine policy is defensible.

I did not say that. Peter Bradfield, the Chief Executive of ERA, said it. So do not come into this House with this nonsense about how the demand for uranium is going to grow and we must have more mines in this country, because that is just plainly not true. I do not care who says it; it is not true. I suggest that honourable members opposite should read the reports of the OECD and the International Atomic Energy Agency and get their facts right.

Having mentioned those matters in response to comments from honourable members opposite, I want to say something about their comments about the Office of the Supervising Scientist. In making those comments I do not intend to say any more about what the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) had to say.
