I think the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) covered those points very well. Of course, the other members on this side of the House who participated in the debate made a number of very good points, and I do not intend to cover that ground either. The Office of the Supervising Scientist does a very good job, and it has the full support of honourable members on this side of the House. I am speaking in particular as Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. In my capacity as Chairman, I cannot let go unanswered the wild and misinformed statements made by Opposition members about the role and functions of the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

Honourable members will be well aware of my attitude to the location of a major mine, the Ranger uranium mine, in one of the most beautiful and important parts of Australia's and, indeed, the world's natural and cultural heritage. Of course, the honourable member for the Northern Territory has outlined to this House the beauties of the area. It remains my firm belief that any mining in the magnificent Alligator Rivers region is inappropriate. Honourable members opposite have argued that the role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist serves no purpose and it imposes unfair and unjustifiable costs on the mining industry. They claim that Ranger operates in a manner which is compatible with the region in which it is located.

Let us look at the facts. In 1986 the former House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, of which I was Chairman, tabled in this House a report which was highly critical of some of the operations of the Ranger uranium mine. In commenting on the number of failures in Ranger's water management system, the Committee concluded that it could not accept that a company which is located within an area of significant environmental value, that claims to be as efficient as any other operation in the world and that claims to be one of the most regulated companies in the world should have allowed the number of accidental spillages to have occurred since operations commenced. In fact, only just the other day there was another spillage. Fortunately, a Senate committee is looking at this matter. It has been to the area, and I shall be interested to see its report on that spillage.

The Committee of which I was Chairman observed many other aspects of the mine's operations which indicated a lack of environmental awareness by the company. Examples included the state of the sulphur dump, exposed and decaying bags of chemicals at the water treatment plant, and the trial dry tailings plot unfenced and with animal footprints in the tailings. I shall leave it to other members to judge the environmental competence of a company that decided to import onto its site about one million cubic metres of water in excess of requirements during 1982, with no concern about the longer term environmental consequences should rainfall return to normal in following seasons, which I might add it did. What was the company's solution to this excess water? It was to make a request to the Office of the Supervising Scientist to release the water into the highly sensitive waters of Magela Creek which flows through Kakadu National Park. That is why we need the Office of the Supervising Scientist. We need it to ensure that these uranium mines and other mines do not take that sort of action to destroy the environment.

Honourable members opposite argue that we do not need the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Even with the close supervision which is now in place, my former Committee, in just one quick visit, was able to see activities which could have harmful effects on the environment. Without the Office of the Supervising Scientist it is possible that we could end up with another Rum Jungle or Mount Lyell. The honourable member for Parkes spoke about Rum Jungle but he did not talk about the $16m that it cost to repair the damage that occurred at Rum Jungle. It amazes me that some members of the Opposition are so blinkered by the attitude that mining companies should be able to operate without being subject to any sorts of controls. They fail to realise how the findings of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in its research activities can be used to support the view that the operations of Ranger, in some cases, cause no environmental harm.

Let us just take one example. Fish kills are frequent in the region. Research by the Office of the Supervising Scientist has shown that the acidity of rain in the region is not due to sulphur oxide emissions from the Ranger acid plant and the fish kills that are common at the start of the wet season have a natural cause and are not a consequence of the mining operations. So there is an example where the Office of the Supervising Scientist was able to point to a danger to animals or an occurrence to the animals in the region which was not a consequence of mining operations.

Nobody can accuse me of being an apologist or a spokesperson for the mining industry. Yet here is just one example which indicates that, without the data provided by the Office of the Supervising Scientist, serious doubts could have been cast on the mining company concerning the effects of its operations on the various systems of the region. The research programs of the Office of the Supervising Scientist are tactical and problem-oriented. That was mentioned by the honourable member for the Northern Territory. All the projects are directly related to the promotion of environmental protection. I have a copy of the annual report of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers region 1986-87. It seems to me that many honourable members opposite just have not read this report. What is said in it is very clear:

Present knowledge of the environment in the south Alligator River valley is very limited and the amount of work required to establish baseline conditions and to evaluate potential impacts of mining operations could exceed that needed in connection with uranium mining on Magela Creek.

What they are talking about here is the need to have research operations along the whole extent of the South Alligator valley. This includes, of course, Coronation Hill. I might say something about that a little later. The honourable member for Parkes was sneering about the work of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. He just picked out a few examples which, I imagine, people listening to the debate would have found rather esoteric. Why did he not just describe the work of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, its research work, in simple language? First, it has biologicial monitoring. The aim is to develop techniques and procedures for detecting and assessing the effects of mining and processing operations on the biota of the Alligator Rivers region. Let us look at toxicity testing, testing for the poisons of metal pollution. Experiments are used to develop prospective methods of assessing the toxic risks of mine waste waters to aquatic organisms in order to specify safe dilutions of these waters for discharge into streams. That was how we were able to find out that the Ranger mine should not discharge water into the Magela Creek.

The Office also has an environmental radioactivity research program. The aim is to identify and evaluate through field measurements, experimentation and modelling, the pathways and mechanisms by which radionuclides from uranium mines in the Alligator Rivers region can lead to the radiation exposure of humans. That is very important. We have to know whether human beings could be exposed to radiation as a result of activities in those mines. The environmental modelling research program is designed to develop mathematical models to determine the impact of mining operations on the environment, in order to predict what will happen in the future.

There is an environmental chemistry research program which is identifying and evaluating chemical interactions between released contaminants and biotic components of the environment that could have a significant effect on biological systems. In other words, what is happening to the animals in that area? Are the activities of the uranium mine affecting those animals? In the plant ecology research program, the Office is attempting to determine whether the nutrients, trace metals and radionuclides released by the mining operations affect the vegetation in the area. Is it possible to rehabilitate and revegetate? When people are rehabilitating the mines after they have been worked out, it is to this sort of research that they turn to find out the sorts of programs they should introduce.

Also there is the geology of the area, the need for siting engineering design of tailings containments, to look at the stabilisation of the earth and rock structures and to see whether they will last for long periods, sometimes thousands of years. Research is done on all this work. Finally, the hydrology research program is something proposed for the future. I fully support the Government's decision to expand the role of the Supervising Scientist to include non-uranium mines and environmental assessments of possible mining operations in stage 3 of Kakadu National Park. In stage 3 one has the operation of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd at Coronation Hill. Many Opposition members seem to be unaware, although that does not apply to the honourable member for Boothby, that many of us have visited the area on a number of occasions. We have looked around the area and I looked at Coronation Hill which used to be a uranium mine. It is now worked out and gold has been found there. They are now reassessing the area and saying that there might be gold elsewhere along the escarpment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably fool's gold.

—It might be fool's gold, as my colleague says. But I do not want to be fooled into accepting mining operations in an area that is so delicately balanced, where the mining itself will take place only 200 metres from the South Alligator Creek. In such circumstances it is essential to have a body like the Office of the Supervising Scientist to look over the activities of the mining operations to ensure that they are not causing danger to the environments or to the plants and animals in the area. I thoroughly support the extension of the Office of the Supervising Scientist to undertake that work.

SPEECH.PARA: The effects of toxic chemicals resulting from most mining operations can be at least as threatening to human life, if not more so, as the contamination from radioactive substances. I believe that the Office of the Supervising Scientist plays a key role in the protection of the region if mining is to continue and if the environment of Kakadu is to be safeguarded. It is also appropriate that the companies whose operations are the single greatest threat to the environment should meet at least part of the costs of the research and monitoring. I fully support the Bill and I do not support the Opposition's amendment.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Growth Hormone-Police Corruption-Far West Children's Health Scheme-Commonwealth Parliamentary Association: Commemorative Postage Stamp-Bauxite Pricing Inquiry-Public Housing-Rainforests-Nurse Education-Government Aircraft Factories-Amnesty International-Submarine Project

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being approximately 10.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House a very sad and eminently correctable problem. Julie Davidson is only 4 feet 4 inches-132 centimetres-tall. She is 14 years old and her classmates are on average 5 feet 3 inches tall. Although she is two years younger, Julie's sister Christie is 5 feet 3 inches and towers above her elder sister. Julie suffers from a problem known as Turners syndrome and, at best, can expect to reach a maximum height of 4 feet 7 inches, compared with an average female adult height of 5 feet 5 inches.

SPEECH.PARA: The sad thing is that there is a remedy. Thousands of dollars, years of research and modern technology have meant that there is a remedy called Somatonorm. It is a biosynthetic growth hormone that makes children grow. It has been used throughout the world and has had miraculous results overseas. It has produced growth rates of up to 14 1/2 centimetres a year. With Somatonorm, the younger the age of the recipient the better is the chance of achieving a normal adult height. What is sad for Julie is that time is running out. Unless she receives this drug before the end of puberty-in the next year or so-it will be too late. She will be sentenced to a life of dealing with all the physical and psychological problems very short people are subjected to.

What is even sadder is that for the last 12 months Julie thought and hoped she would be able to receive Somatonorm and thus receive a chance of a pretty well normal life. Late last week she was told that the committee that decides to whom government funding will be allocated rejected her application to receive this drug. The drug is available but her parents or other sources will have to pay between $20,000 and $30,000 a year. Her parents, who are not particularly well off, are desperately thinking of ways to raise the money. I am afraid that, unless she is an exception and is approved by the committee, this drug has become a drug for the wealthy. At present the Government of this country says the poor will have to sort out this problem for themselves and they may have to accept that they are going to be short. The rich can buy the drug, achieve normal adult heights and avoid all the problems of short stature.

There is a newly formed Human Growth Foundation. Unfortunately, this illustrates that Julie is not alone in her plight. Dozens of families who face similar fates have joined this foundation. The Federal Government should extend its funding allowance and widen the outdated restrictive criteria which determine who is eligible and who is not. The criteria on which this committee decides who may have the drug and who may not were formulated in the 1960s when the supplies of the drug were very limited. It was produced then from extracts of human pituitary gland which were very limited in volume. Now, apart from the Government's wish to restrain spending-an admirable wish in principle-there is no need to be restrictive. There is a plentiful supply of this biosynthetic hormone. This hormone would allow Julie and dozens of others to lead a normal life.

I am unable to accept that the Federal Government and the Federal Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) have the right to play God for Julie. I believe in no other country in the Western world is such callousness displayed in dispensing such critical medication. The overall addition to the medical health bill would be small; the overall importance to Julie and the dozens of other in her situation would be enormous. When technology is available to help these children, it is nothing less than absolutely cruel to condemn them to a life of both physical and psychological problems. A little money in terms of the overall budget would solve their problems.

In the next year or two an Australian drug will be available on the market but at present it is only undergoing trials. I do not believe it is reasonable to expect Julie and the others to wait a year or more, because in their situation it may be too late. This Government should make the drug available free of charge to all. At present, one has to be lucky enough to pass the outdated criteria imposed by the committee. The rich are okay, they can have the drug and attain normal stature. Unfortunately the poor are condemned to a life of short stature, with all its complications. Our community should not accept that there is one law for the rich and one law for the poor. As the Government dillydallies these children are losing the chance to gain centimetres which may help them to achieve a normal life under the influence of this drug. I urge the Government to show compassion and caring and to finance the supply of this drug to these people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The election of a Liberal-National Party Government in New South Wales on 19 March would see a return to the days of the Askin Government when little action was taken to investigate complaints against police. I have today obtained a statutory declaration which confirms the allegations made by former New South Wales Ombudsman, George Masterman, in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. Under the headline, `The case of the poll pledge that could die on March 19' the Sydney Morning Herald article said:

SPEECH.PARA: The former Ombudsman, Mr George Masterman, said yesterday that the Opposition's police spokesman had indicated that a promise to restrict the powers of the Ombudsman was ``just for the election''.
The Opposition spokesman on police, Mr Pickering, has promised to restrict the Ombudsman from investigating complaints against police unless they are serious enough to involve an indictable offence.
Mr Masterman, who resigned as Ombudsman late last year, said that Mr Pickering had come to see him before he resigned to discuss the Coalition's policy.
`What Pickering said to us-and there was a witness present when I saw him-was' `This is just for the election . . .'
The article goes on to say:
Mr Masterman said a member of his staff had been present during the meeting. ``Never see a politician without someone else present,'' he said.
He believed that Mr Pickering's policy was obviously a play for the Police Association vote. Under it, a number of instances of police misconduct might have been swept under the carpet.
He also criticised Mr Pickering's understanding of the issues. ``He had a very limited knowledge of what was an indictable offence or not,'' Mr Masterman said.
Mr Pickering strongly denied last night that he would institute a policy for the election which would not be carried through after it.
``That's nonsense. That's not true. I'm not in the business of telling two people two different things,''

That is what Mr Pickering said. Obviously Mr Pickering and Mr Masterman cannot both be telling the truth. I have today received a statutory declaration which confirms Mr Masterman's allegations. Michael Egan, a Labor member of the New South Wales Legislative Council, has made the following declaration:

Last year the Leader of the Opposition in the New South Wales Legislative Council, Mr Ted Pickering, M.L.C., asked me to his office to discuss a proposal I had made. When I entered his office Mr Pickering picked up a document from this desk and excitedly waved it around. He told me it was a speech he had written for the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Greiner, to give at the forthcoming Police Association Conference. `We are going to buy the police force with this', Mr Pickering said. These were his exact words, which he repeated a couple of times. I have not previously revealed Mr Pickering's comments because I felt that they were so incredibly cynical that few people would believe Mr Pickering would be so stupid to make them to a government member. However, that has been changed by the reported comments Mr Pickering made to the former New South Wales Ombudsman, Mr George Masterman.
That is where the statutory declaration ends. I seek leave to table a copy of Mr Egan's statutory declaration.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I remind the House that it was not just Mr Pickering's word against that of a Labor MLC; it was also Mr Pickering's word against that of Mr George Masterman, a man who proved his independence as a forthright and outspoken Ombudsman who did not hesitate to take on the Labor Government. If the Opposition is willing before an election to buy the support of elements of the police force which are opposed to proper investigation of misconduct claims, the election of a Liberal government simply means a return to the bad old days of the Askin Government, when police corruption was tolerated and indeed encouraged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to bring up tonight the matter of the royal far west children's health scheme in Manly. In doing so, I wish to bring to the attention of the House the existence of Federal Government interference and attitudes to the operation of the scheme, which is really posing a danger to its continuing efficient and effective operation. Just to remind the House, the health scheme is a respected part of Australia's history and has a well-earned place in the hearts of tens of thousands of children and their parents who have benefited from its services over the 64 years of its existence. It was founded in 1924-in fact, four years before the Flying Doctor Service began its first flight. It was funded by the Reverend Stanley Drummond and was dedicated to the care of children from the far west of New South Wales. Its initial purpose was to give children some relief from the harsh living conditions normally encountered in that remote area by bringing them to summer holiday camps at the seaside suburb of Manly in Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme soon extended its scope to provide medical and dental treatment for the boys and girls attending the camps each year, as well as mobile health clinics to tour the outback districts. It was expanded as the demand increased, and it now has a very effective, efficient and far-reaching accommodation scheme. The scheme is non-denominational and is financed by public contributions and by the Federal Department of Community Services and Health. Because of the latter funding, the Federal Government has involved itself increasingly in the organisation and administration of the scheme, and it is aspects of that involvement to which I wish to turn my attention.

The Commonwealth requires that its own medical officers approve all admissions to the scheme's health and medical services. In view of the contribution being made by the Federal Government to the deficit financing of the organisation, such an involvement is not unexpected, nor in principle unacceptable. However, in recent times that involvement has taken a form which is so unhelpful as to seriously prevent the scheme from meeting its long-held conviction that no child shall be deprived of adequate health services because of isolation or the socioeconomic status of his or her family. The parents, in consultation with their family doctor, have a right to determine what is best for their child.

Let me give the House three examples of the type of interference which the Federal Government is meting out to this organisation. First, the admission of some children has not been approved by departmental medical officers, even in circumstances where requests for such an admission have been supported by the child's local doctor. One case that has been brought to my attention involved the rejection of an application by a departmental medical officer, despite that application having the support of 13 local health workers, two of whom were qualified medical practitioners. Secondly, departmental officers have recently informed the chief executive officer of the scheme that it is their intention not to approve any further admissions for medical, psychological or certain other assessments such as physiotherapy and speech therapy. Thirdly, applications for children from the greater Sydney area will not be approved for admission.

I wrote to the embattled Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) last December about these matters and his reply gives us a clue as to why the Federal Government has adopted such an unhelpful and aggressive attitude. In a letter to me dated 18 February he said:
The essential points are that children with disabilities and their families should be assisted to remain together and that services should be provided to them where they live.
He also stated:

It is the Government's view that the disruption to families and the provision of inappropriate nursing home care could be largely eliminated by the provision of the needed health and other services actually in the far west of NSW.

There we have it. The Federal Government has obviously decided that it would be better for far west children if they were not separated from their families and instead, receive whatever medical and health care treatment they need from services which are alleged to be available where they live. That is the point: the services are simply not available. Too bad that getting access to medical, psychological, orthodontic and other health care services in the far west, particularly in one location, will involve many families in greater inconvenience and uncertainties than having them admitted to the multi disciplinary services available at Manly. Too bad that despite the Minister's preferences for far west children to use local services, there are far west doctors and health care workers who are clearly of the opinion that there are children-and in 1986-87 there were 1,550 of them-who have a need for the sort of care and attention offered by the royal far west scheme. It really is bureaucracy and the Australian Labor Party's socialist experiment gone mad.

The simple fact is that the services are not available where the Minister alleges they should be available. It would be great if they were, but they are not. The services are available in this caring, modern and committed scheme which has been operating in the Manly area for 64 years and the departmental officers are simply not admitting children in very great need to these disciplines. That is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter which I would not normally raise in this Parliament. Later this year-our bicentenary year-it is intended that the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference be held in Australia. This is a conference which is viewed by member parliaments as being extremely important. However, a functionary of this Government and of the Commonwealth has decided of its own initiative to issue a calculated insult to the countries of the Commonwealth. Australia Post's stamp issue committee, a body of great insensitivity and massive arrogance, has over a long time shown itself to have no real appreciation of the importance of the function it performs and is certainly killing off one of the most profitable sections of Australia Post.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Parliamentary Association holds regular conferences in Commonwealth countries and on every occasion when such a conference is held the host nation has issued a commemorative stamp in order that those who attend the conference can understand and appreciate that the host country recognises the importance of the conference. But Australia Post, substituting for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, I take it, has decided to insult each of these nations by refusing to issue a stamp. It says that, having carefully considered and decided upon its stamp issue policy, which is an absolute disgrace to every member of that committee, there is no room in the program for a single stamp for the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association.

If one walks to the post office downstairs now one will see 12 or 13 stamps with the theme of `living together', and Australia Post is going to issue another 12 in that series next month-25 comic characters in one series. We have had fungi depicted on stamps, two lots about horses-we have had everything one can imagine. But this is not the first occasion on which an important event has been snubbed by the stamp issue policy. Apex, an organisation founded in my electorate, celebrated its fiftieth anniversary a few years ago. We had a stamp issued for Rotary International, an American organisation which has become firmly established in Australia. We had a stamp issued for Lions Clubs International, another American organisation, well respected and well founded in Australia, for its fiftieth anniversary. But Australia Post could not fit Apex into the program-until the political pressure by members of this House and persons outside it forced a change in that policy.

I am not asking for people outside the House to take this matter up; I am asking that the Government direct Australia Post to do what it ought to do without direction, not to act in a pseudo foreign policy manner and certainly not to insult the countries of the Commonwealth. Some people may think the countries of the Commonwealth are not sensitive to this type of snub. Some honourable members will recall that, at the last Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference in Australia, when the representatives of one nation came here they left at the front door and went home because their flag was not flying and they considered that an insult by the Australian Government. Unfortunately, it was an error, but those representatives went home.

I think it is about time that someone took in hand Australia Post and its stamp issue policy. Australia Post makes a lot of money out of philatelic sales. I am a member of a society in which people who have collected new issue Australian stamps for over 50 years have ceased collecting this year because of the exorbitant issues of Australia Post and the stupidity of the policy decisions on which they are based.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise matters concerning the attempt of the former Minister for Trade to rig the Spigelman inquiry into pricing arrangements for the export of bauxite and alumina from Gove. When the Minister announced this inquiry in April 1986 he suggested that a transfer pricing arrangement existed between Austraswiss and its Swiss parent. The special investigator appointed was Mr Jim Spigelman, a former Sydney University Labor Club President and a former private secretary to former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, who was appointed by the Whitlam Government in 1975 to head its infamous Department of the Media.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Spigelman's career provides ample proof that, far from being an independent investigator, he is another of the former Trade Minister's cronies with a demonstrable bias in his area of inquiry. In 1972 he wrote a book entitled Secrecy-Political Censorship in Australia. This book provides undeniable evidence of Mr Spigelman's prejudice about transfer pricing. Chapter 6, entitled `A Farrago of Secrecy and Deception', has a subsection entitled `Foreign Investment'. Spigelman began:

Under Section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act the Commissioner of Taxation is empowered to impose special taxation on a foreign-controlled business if he believes that it is earning less taxable income than could be expected. The techniques by which international companies can shift earnings from one jurisdiction to another, such as through intra corporate pricing, are well known. Section 136 is designed to counter such techniques . . .

Section 136 is, of course, the section under which the current Labor Government, in an attempt to recoup revenue allegedly lost by transfer pricing in June 1984, issued tax assessments to Austraswiss for the years 1976 to 1979. The Spigelman inquiry was announced in April 1986 after what Trade Minister Dawkins described as `the Government's frustration, dissatisfaction and lack of confidence in the principal parties involved' in the Gove project. In fact, it followed a vendetta the Minister was waging against Austraswiss in the media at that time. Mr Spigelman's report was intended to be part and parcel of the Government's attempt to press its section 136 vendetta against Austraswiss. Again in 1972, in his book, Spigelman continued:

The Commissioner does not include any information on Section 136 in his annual report to Parliament. When asked for general information he relies on secrecy provisions. The High Court has held that the section imposing an obligation to report to Parliament is in no way qualified by, or subject to, the secrecy provisions. This decision has been ignored. In any case the suspicion that Section 136 is hardly used at all suggests that the failure to give even general aggregate information is designed to hide a vital gap in Australian surveillance of foreign investment in this country.

That appears at pages 109 and 110. That is irrefutable evidence of Mr Spigelman's prejudice about transfer pricing and the use of section 136. Spigelman's appointment as special investigator into exports from Gove must be viewed as a corollary of his and the Whitlam Government's vendetta against multinational mining companies through the use of section 136. In 1975, Spigelman was appointed by Gough Whitlam to the task force to review the continuing expenditure policies of the previous Government. I now quote from Alan Reid's The Whitlam Venture:

On March 28, 1973, Whitlam set up a task force to `apply a close scrutiny to the continuing policies of the previous government so that room may be found for our own higher priority programmes' . . . Rural interests was not represented either through an individual or departmentally. Spigelman, one of Whitlam's secretaries, was, like Whitlam, a lawyer . . .

In 1981, Mr J. J. Spigelman co-authored The Nuclear Barons-the inside story of how they created our nuclear nightmare, a rabid tract which takes a jaundiced view of the nuclear mining industry. I was told of Mr Spigelman's imminent elevation to the ranks of Queens Counsellors prior to this occurring in November last year. In legal circles it was seen as a pay-off for Mr Spigelman's submission of a satisfactory report on transfer pricing with regard to exports from Gove, also due in November, but extended to 1987. Interestingly, a Press release from the then Trade Minister dated 20 January 1987, announcing receipt of the Spigelman report, acknowledges the fact that Mr Spigelman had been made a QC. In short, the former Trade Minister should never have appointed Mr Spigelman and he should be condemned for doing so. I note from Senator Cook's ministerial statement to the Senate last Thursday that the dispute between the Government and Austraswiss has been resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in Question Time I raised the fact that the New South Wales Opposition has proposed to sell public housing at a discount to existing tenants. In answer to my question the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) confirmed that such a proposal by the New South Wales Opposition to sell public housing stock at heavily discounted prices was in direct contravention of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA) to which New South Wales is a signatory. The Minister said that Australian taxpayers have provided substantial funds to develop public housing and New South Wales has benefited in great measure from the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Such an investment cannot be squandered by allowing the Liberal Opposition to get control in New South Wales. The Minister went on to say that not only does the proposal contravene the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement but also, if implemented, it would reverse advances in public housing in New South Wales over the past four years and dramatically reduce the availability of adequate, affordable accommodation for low income families. In fact, it would result in less stock and eventually in higher rents and increased homelessness, which is probably the greatest problem facing low income people in Australia, including, of course, New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister pointed out that, through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, the Federal Government provides funds to the States for home purchase assistance and public rental housing. Under the agreement, New South Wales will receive more than $229m in 1987-88 for public housing. All up, in 1987-88, the Federal Government will make over $344m available for public housing in New South Wales-more than double the $149.9m provided by the previous Federal Government in 1982-83. Of the Federal contribution-I referred to the figure of $299m earlier-around $230m will be provided as direct grants through the CSHA of which $184.4m is untied funds and the balance is allocated to specific purpose programs.

The Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, signed in 1984 by the Commonwealth and all States, specifically prohibits the sale of CSHA-funded public rental dwellings at discount prices. Houses may be sold at market value or at replacement cost to keep the stock there, provided that the funds are directed back into the public housing area. This measure is designed to prevent a run-down in public housing such as occurred under previous Liberal governments. The Minister said that Mr Greiner's proposal would have serious consequences for public housing funding in New South Wales and would force a reassessment of the Commonwealth commitments under the CSHA. He said that with 60,000 people in New South Wales waiting for public housing New South Wales needs a boost in the amount of public housing, not some bargain basement sale of this valuable public asset.

In the State electorate of Waverley in my electorate-the State member is my very dear colleague, Ernie Page-the Waverley Council is beginning to re-implement the housing programs that were instituted by the former Waverley Council and my colleague Ernie Page some years ago. That Council was replaced for four years by a Liberal council which immediately began to dismantle the public housing programs implemented by the former Waverley Council and which became a model for the local government component of the CSHA.

Housing is basic. Public housing availability is essential. Another basic, I point out to the people of New South Wales, is public information. There are rumours going around this place that the Sydney Sun may close. If such a newspaper disappeared it would mean that Rupert Murdoch alone would have control of the evening newspapers in New South Wales, another basic to be taken away from the people of New South Wales-diversity of information. All we know about the Murdoch newspapers overseas like the Sun in London is that they are into all the things that bring disgrace on the newspaper industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I live in an area where, if one sees a big green tree, one quivers with excitement. One rarely sees a big green tree. Hence I was the greenest of all greenies when it came to rainforests until I had the opportunity of going into some rainforests, having had a new area brought into the electorate of Kennedy. There is not much of Queensland that is not in the electorate of Kennedy. I began to understand how gentle and totally compassionate the foresters were in regard to retaining the forest growth and regrowth. Let me explain. Cyclone Winifred came along and swept everything away, including a lot of the rainforests. One cannot even see where that happened now.

SPEECH.PARA: So that is the scenario: I am not a prejudiced anti-conservationist. But what I have seen happen since the World Heritage move has been made by our present Government has been absolutely appalling. Although I love trees, I love human beings much more. Someone said to me the other day, `You are getting all worked up over the people who are losing their jobs and the small contractors who have their backs to the wall at the moment. What about future generations?'. My reply was very precise. The message was loud and clear: future generations will see what has happened in so many other parts of the world and the rainforests will be pillaged. They were being protected by a State government instrumentality. Would it not be a simple little ploy, if one wanted to infiltrate other countries, a small group of nations, to use the argument of World Heritage, the preservation of natural attributes? One could infiltrate psychologically and in every other way. Do honourable members know what is happening? The World Heritage Commission is beginning to get very worried, and for one special reason. May I say that I speak with a little authority on this subject. On two occasions I have been a delegate to the United Nations. One gets to know the people who can give you the dinky-di oil about what is really going on, and I made a number of valuable contacts there. The members of the World Heritage Commission are worried because the United States of America has withdrawn from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation. Britain, Japan, and several others are thinking about withdrawing. Consequently the whole thing is beginning to collapse. I believe-I wish I could produce decisive evidence on this-that they are beginning to look now to whether countries that are coming forward with World Heritage recommendations are doing so for political motives. I want to read out very quickly one of a number of statements I have taken from people, ordinary working people, who are to be found in many areas of my electorate of Kennedy. A Mr John Kidner from Ravenshoe said:
I am married with four school age children. I am a part owner of Kidner Logging Company . . .
Mr Kidner graduated from being an ordinary timber worker to taking over his father's logging business. He said further:
Both my grandfathers were logging with bullock teams. Since World Heritage Listing of our rainforest, we have tried to diversify by putting gravel bodies on our trucks.

Mr Kidner went on to explain that he had hoped to be able to compensate for the loss of contracting in the timber industry by doing work for the local council. However, the local council has its back to the wall. I have a statement also from the Chairman of that local council, Mr Harry Rankin, a courageous man who has given considerable detail about how the areas for which the council is responsible are being absolutely clogged with the unemployed. An inhuman thing has happened in that area. I am sure that many members on that side of the House, if they would come with me to Ravenshoe, would totally agree with me about the inhumanity and lack of compassion associated with this dreadful World Heritage listing of the rainforests of the north.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on behalf of a number of people who work at the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital, and on their behalf I wish to acknowledge the passing of an era. Last week, on 20 February 1988, a group of 38 student nurses completed the three-year training course that they had commenced on 21 February 1985. They were the last group of nurses to complete their course at the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital. Why is that so? The answer is that nursing in Queensland has moved into the twentieth century-and, indeed, into the twenty-first century. Nurses in Queensland will now receive a college education. No longer will they be simply subject to the direction of the school in which they work, and henceforth to the hospital in which they work, and thus be able to move only within a very small range of people who acknowledge their qualifications. Rather, they will be able to move within a very wide circle throughout Australia. I welcome that.

SPEECH.PARA: What really committed me to this course was my being convinced of its worth by a very honest and noble woman who has been Director of Nursing at Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital for a very long time, Matron Patricia Drew. At the graduation ceremony of the group of nurses to which I have referred, Matron Patricia Drew acknowledged and welcomed the fact that Queensland nursing, and particularly nursing at Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital, have moved into the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Her statement made me very happy.

Of course, a number of other people in their late 20s and early 30s talked about bonding and the way in which training in the Queensland nursing system had occurred in the past. But of course they spoke from their own perspective. That is no problem, but these people do have a very real problem when they talk about educating people to work in mainstream Australia. We have to acknowledge, and we are working towards this within the whole nursing education area, the relationship between nurse education and the requirements of Queensland and the rest of mainstream Australia.

I was very happy to be part of that last graduation ceremony at Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital. I acknowledge that it was a very sad day. It was a say day for me because my Dad, who was a Rat of Tobruk, has been very ably nursed and cared for by the nurses at Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital. Nonetheless, we look forward to a future in which Queensland nurses, including those nurses trained at Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital by Matron Patricia Drew, meet the requirements of twenty-first century Australian nursing and enter the mainstream of Australian nursing. I welcome that. This will not lead to a denigration of care, nor does it denigrate the standards of the people who have gone before. It is simply an acknowledgment of the reality of the way in which we hope to continue to care for those veterans in Australia, whom we acknowledge have very special interests. Their carers need very special training.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter of some pressing concern in the defence area. I am very glad that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) is here with us in the chamber because on this issue he might actually be able to answer some questions and get some action taken. I am referring of course to the conversion of the Government Aircraft Factories located at Fishermans Bend and Avalon over to Aerospace Technologies of Australia (ASTA). There are a number of matters in relation to that conversion that are of very real concern. As an example of that concern I take firstly an aerogram issued on Monday, 5 October 1987 to all employees of ASTA by George Stuart, the Managing Director, on the matter of delivery performance. He had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Our customers and potential customers are particularly interested in our ability to meet
delivery
price (cost)
quality
as agreed in contracts.
At the present time, a number of our contracts are behind the agreed delivery schedules and this is causing serious concern to existing customers and will be a deterrent to potential customers.
It was therefore pleasing that during September 1987 our efforts at recovering delivery backlogs were rewarded in some areas. My thanks to those personnel who supported our efforts in this regard.

I would hope that, as we resolve the remaining uncertainties in the formation of ASTA, all employees will commit themselves to achievement of appropriate delivery, cost and quality requirements so as to enable the Company to consolidate its place in the markets in which we wish to compete.

I gather that a lot of those delivery problems still exist. In fact, there have been very serious problems in relation to offset work for the Boeing aircraft company in relation to the completion of obligations there on components, and also work on the FA18 project has been affected most adversely. This has all come about because of the very messy way in which the conversion has been handled. Some 1,500 employees have been taken on by ASTA and some 540 were retrenched. It now appears that that retrenchment figure was higher than needed. There are a number of jobs that are now vacant where key technical personnel are required. In fact ASTA, the new company, has had to go back actually to recruiting people to fill some of those positions, and I understand that at least one person who was retrenched has had to be called back on contract to fulfil some of the technical requirements in those areas. So there are some very real concerns there.

One of those further concerns has to be the fact that, in this conversion process, there are some 80 Public Service personnel who have elected quite legitimately, as is their right, not to join ASTA and who have not yet been placed anywhere. In the Melbourne Sun News-Pictorial of Tuesday, 9 February, their situation was covered in some detail. Of those 80 people, about 40 are located in the Kingsway in Melbourne and another 20 at Fenwick Street in Geelong doing absolutely nothing but sitting around in leased office space because they have not been redeployed anywhere. There are yet a further 20 people at what was the Government Aircraft Factories, now ASTA, at Fishermans Bend and Avalon who are also not at this stage redeployed. They have been given a whole series of very confusing and constantly changing offers of redeployment by the Department. Most of it seems to come down to just temporary make-work situations. The Department has not fulfilled its obligations to give them permanent redeployment.

Their unions-that is, the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, the Association of Drafting, Supervisory and Technical Employees, the Professional Officers Association and the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union-have also absolutely deserted them and are more concerned about playing down the whole thing so as not to embarrass their colleagues in the Labor Government. I understand these 80 people want to work. They want permanent work. They want their statutory entitlements met by the Department of Defence so that they can be redeployed to work that is of value. They are sick of sitting around doing nothing. It does not do the image of the Department any good or the image of ASTA any good for this sort of situation to continue.

I trust that the Minister at the table will kick some tails down there, get things moving and make sure that these people who want to work can get permanent redeployment and that some of the other conversion problems are sorted out so that we do not have the embarrassing situation of delivery problems, with various manufacturing commitments being reneged on or not being met, particularly in relation to Boeing and the FA18s. I trust that the Minister will get things moving in this area and that there will be no further delays.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes remaining for me to speak tonight, I would like to raise a matter that I think represents some good news in the adjournment debate. I refer to a very important initiative that the Australian Government has undertaken at the request of the parliamentary group of Amnesty International. It is very much my belief that people come to the Parliament in the hope and expectation that they can make a contribution and leave this place-and dare we say the world-in a better position than when we first arrived. To that end I think it is extremely important that we look as members of parliament to see how we can make institutional changes in society or government practices that turn out to be an enduring legacy of reform to improve the lot of humankind.

SPEECH.PARA: To this end I make reference to the fact that the Australian Government now takes up as a formal Government initiative every single urgent action appeal of Amnesty International. On every occasion that a signal is sent out from Amnesty International, highlighting the desperate plight of a prisoner of conscience-perhaps someone undergoing torture, threatened with execution or held captive because of his religious beliefs, racial or ethnic origin or for some other reason-what normally happens is that individual citizens around the world take up a letter writing campaign to the offending government. But how much better it would be if the governments of the world would lend their weight to the campaigns of Amnesty International.

I believe the Australian Government has taken a pioneering initiative by formally raising each and every one of those cases through formal diplomatic channels. I do not pretend that this policy is without difficulties because we know that there are often potential issues of trade involved, and sometimes sensitive diplomatic questions. But, if we as a country are seen throughout the world as a forthright and consistent defender of human rights, it is very much my belief that that model for action will spread to other countries and thereby create a vastly improved climate for human rights around the world. I commend the Government for this initiative. I firmly hope that it will be followed by the Opposition parties. I look forward to a response from those parties when in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—I require that the debate be extended.
—The debate may be extended until 11.10 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer a couple of points that have been made by the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) both yesterday and today. I take up, first, the points he made about the Government Aircraft Factories. By way of preface, I should say that in the successive reforms that have taken place in the structure of the now company, the then Government Aircraft Factories, over the last 12 to 18 months, production from Aerospace Technologies of Australia (ASTA)-formerly the Government Aircraft Factories-is now much higher than it was in a global amount, not per capita, when there were 800 more workers in the Factories. Productivity has reached unprecedentedly high levels. The major projects which he mentioned are, I think, by now in large measure back on-stream and are delivering at the expected rates. There are some newer projects in regard to which that is not the case. We are hopeful, however, given the rapidly improving record of the company, that that will not be the case within the reasonably near future.

SPEECH.PARA: A very good job is being done by the work force there in getting back to schedule. Jobs have been advertised at ASTA in recent months. At least some of those jobs are related to new work. Some skills are required for those activities which previously did not reside in the factory. I cannot guarantee that that is the situation in all cases. Naturally, in such a massive change inducing efficiencies in the work force and in the structure of the Factories, when reducing the work force by 40 per cent, somebody will perhaps be let go who would be better kept. Somebody with a particular skill may have been let go, which skill, it was known, would be needed, in the anticipation that somebody better with the same skills could be employed if the jobs were re-advertised. A variety of those sorts of things happens when there is that sort of dramatic change. The honourable member then raised the question of the redeployed workers.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are still there today.

—Yes, I do not dispute the honourable member's facts. Without briefing notes in front of me, I will not confirm his exact numbers, but the general propositions he made are correct. As I understand it, they have received an indication that they will take redeployment in the Commonwealth. The process under industrial legislation, some of which is of much longer standing than this Government, in dealing with Commonwealth employees who are surplus to requirement, is very lengthy. They are not matters within the control of the Department of Defence, nor will they ever be. We are, nevertheless, caught in that situation of being obliged to administer those processes. Certainly, when one is being obliged to administer those processes one is likely to find oneself spending some money that one would rather not have spent.

SPEECH.PARA: All I can say is that we are proceeding in accordance with the industrial practices by which we are obliged to proceed, which are different from those in private enterprise, even though the company now is effectively operating in a way in which most private companies would. We need to follow that through sensitively. We are doing the best that we can in that regard. All I can do is to give the honourable member an assurance that we do not see our interests as being served by the situation persisting as it is at the moment; nor do we see the taxpayers' interests being served by the situation persisting as it is at the moment, and we want it changed. However, we are bound by laws. We will do the best that we can within that framework.

I appreciate the fact that the honourable member for Bruce has raised these matters here. They are worth while talking about. Overall, as a result of the changes that have occurred there and at the other factories, the work force has been reduced from 14,000 to about 8,500. There is a saving of between $80m and $100m per annum on the defence budget, which is making possible, because we get our budget in global amounts, a great deal of the activity we are undertaking at the moment. These are tough times.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. As no other Minister is rising, the Minister may continue until 11.10 p.m .

—As I said, those changes which in terms of savings to the taxpayer far outweigh the costs of the particular problem referred to by the honourable member, are what in effect are keeping the defence budget on program. In fact, an amount of about $100m is equivalent to about 1.5 per cent real growth because it is available to us in Defence to spend in other areas. The House will appreciate that this makes a heck of a difference in the economic times in which we find ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member yesterday raised a number of matters relating to the submarine program. I did attempt to answer them yesterday but Speaker Child thought that 8 o'clock was enough and decided that she would vacate the chair, ignoring the fact that I was standing at the despatch box. I am sure it was overlooked. The points made by the honourable gentleman I am sure I can answer. Firstly, there is no blow-out in costs reported or in prospect. The vast bulk of the work on the submarine is subject to fixed price contracts with very strict variables. We are expecting the work to proceed, and have no reason in anything we are confronting at the moment to expect that it will not proceed, in a satisfactory and cost effective manner.

A point was raised on the question of detail design. Detail design is a complex matter, but the detail design is deliverable by either the end of this year or early next year-in any event in the near future. What the honourable member should appreciate is that we get one set of detail designs which to all intents and purposes is the final detail design. In fact, as the submarine development proceeds, and this would apply to any submarine, we will find situations where we will wish to make adjustments. So the final detail design will be the first submarine that is delivered. There will be subsequent design changes based on the experience of that submarine. The point is that the main design for that submarine is deliverable in the immediate future and will be delivered.

As to the question raised by the honourable member on the issue of the availability of appropriate manpower, already the Australian Submarine Corporation (ASC) has hired over 200 people, mainly from South Australia. It is satisfied with its recruitment program. It has initiated discussions with relevant trade unions, educational institutions and employer organisations in South Australia concerning ASC's needs for skilled workers. Based on these discussions, it appears that there are no insurmountable problems in the long haul in recruiting these people.

In the couple of minutes available to me, I shall refer to the points raised about the cooling systems which are exposed to external sea pressures. The British and United States submarines contain such systems. The design of these and other systems which work at higher pressures are, as in the case of the type 471, subject to a vigorous analysis to ensure a large factor of safety. The Royal Australian Navy is satisfied that the design of those parts for the type 471 cooling system which are exposed to external sea pressure are safe. The overall design of the submarine recognises and incorporates the most modern internationally accepted standards. The production of the critical parts will be subject to 100 per cent quality control, a practice that is now followed by all contemporary submarine builders, including those in the United States and Britain.

These submarines will be a major addition to our defence capability in this country. They are going to be among the most effectively armed attack submarines anywhere in the world. They are going to be useful for the sorts of waters in which we operate. The honourable member can put his mind at rest on all these matters and start to concentrate on other areas of policy where no doubt his attentive research will be more useful.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What system of exchange control now operates in Australia.
(2) Is he able to say how exchange control operates in (a) the USA, (b) Japan, (c) the Federal Republic of Germany and (d) Sweden.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under Australia's current foreign exchange arrangements, the bulk of external transactions are free of exchange control restrictions. However, some categories of external payments are subject to tax screening arrangements. This may require the prior production of a tax clearance certificate before certain overseas payments can be effected or certain declaration forms completed. In addition, the investment at interest in Australia of official reserves by foreign government monetary institutions-while essentially unfettered-must be undertaken in consultation with the Reserve Bank of Australia, which may require certain conditions be met. A general restriction also applies to foreign governments, their agencies not akin to private sector commercial entities, and international organisations undertaking borrowings or other forms of capital raising in Australia.

(2) The International Monetary Fund's 1987 Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions indicates that, as at 31 December 1986 the Federal Republic of Germany and the USA were, like Australia, essentially free of restrictions and requirements of an exchange control nature. The Annual Report also indicates that while most current and a wide range of capital transactions could be readily undertaken under Japan's exchange control arrangements certain categories of capital transactions were subject to prior approval/notification requirements, the coverage of which could be extended during times of balance of payments and other economic disturbances. In the case of Sweden, most current transactions were also free of exchange control restrictions and requirements and, while the majority of capital transactions were subject to prior authorisation, these were in the main normally permitted. Certain categories of capital transactions, however, could only be undertaken on a restricted or limited basis.

(2) The terms of trade are calculated as the ratio of the implicit price deflator for exports of goods and services to the implicit price deflator for imports of goods and services. The terms of trade measure the purchasing power of a country's exports in terms of imports. A fall (rise) in the terms of trade indicates a fall (rise) in the volume of imports of goods and services that can be financed by a given volume of exports of goods and services.

(3) Australia's terms of trade are monitored continuously by the Government, as are reasons for changes and the policy implications of those changes. Movements in world prices of primary commodities (which account for over three quarters of Australia's exports) relative to prices of manufactures in industrial countries (which account for most of Australia's imports) exert a powerful influence on Australia's terms of trade; a general weakening of commodity prices of interest to Australia lies behind the sustained decline over recent years (see table).

(4) and (5) Prices for relevant commodities and manufactures are established in world markets, over which the Australian Government has little or no influence. In these circumstances economic policy has been directed towards making the Australian economy more flexible and better able to cope with external shocks whether they stem from worsening terms of trade, world recession or world stock market adjustments. In essence it is a matter of making the Australian economy more competitive and more productive; details of the Government's policy response, and of the progress being made, are contained extensively in the last two issues of Budget Statement No. 2, `The Budget and the Economy'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are members of organisations with a religious basis exempt from paying taxes?

(2) Are organisations with a religious basis which enter into a commercial operation (a) to grow vegetables for restaurants which are operated and owned by that organisation or (b) to grow flowers for sale, liable to pay tax on profits earned?
(3) Do those organisations pay (a) company or (b) payroll taxes?
(4) Are the employees of such an organisation exempt from paying income tax by virtue of the fact that the organisation has a religious base?
(5) Are profits made by their commercial enterprises taxable?

(6) Are restaurants which are operated by organisations with a religious basis and provide meals, board and lodging or accommodation for their employees liable to pay fringe benefits tax on the benefits provided?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No
(2) (a) and (b)-No

(3) (a)-No. (b)-Payroll taxes are generally levied by the States and thus are not a Commonwealth matter. However, the ACT Payroll Tax Ordinance exempts charitable organisations, where ``charitable organisation'' is defined as ``an organisation, society, institution or body carried on for a religious, educational, benevolent or charitable purpose, other than one carried on for the purpose of securing pecuniary benefit to its members''.
(4) No
(5) As for (2)-No

(6) Generally, yes. However benefits provided by a religious institution to a minister of religion or a member of a religious order provided principally on account of that person's religious duties are exempt.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that there are many low income families paying sales tax at the luxury rate for the purchase of a caravan which is the sole form of housing available to them.
(2) is it a fact that such sales tax is often financed by borrowing at rates of up to 30%, leading to payments of up to $4,000 in tax and $3,000 in interest payments on the accommodation.
(3) Will he provide a sales tax exemption or a substantial reduction in sales tax when a caravan is to be used solely as a permanent residence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The highest rate of sales tax, currently 30 per cent, applies to goods specified in the Second Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. These goods include jewellery, perfumes, cosmetics, audio and video equipment and the more expensive motor cars and station wagons. Caravans are taxable at the 20 per cent rate, commonly referred to as the ``general rate'', which applies to goods not specified in any Schedule to that Act to be exempt or taxable at either the 10 per cent or 30 per cent rates.

(2) The amount of sales tax included in the purchase price depends on the wholesale sale value of the caravan. The ``sales value'' on which the 20 per cent sales tax is payable in respect of caravans is determined on a concessional basis, as 85 per cent of the wholesale selling price of the manufacturer or wholesaler to the retailer. The wholesale selling price would have to exceed $23,500 in order for the sales tax payable to be $4,000.
The amount of interest paid will depend on the amount of money borrowed and the rate of interest. It is possible that some persons may be obtaining finance at interest rates of up to 30 per cent.

(3) Any move to amend the law to provide sales tax relief where caravans are acquired for use as permanent residences would cause administrative difficulties in attempting to distinguish between these and caravans sold for other uses. The intention of the ultimate buyer of the caravan might not be known when the caravan passes the wholesale taxing point, or, if it were known, might not subsequently be adhered to. Further, any reduction in the sales tax payable on caravans purchased as residences would tend to provide the greatest benefit to those who were able to purchase the most expensive caravans and would not provide any benefit to families purchasing second-hand caravans for use as residences.

DEPARTMENT OF EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING
Special Assistance for Students Guidelines to Institutions-1988
Introduction

In accordance with the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1987, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training is required to determine guidelines for the application of special financial assistance to students. The Act also requires the Minister to cause these guidelines to be tabled in each House of the Parliament. It is intended to determine broad principles which will ensure some degree of uniformity in the application and accountability of financial assistance to students, leaving it to each institution concerned to develop its own local procedures and eligibility criteria within the general framework.
Funds being made available under the Act and subject to these guidelines are not provided in substitution for any funds currently available to institutions for loans and grants.
Guidelines

1. Funds provided under the legislation are to be used for the provision of loans or grants to Australian students or students with permanent residency status attending the respective institutions. Funds are not to be used for administrative purposes.

2. Loans or grants should be made available to students who demonstrate a genuine need, particularly those who require assistance for accommodation or for other circumstances where a student's continued study is in jeopardy. In providing assistance institutions should pay particular attention to the requirements of students from country or isolated areas or who are required to live away from home to pursue their studies, and students from disadvantaged groups such as Aborigines and low income groups. Institutions should also take account of the applicant's academic record when considering any application for assistance.
3. Assistance is to be available on a needs basis to students whether residing in halls of residence and affiliated colleges or renting private accommodation.

4. Generally it is expected that financial assistance would be provided in the form of loans. In exceptional circumstances, however, the payment of special grants may be justified. Assistance provided by institutions as grants should not exceed 10 per cent of the total assistance to be made available in any year. Institutions should not regard the 10 per cent maximum as a quota for grants.

5. Administration of loans or grants including the determination of loan periods and repayment policies is to be the responsibility of individual institutions. Many institutions have emergency assistance currently available from within their own resources which could provide a pattern for the administration of additional loans and grants.

6. It is expected that student representatives will be involved in the assessment of applications for assistance, and that information on the criteria used in assessing applications will be publicly available.

7. Loans should normally be provided on a concessional interest rate basis. Institutions should provide for the real value of loan funds to be maintained. There may be cases where, at the institution's discretion, a penalty is applied for default. Students should be required to sign an undertaking that assistance provided will only be used for the prescribed purposes and that the conditions of the loan will be met.

8. The use of these funds is to be accounted for by institutions separately from the use of other funds available to the institutions. Institutions will be required to report annually to the Commission in accordance with Section 13 of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1987.

9. Money obtained from the repayment of a loan (including any interest) or a grant by a student are available for relending by an institution. The Minister may direct that any funds held by an institution at the end of a year may be carried forward and applied for the same purpose in the subsequent year.
10. Institutions also will be required to report from time to time on the details of loans and grants. These reports can be expected to include such matters as:
The numbers, amounts and purposes of loans and grants
The terms and conditions attached to loans and grants
The distribution of loans and grants to:
men and women,
students from country or isolated areas,
students in residences,
socio-economic groups; if practicable,
disadvantaged groups,
Aborigines and other specified groups.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Bicentennial Gift from Mr A. Bond

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 10 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In welcoming the Bicentennial gift from Mr A. Bond of a replica of Captain Cook's barque Endeavour, had his attention been drawn to the number of square rig ships presently being constructed around the country by Government and business capital.
(2) Who will be footing the bill for maintenance and crewing of Mr Bond's gift and what sum is it estimated to cost annually.
(3) What sum is the Commonwealth already committed to pay in the support of other square rig vessels, including the British Bicentennial gift.
(4) Did he discuss any other alternative gestures to the Australian nation which may have been more appropriate and beneficial to the wellbeing of Australian people as a whole.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I was aware that a number of sailing vessels some with historical associations had been or were being built in various States.
(2) The Commonwealth will meet the cost of maintaining Mr Bond's gifts of a replica of the HM Bark Endeavour as a museum exhibit but does not propose to crew it.

It is estimated that $750,000 will be provided annually by the Commonwealth for cleaning, maintenance and museum interpretation costs for the replica. This sum is expected to be partially offset by entry charges to the vessel which is to be berthed at the Australian National Maritime Museum's wharves in Darling Harbour, Sydney.
The vessel will not be crewed by Commonwealth employees although Museum support staff will be allocated to assist visitors inspecting the vessel.

(3) The Government allocated $2.009m in the 1987-88 Budget for the Young Endeavour Youth Scheme, the bulk of which is for salaries and administrative costs associated with establishment of the Scheme in the Defence portfolio. The object of the Scheme is to provide an `Adventure under Sail' for young people from all over Australia.

In addition the Australian Bicentennial Authority has undertaken to pay the voyage costs of trainees for the first four ten-day voyages of the Young Endeavour, these trainees being other finalists from the the selection of the delivery crew of the Young Endeavour. These voyage costs are expected to total $60,000.

In 1985-86 and 1986-87 the Commonwealth Government provided to the Western Australian Government a total of $336,700 towards construction of the sail training vessel Leeuwin under the Commonwealth-State Bicentennial Commemorative Program. There is no commitment to continuing Commonwealth funding for the vessel.
